PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship of any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy the independence of the Corporation

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coates (from 171 citizens), Cooney (from 47 citizens), Devereux (from 164 citizens) and Tate (from 476 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: War Crimes Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The Australian Government's proposed War Crimes Amendment Bill is seriously deficient. It is discriminatory. The attention of the Bill is focussed exclusively on political refugees from the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Yugoslavia. It is bound to result in hostile political stereotyping of refugees from Communist countries and will be profoundly destructive of Australia's multi-cultural society.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that, if the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled are minded to support the War Crimes Amendment Bill, the following provisions be guaranteed:
1. That Soviet, Yugoslav or other similar evidence should be totally disregarded unless corroborated by independent evidence clearly beyond Soviet (or similar) control.
2. That the defendant should have adequate and equal access to archives and site visits, as well as the right to select and interview witnesses from overseas, in the preparation of his defence.
3. No affidavits, videotapes or audiotapes to be admissible as evidence. Witnesses to appear in person and be cross-examined before an Australian jury.
4. The word ``Omission'' to be deleted from s. 6 (1) (k) (III) and s. 6 (5).
5. No extradition to occur before trial or after verdict.
6. Entitlement to legal assistance for the defendant so that he can conduct a proper defence.
7. Financial compensation to any person cleared of war crimes allegations.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migration Education Service: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the President and honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned strongly protest 1987 cuts to ESL programs for adults, conducted by the Adult Migrant Education Service (AMES) in New South Wales.
* Evening ESL classes have been cut by 25%.
* The ESL Correspondence course is to be abolished in a few months time.
* The English-in-the-Workplace Program has been reduced.
* Full-time on-arrival courses have been abolished.
* AMES day centres have had their teaching hours reduced.
* Community programs have lost teaching hours.
We call for:
(i) the full and immediate restoration of AMES teaching programs in New South Wales to at least 1986 levels and
(ii) a substantial increase in funding to AMES programs in the 1987 budget, in view of the recently announced increases in the immigration intake.

Dear Senator Collins,

I refer to your letter of 20 May 1988 in which you sought, in your capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, advice on two aspects of the Information Provision Incentive Payment Rules under section 99AAA of the National Health Act 1953. I believe some background information would be useful in understanding the processing system for which the `CTS Rules' were developed.

Since 1984 the Department has processed claims for reimbursement for pharmaceutical benefits through a payment system known as Pharmpay. Each month pharmacists forward to the Department a claim for payment which is comprised of prescriptions dispensed by them during the previous month. Departmental staff (Pharmpay operators) read the prescriptions and key into the Pharmpay System details of the drugs dispensed. The prescriptions are then priced and, after audit by the Pharmpay System, payment is made to the pharmacist.

During the early 1980s a significant number of pharmacies had installed computer systems to facilitate many pharmacy tasks such as the issue of repeat authorisations, record keeping, drug information, patient information and label production. These systems were developed by commercial pharmacy computer suppliers to meet the demands of the market place. They were not designed by or at the instigation of the Department. Because of this trend towards computerisation, the Department introduced the Claims Transmission System (CTS) to enable such pharmacists to submit their claims in a computer-readable form.

When a pharmacist dispenses a prescription for a patient, details of the prescription are entered into the pharmacist's computer system. At the end of the month the information relevant to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is transferred to a floppy disk which is then sent to the Department together with the bundle of prescriptions to which it relates. The information contained on the disk is then transferred into the Pharmpay processing system thus bypassing the keying normally performed by Departmental staff.
Some pharmacists submit claims by modem transmission rather than on a floppy disk, but the steps are essentially the same.
CTS thus relies on the accuracy of the pharmacist and of the computer systems used by pharmacists, rather than on keying done by Departmental staff.

The Commonwealth instituted an incentive payment of 2.5 cents per prescription to encourage pharmacists to make claims by computer, due to the administrative advantage to the Commonwealth when claims are made this way.

As CTS is in effect a by-product of pharmacy computer systems, the Department has insisted that a number of safeguards are put in place to ensure the security of the system which generates the data for entry into Pharmpay and to ensure that the data generated by the system is accurate. Approval of a pharmacy computer system for use by pharmacists to prepare and/or transmit pharmaceutical benefits claims data is given after the system has been shown, through stringent testing, to meet the Commonwealth's audit requirements.

The `CTS Rules' reflect those safeguards and a key element of the Rules is that the onus has been placed on pharmacy system suppliers to maintain the integrity of their systems so that the transmitted data is accurate.
Your Committee has sought specific advice about rules 24 and 13.
Rule 24 deals with systems which cease to be acceptable to the Department. The rule reads:

`An approved supplier who uses a computer software system which ceases to be acceptable to the Department under these Rules shall not be entitled to claims processing by the preferred method or to the incentive payment until such time as the system again becomes acceptable to the Department.'

It is not in the Commonwealth's own interests to unfairly exclude pharmacists from the Scheme-in fact the Commonwealth is hoping that as many pharmacists as possible will take advantage of the incentive payment and claim by computer in accordance with the Rules. Any decision pursuant to rule 24 to exclude a pharmacist would be made on strictly technical grounds.

Any exercise of the power to cancel approval would leave the decision maker open to review through the normal appeal system ie the Ombudsman or action under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. While there would be no excuse at all for the unjustified exercise of this power, there would be circumstances where a computer software system was no longer acceptable. Such a circumstance could arise where alterations to the system were made by the system supplier which enabled a pharmacist to falsify the data prepared for processing by the Department. This could result in a serious overpayment of Commonwealth moneys.

In such circumstances approaches would be made to the supplier to achieve speedy correction of the fault or deletion of the offending alterations. If this approach failed, the Department would have no option but to cancel acceptance of the system thereby safeguarding public money. The individual pharmacist, although affected, would be reimbursed for benefits supplied through Pharmpay with Departmental staff manually entering the data from the prescriptions.

Similar action would apply if an individual pharmacist tampered with the system or a fault developed with that pharmacist's data production. In this case non-acceptance of CTS data would apply only to the offending pharmacist. Again manual data entry would be used to ensure the pharmacist would still be reimbursed for pharmaceutical benefits supplied.
Rule 13 relates to the use of a patient identification program within pharmacy computer systems. The rule reads:

`An approved supplier using the preferred method is required to enter in the computer system in respect of each concessional prescription or pensioner or entitlement card prescription the number of the Health Care Card, Pharmaceutical Benefits Concession Card, Pensioner Health Benefits Card, Health Benefits Card, Dependant Treatment Entitlement Card, Service Pensioner Benefits Card or Pharmaceutical Benefits Entitlement Card which applies to the person for whom the prescription is written, and in respect of each general prescription the unique identification held by the approved supplier for the person for whom the prescription is written.'

As has been indicated, CTS is a by-product of pharmacy computer systems. A significant feature of these systems is the maintenance of individual patient medication profiles. Software authors have designed their systems to accept individual patient identification so that the medication profiles are accurate and meet State law requirements. In the case of pensioners and other Commonwealth entitled persons the systems accept the entitlement number allocated by the Department of Social Security, Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Safety Net number. In regard to general patients, the approved supplier (pharmacist) allocates his or her own identifying code to patients.
This identifying code would not enable identification of the individual patient by the Department or anyone else (apart from the pharmacist who allocated the code).

However the information available from pharmacy computer systems could provide useful information about utilisation patterns of particular drugs without specifically identifying the patient. This information could also greatly assist in the monitoring of the Scheme from an audit perspective.
I trust this information is of assistance to you and your Committee.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples
25 August 1988
The Hon. Peter Staples, M.P.
Minister for Housing and Aged Care
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting of 25 August 1988, the Committee considered your letter of 18 August 1988 in relation to the Information Provision Incentive Payment Rules Under Section 99 AAA of the National Health Act 1953 relating to Pharmaceutical Benefits. The Committee thanks you for the valuable information provided concerning the schemes known as `Pharmpay'' and ``Claims Transmission System'' and accepts your advice in relation to the Committee's query concerning Rule 13.
In this Committee's letter to you of 20 May 1988, concern was also raised in relation to review rights applicable to Rule 24 and I quote from that letter:

``It would seem that an unjustifiable adverse exercise of this discretion could cause commercial injury to a supplier. While recognising that there must be adequate computer compatibility for your proposed scheme to operate successfully, the Committee wondered if any avenue of appeal or review existed to provide redress should an unfair decision be made that a system was and remained unacceptable.''
Your reply to the Committee indicated that the following avenues of review were available:

``Any exercise of the power to cancel approval would leave the decision maker open to review through the normal appeal system, i.e. the Ombudsman or action under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. While there would be no excuse at all for the unjustified exercise of this power, there could be circumstances where a computer software system was no longer acceptable.''

While acknowledging that there are appeal avenues available through these channels, the Committee is concerned that a merits review right of the discretionary power in Rule 24, through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, was not included in the avenues open to an approved supplier who uses a computer software system. This right of appeal would cover the unfortunate circumstance where the discretionary power was, by mischance, used to the disadvantage of a pharmacist. The Committee would concede that the example provided by you in your letter would require action by the Department but such action would, no doubt, bring against the pharmacist charges of fraud and court action.

The Committee was surprised that a merits avenue of appeal was not included as the National Health Act 1953 in Part VIIa-Reviews by Administrative Appeals Tribunal has extensive provisions for the review of discretionary decisions by the Minister or a delegate of a Minister.
The Committee would appreciate your further views in relation to this matter.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
28 September 1988
Chairman
Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter of 25 August 1988 in which you sought, in your capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, my views as to the review rights applicable to rule 24 of the Information Provision Incentive Payment Rules under section 99aaa of the National Health Act 1953 relating to pharmaceutical benefits.

I have noted the Committee's concerns regarding the adequacy of the current appeal mechanisms available in respect of an exercise of power under rule 24 which may act to the disadvantage of a pharmacist and the Committee's surprise than an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was not included in the National Health Act. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade: Australia's relations with India, with particular reference to:
(a) prospects for increasing trade between the two countries; and
(b) the implications for the regional strategic outlook of India's enhanced defence capability.

Compared with the attention which has been given by Australian government and business to the countries of east and South East Asia and the South Pacific, the south Asian countries, particularly India, have been relatively neglected. India is also a country on the Indian Ocean concerned with regional stability-in this case, to our west. The political harmony and economic growth of the countries of south Asia should be matters of strong interest to Australia.

The present Australian Government has made efforts to renew and expand the relationship with India, particularly in developing the potential for economic cooperation between the two countries. Many Australian businesses are now becoming involved in India in areas as diverse as banking and investment, shipbuilding and port development, and optic fibre and coal technology.

The significant development of the Indian defence forces, particularly the expansion of naval capability, has been of interest to international observers in recent years, but its dynamics have not generally been well understood.

As `neighbours' in the Indian Ocean, we in Australia share an interest in maintaining stability in that region. As India seeks to expand its naval presence, its strategic importance for us will increase.
Increasingly, political dialogue with India is taking place on areas of mutual concern such as Kampuchea, Fiji and Antarctica. We are also engaging in dialogue on multilateral trade issues.
I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated in the record.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Other aspects of the relationship are developing, albeit slowly. In science and technology, there is a project underway whereby an Australian `state of the art' remote sensing device will be flown in an Indian satellite, and the University of New South Wales and the Indian firm Central Electronics Limited (CEL) are working on a project for the development of a photovoltaic cell. A Memorandum of Understanding on monsoon meteorology research should be signed shortly. Cultural relations is another area of expanding cooperation, where advances are being achieved on a small budget.

But the economic relationship is a crucial part of the whole, and one likely to become increasingly important in the future as both Australia and India look to expand and develop their respective economies.
Trade between the two countries has varied considerably over the past decade, and shown a significant improvement over the last five years.

India is among those countries showing the highest trend growth-37%-as a destination for Australian exports over the 5 years to 1987. Australian exports have increased from $151.7 million in 1983 (0.7% of total Australian exports) to $444.3 million in 1987 (1.2% of total exports);
India now ranks 19th as a destination for Australian exports (up from 21st in 1985);
major exports in 1987 were coal (177 million); wool (99 million); lead (31 million); computers and office machinery (26 million); vegetables (25 million); zinc and zinc alloys (10 million);
India is the sixth largest market for Australian coal exports.

In the past, trade between the two countries has been limited. On the Australian side it has been based almost entirely on export of primary commodities, particularly coal. Imports from India have mainly been textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF).

The outlook for export of traditional commodities (coal, non-ferrous metal, wool) is good over the medium term and will remain an important source of export revenue. But, in the longer term, prospects will reduce because of India's drive to self-sufficiency and its sourcing of requirements from elsewhere as prices fluctuate. For instance wheat, a major export in the decade up to 1985, no longer figures as an export item because India has achieved self-sufficiency in this area. India's current economic development includes exploitation of its coal reserves.
But India is seeking to boost economic growth through liberalisation policies aimed at:
encouraging private enterprise and investment;
overcoming the deficiencies of the public sector; and
forcing Indian manufacturers to enhance productivity and competitiveness by allowing acquisition of new technology for modernisation.
Policy steps towards liberalisation have included:
easing of licensing restrictions,
permitting greater transfer of technology from abroad through joint ventures; and
moves to streamline foreign investment processes for individual countries (notably Japan, Canada, the United States and West Germany).

Exports of Australian manufactured goods, technology and services have increased in recent years, and are expected to grow in conjunction with the liberalisation process. India's economic growth will also enhance the prospects for export of Australian capital and consumer goods. A commonly cited estimate of the size of the Indian consumer middle class at present is up to 100 million.

Turning to defence matters, the Soviet Union has recently loaned to India a nuclear powered submarine of the Charlie class. This is said to be the forerunner of a flotilla of six nuclear-powered Victor III hunter-killer submarines. The Victor III submarines are capable of deploying the Soviet SSN-7 underwater-launched anti-ship missile, which can carry a nuclear warhead-although it is not known if such a capability is planned by the Indian Navy.

This development has focused international attention on the enhancement over recent years of Indian naval and military capability. The Indian navy, for instance, now possesses two aircraft carriers, equipped with Sea Harriers and Sea King helicopters. A third carrier is planned. As well as the nuclear powered submarines, a flotilla of eight German-designed Type 1500, electrically powered submarines is planned. India's overall defence budget is equivalent to approximately 5% of GDP, and for 1987/88 was estimated at $US 9.73 billion.

This is not to posit a threat to Australia's security. The Minister for Defence has clearly stated that India has not and does not constitute a threat to Australia's security. The Prime Minister has indicated that India and Australia as active members of the Commonwealth, have enjoyed a cooperative approach toward international and regional issues for more that 40 years. Furthermore, as a leading member of the Non-aligned Movement, India has always asserted a strongly independent stance in world affairs.

Nevertheless, it is simply prudent for Australians, and especially for a Committee of the Senate charged with defence matters, to take account of all military and naval developments that are occurring in our region of strategic concern, and to ensure that in the development of Australia's defence posture any appropriate responses are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the motion and say that, while the Opposition has no objection to this referral, we draw attention to the fact that this suggestion has come from the executive side of the Parliament and not from the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade itself. As I understand it, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has asked the Committee to deal with the matter. One has no objection to Ministers asking committees to deal with matters. That is perfectly all right. But I would have thought that this Committee should set its own agenda and its own priorities. While I take no objection to this reference being referred to the Committee-as I say, my colleagues on the Committee approve of it-I believe that Labor committee chairmen should set their own agenda. We adopted this practice when we where in government. I urge committee chairmen to observe the parliamentary supremacy principle of the Westminster system. In other words, it is for them to determine the agenda of their committees and not to become simply another arm of the executive government.

—in reply-Can I make it abundantly clear to the Senate in reply to the point made by Senator Lewis that this proposed reference has come totally from the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade itself. Of course, Government members, Opposition members and Senator Dunn are represented on the Committee. There has been no request at all from the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) that we pursue this reference. I think that point should be made in response to what has been said by Senator Lewis.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Can I briefly add that what Senator Maguire says is correct. I was not consulted on this matter and I regret any misunderstanding as a result of the lack of that consultation. All I want to say is that I believe that Australia's relationship with India has been a too much neglected area of our foreign relations. When I was a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of this Parliament this matter was proposed as an urgent priority for us to study further and to bring into focus for the Parliament and for Australians as a whole. Therefore, it is not surprising that this was a matter that was proposed by members of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I certainly supported the priority of that reference and I am happy to support the motion that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Maguire, has brought to the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That the Pharmaceutical Benefits Declaration, as contained in Declaration No. PB 3 of 1988 and made under subsection 85 (2) of the National Health Act 1953, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening when I was debating this issue I was pointing out that because 53 pharmaceuticals have been taken off the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and put on the authority list this has made it very difficult, particularly for general practitioners, to be able to treat their patients urgently. We are told that all these vital areas where people need drugs instantly are able to be undertaken through a hotline. I have been assured that the hold-up on the hotline is sometimes quite acute. Doctors now have to try to encourage their patients to come back and see them while they still have at least a week's medication left because it will take a week for the authority for the prescription to get back.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the patients, particularly pensioners, that are being disadvantaged. The chemists are finding that they will not be able to carry out this idiotic nonsense. I have received so many photograms. The Government may be interested in the thickness of the number I have received because there is a considerable number here. As I have already said, they strongly object to these changes in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. They say that it will create a two-class system, with the elderly and disadvantaged being treated as second-class citizens. One letter I have says that pensioners are deeply concerned and they are speaking not only to the doctors in showing their concern but also to the pharmacists. The pharmacists share that concern. They say that there will be increased paperwork which will cause patient delays and public outrage will result. Another chemist says, `A reversal is needed of this ill-conceived change'. `Doctors and pharmacists are trained for excellence', one says. Another says, `They will not accept pressure for second best. Patients will be forced to accept second rate health care. Urgent discussions and revisions are necessary'. Another one says that if the benefits scheme goes ahead, `I will be telling all my customers that the present Government is intent on destroying the quality of life of health care in Australia'. That statement came from another chemist and so they go on.

I have a whole range of views from chemists who say that the scheme is unworkable and will only result in a second-rate health system in this country. To obtain one of the drugs mentioned for treating severe diarrhoea of greater than two weeks duration in infants under the age of four months, they have to seek written authority from the Secretary or, as I have explained, use the alternative method. From my small medical knowledge as a nurse, I would have thought that severe diarrhoea of greater than two weeks duration in infants under the age of four months would be pretty critical. Yet to prescribe the drug that is the best treatment for this condition-admittedly, it is more expensive than other drugs that are not as effective-the doctor has to write and ask, `Please can I use it?' or the doctor may use the hotline which, according to the Government, is available.

All members of the medical profession who have approached me in this regard have said that this system is delaying and cannot be tolerated if they are to deliver the best health care to patients. Doctors will have to go through this process because they will not tolerate their patients having second best. As a result, the administration of the Department will be massive. I would like the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) to drop his newspaper for a few minutes and tell me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give me one good reason why I should listen to you.
—I am asking the Minister a question. Can he tell me--
—I do not have the floor. Are you ceding the floor to me?

—No, I am asking a question. Will the Minister look into the cost of the administration of this scheme? How many public servants will be required to answer the telephone hotline? How many public servants will be required to answer all the requests by general practitioners and specialists requiring these drugs for their patients? The whole situation is quite ludicrous. The Government, in its attempts to cut costs purely for the ideological position it has taken on health, is creating a second class health system. If the Government wants to save money it should take my advice and cut out bulkbilling. That would save the Government more than its $40m which it aims to save from this little exercise. As I said yesterday, it could have spent far better the $46m that it spent on the abortive referendum campaign, the referendum--
—Fiasco.
—Fiasco; thank you, Senator. It could have spent the money far better on the health of the nation than on trying to diddle the community into believing that our Constitution needed to be changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to my happy lot to do as I often do in this chamber; that is, follow Senator Walters. I must say that I have not heard a more outrageous performance from Senator Walters for a long while. It was quite over the top. It was the most disgraceful misleading and misrepresenting of the facts of this matter that I have heard in many a day. I do not know a better word for it than lies. I think that what has been happening with this debate--

—I raise a point of order. I take strong objection to Senator Crowley in effect calling Senator Walters a liar and I ask her to withdraw it. I ask her not to make such allegations again during her speech, otherwise I will continually interrupt her speech.
—Order! I ask Senator Crowley to withdraw the accusation of lies.
—I will withdraw the reference, but I will now proceed to devote half an hour to pointing out that what Senator Walters did yesterday misrepresented the truth. (Quorum formed)
—Order! Senator Crowley, will you withdraw the comment about lies?

—I have already withdrawn it. I think I have some things to do in this debate. One is to give the complete contradiction to Senator Walters's claims. I would like to take honourable senators through the debate we have had to this point. Senator Puplick opened this debate by bringing a disallowance motion into this chamber addressing the listing for authority of 53 drugs under the National Health Act 1953, subsection 85 (2). I thought the disallowance motion threatened to make Senator Puplick burst yesterday, such was his performance of hot air and rhetoric. It was a quite splendid performance-totally remote from the point being debated here. Senator Puplick mostly used the opportunity to whack and slather over a whole area. He certainly did not convince me or anybody else of the importance of his claim that this disallowance motion should be supported. Senator Cook refuted all those claims and, most accurately and properly, dealt with the Government's position.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not heard all the speakers opposite, though I had the opportunity to listen to Senator Peter Baume in some part yesterday. I refer honourable senators opposite to Senator Peter Baume's speech because that illustrated one way of tackling an issue and at least he tried to stay on the point. He was followed by Senator Margaret Reid, who gave us an eloquent discourse on the failures of Medicare in the Canberra hospital system, which has absolutely nothing at all to do with the disallowance motion before this chamber. Senator Walters has actually given us a rundown on the insufficiencies of statisticians and Dr De Souza's assessment that three visits to specialists at an extra cost is not sufficient to deal with a condition, all of which is splendid. It is from times past and has absolutely nothing to do with the disallowance motion before this chamber.

It is clear that Senator Walters would speak about anything but the motion because there is no way in which she could properly defend it. What she did say when she addressed it was outrageous. She very much endorsed Senator Puplick's words, which were to establish and elaborate on the scaremongering that the Opposition and a number of other people have been doing on this topic to frighten pensioners and patients around this country into the understanding that, if they wanted these drugs, doctors would not be allowed to give them. That is an absolutely outrageous lie. It is a scandalous misrepresentation of what is the case. The disallowance motion for those reasons, if that is what the Opposition is arguing, is totally unnecessary. They are not the facts. Senator Walters may well not know what are the facts but Senator Puplick does, and he was shameful in his performance on air yesterday, contributing further to the fear of many of the very people he is supposed to represent in here, beating his heart and the air in so-called support for their position. (Quorum formed)

As I was saying, members of the Opposition, in their contribution to the debate to this point, have certainly not made any points to warrant support for the disallowance motion brought into this chamber by Senator Puplick. In fact, their contribution has been very much to misrepresent the facts and contribute to the scaremongering campaign that frightens the very people they claim to support.

One point that Senator Walters made was that the Government seemed to want to put certain drugs back on to the special list, the authority list, for the purposes of saving money and cutting costs. That is absolutely right. Saving public expenditure is not a thing to blush about, and it is not a thing that this Government blushes about. Indeed, I have listened to members of the Opposition wax eloquent on any number of occasions about the importance of cutting public expenditure outlays. Why is it that it is legitimate for those opposite to propose to cut costs but, when we do it, it is an outrage? I do not understand how the Opposition can claim that cutting Government expenditure costs, even allowing for the fact that in this instance we do not identify the particular cost-cutting measure, makes any difference at all. Even if we just look at the importance of Government expenditure restraints, Senator Walters seems to suggest that that is an outrageous thing to do. It is not; it is a useful thing to do. In this exercise it is useful because it has been done under the recommendations of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. It is not a wanton act by the Government at all, and I will give some further evidence in a moment that strongly supports that contention.

Those opposite continually tell us that the problem with the Government is that we are not cutting expenditure enough. That they can keep saying that in the face of our achievements is yet more evidence of their own difficulties, not ours. But to argue, as was done here yesterday, that cost cutting is what the Government is on about as though this is somehow deplorable is very peculiar indeed. The Government is determined to try to restrain expenditure. That is exactly what it is doing, but it is doing it in a way that does not disadvantage any patient, does not delay the filling of prescriptions, does not interfere with the quality of medical care, does not interfere with the doctor-patient relationship and does not tell doctors how to practise their medicine. It does none of those things, Senator Walters, and when you say that that is the case you are wrong, you are mischievous, and you are misrepresenting the truth in a very wicked way and contributing to the scaremongering tactics that have upset and could frighten the very pensioners and sick people in this country that you claim to protect. It is scandalous, Senator Walters-absolutely scandalous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, will you please address the Chair and not other senators.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I was saying, Senator Walters's behaviour is scandalous. (Quorum formed). The point that needs to be made is that, under the provisions whose disallowance is being argued for, the changes in prescription proposals will in no way disadvantage patients or interfere with good medical practice or the doctor-patient relationship. The Government is not telling doctors how to practise medicine, but it is asking them when prescribing a prescription drug to consider whether there is a cheaper alternative that is just as effective.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of evidence, I cite what happened with the removal from the authority list of 17 drugs in 1985. After that removal of the authority restrictions, all but two-15-of the 17 drugs continued to be legally available to patients; the terms on which they could be provided remained exactly the same. There was no change in the wording at all. But there was a dramatic blow-out in the prescribing of those drugs after they were taken off the authority list. They were on the special purpose list. The requirement for thoughtfulness in their prescription remained. In the six months to June 1984 the total number of prescriptions for all 17 drugs was about 150 per thousand. By December 1987 that figure had increased to 650. There was a massive blow-out in the prescription of those 17 drugs following their removal from the authority requirement listing.

The Government is aware that doctors change their prescribing habits consequent upon some of the decisions the Government makes on advice from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. In this instance the Government has taken advice from that Committee. I can see Senator Puplick about to say, ``Aha, but they were given restricted advice'. The Committee was given a request, to which it properly attended. It properly advised the Government, which in turn properly responded with two considerations in mind-cost constraints and the continuing practice of good medical care. Those things are in place.

There is always a mechanism for addressing complaints from doctors and difficulties of pharmacists, not by the ham-fisted way that Senator Puplick is proposing of a disallowance in this area but by further review of the pharmaceutical benefits schedule and by Ministers taking requests for further examination to that Committee if that is what people want. If there are difficulties consequent upon this listing, they can be considered and decided by that Committee in the appropriate way.

The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) explained clearly yesterday some of the unintended consequences-we hope they would be unintended-of this disallowance motion being passed. What Senator Puplick proposes does not address the point that he has raised-that is, cost constraint-because this declaration will certainly have some cost constraining effect. The disallowance motion will not alter the prescribing habits of doctors. It is not about that at all, but if those drugs are taken off the list I can cite evidence that they will more likely be used. The authority prescription does not prevent any doctor from requiring them to be provided or having them provided to patients, as Senator Puplick well knows. To suggest that people cannot get treatment for epilepsy or a heart condition when these are the drugs of choice of their doctors is wicked and mischievous and it is not true. I simply say again that anybody who is judged by the doctor to be in need of these medications will get them without delay. That must be understood. The Department of Community Services and Health has been at pains to make sure that the procedures are minimally difficult for doctors. It has established a hotline so that a doctor who needs authority very quickly can get it straightaway. If the hotline is not available to the doctor, he has the opportunity to write `Urgent' on the third copy of the authority form and send that authority to the Department within a week. The prescription can be taken out of the rooms there and then by the patient. If the drugs are needed urgently there is no prospect of delay. Senator Puplick knows that, and if he does not then he was not adequately briefed. He has brought a very inappropriate motion for disallowance into the Senate and used up a lot of time on this mischievous nonsense. If he did know it, then he is disgraceful for not making it clear in his debate.

I hope I have laid to rest the point made by Senator Walters about delays and difficulties for patients. It is not the case and the motion for disallowance cannot be sustained by that kind of argument. The problem does not exist. Senator Walters argued about cost containment. Precisely: the Government is unashamed in saying that this is about restraining costs. I cite the clear evidence of the cost blow-out once 17 of those drugs were removed from the authority listing over the period from 1985 to 1987. Doctors' prescribing behaviour will change according to the listing of drugs in one or other category of the pharmaceutical benefits schedule. We know that; the medical profession knows it. Many people would be at pains to advise the Government to take great heed about some of these medications. I think it was Senator Peter Baume, but it may well have been Senator Puplick, who talked about the seriousness of these drugs. They are very potent and powerful chemicals. They have very significant side effects. In the case of anti-cancer treatment, they are used with great caution and great care. The medical profession, let alone the pharmacy profession, would be saying that we need to make sure that these drugs are provided in a considered and thoughtful way.

Across the board, the professions involved are concerned about the costs. It is not only the Government that says we must ponder on how best to provide pharmaceuticals to the people in the fairest and most equitable way. Some honourable senators in this place have raised, for example, the cost of treatment for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) sufferers. It is a very expensive treatment indeed. Where does that fit in? Are we to take no regard of the huge cost for treating one person with AIDS? Are we to put a value on that kind of condition or the quality of life for such people? I think Senator Puplick would be one to argue that we do. We have to weigh all those things in a fairly thoughtful and complex equation. That is what the Government is doing, and it has done it properly on advice from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. This is not a random arbitrary approach; it is the system that has been in place for a long time. The authority listing is not new. Senator Peter Baume mentioned that yesterday. We have had authority listing, and doctors have been properly and ably coping with that requirement on their pharmaceutical dispensing practices, for over 30 years.

This is not a new tyranny or some horrible thing that has just been introduced. This action has been cause for concern for a few reasons but principally because a scare campaign was initiated by the Australian Medical Association (AMA). I could cite, though I will not, letters from the AMA urging doctors to boycott the proposals for change by the Government and, more than that, to urge their patients to write letters and take up the cudgels against the Government. This was clearly a campaign led by some members of the AMA to promote and create fear and anxiety-the very thing Senator Puplick claims he does not want for patients. If he really wanted to address the issues of patient concern, of care for patients, of quality medical practice, he would have criticised that AMA campaign because it did precisely the sort of thing he says that the listing of these drug does. The drugs listing puts a requirement on doctors to be thoughtful when they write scripts for those drugs. It is certainly not about terrifying or tyrannising patients. It is not about requiring doctors to practise their medicine in a way that they do not choose. It was never the Government's intention, and it is not a consequence of this Government's decision, to scare patients or to practise the fear and tyranny that the AMA proposed and led campaign did.

It rather shocks me to see Senator Puplick arguing on behalf, he tells us, of the patients of this world-the old and the sick-precisely the sort of scare and fear campaign that the AMA conducted. If he were genuine he would have put down the AMA; he would have criticised its campaign for doing precisely the sort of thing he wanted this motion for disallowance to save us all from. He cannot have his motion for disallowance because his argument has no evidence, no facts, to sustain it. This is clearly a cost constraint measure by the Government. The Government makes that clear and is not apologetic about it. Cost constraint is being introduced in a way that evidence has suggested will be effective. I can cite the evidence of what happened previously when medications were removed from the authority listing. There is clear evidence that this is likely to have some cost constraining effects.

It is done on advice from a committee that has been set up specifically. It has medical and pharmacist representation and is a properly constituted, thoughtful committee that has been contributing to government for years. It is also open to government to take further advice at any time and review decisions, and that is an ongoing process. It is done by government in a way that does not interfere with the doctor-patient relationship or with how doctors practise medicine. It does not require any delay in the provision of medications if doctors decide that these are their drugs of choice for their patients.

Finally, the changes come with an education campaign. The Government will expend $2m to further assist doctors in the practice of good medicine through an education campaign on the latest and greatest of drugs. Doctors need to be reminded about those things and assisted from time to time. Anybody who has followed the treatment of cardiac diseases over the last 10 years would know how drugs that were the drugs of choice 10 years ago are no longer so much in favour. Some had side effects and have gone out of favour and some have been replaced by better and more precise drugs. The Government is proper, comprehensive and responsible in this area. No evidence has been brought in this place to justify support for this motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in this debate, not to cause concern to the people of Australia, which Senator Crowley seems to think we are doing, but more as a reaction to the number of people who have come to my office, the hundreds of people who have submitted signatures on petitions, and the numbers of doctors and pharmacists who have made representations to me. If Senator Crowley thinks that the Opposition is using scaremongering tactics amongst the people of Australia, perhaps the Government should get its public relations act together. The people of Australia are scared; they are concerned about these changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Act. That is why this side of the House is urging disallowance of the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not the only people who are concerned about this matter. Senator Crowley mentioned a hotline, and I notice with some interest that her colleague the Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia has set up a hotline. His hotline proclaims `Help us to get the drugs you need'. In this way he is asking the people of Western Australia to lobby the Federal Government in an attempt to change things. I suggest that Senator Crowley should at least try to convince her Labor colleague in Western Australia that his fears are certainly unfounded. The Minister for Health in Western Australia has indicated that the Western Australian Government is fighting for an urgent review of the drugs on this list. He also says that patients are suffering as a result of these changes.

Quite obviously, the Government and Senator Crowley and her colleagues have not convinced the Labor Minister for Health in Western Australia. Yesterday Senator Panizza presented to the Senate a petition with thousands of signatures of people who are opposed to this proposal. That also shows how far out of touch the Government is with the people out there in the community. Many people are worried and concerned about the need for and the supply of these life prolonging drugs. It seems that the Government, which is so out of touch with the people, seeks to break down the good relationships which exist between doctors and patients and which have been part of our lifestyle for so many decades. Why should a paper shuffler have the right to say what is the best drug for a person who is in desperate need of the best medication? What right has a government that is so out of touch with the people to take away the best medical care and the best drugs available and let the bureaucrats have the final say?

Regardless of the question of the drugs, my main concern about this whole matter is the requirement to disclose to the bureaucracy certain facts about a person's health. It is another attack on the privacy and confidentiality of the people of Australia. I have been in this place for only a little over 12 months, but in that time I have seen all sorts of attempts by the Government to attack the privacy and confidentiality of the Australian people. We all remember, of course, the ID card proposal, and that was soundly rejected by the Australian people because of its meddling in people's privacy. I remember, just after I became a senator, sitting in the Hobart Town Hall and listening to Senator McLean. Unfortunately, he is not in the House at the moment, and he seems to have turned his back on this place like he has turned his back on the people of Australia. He spoke very well about people's privacy and the rights of people. However, now he and his colleagues in the Australian Democrats are turning their backs on the people and selling out the people in relation to the matter of their privacy, even though he defended it so well some 12 months ago. The honourable senator is allowing this legislation to go through, and in doing so he is endorsing the proposal to make doctors divulge private medical information to unknown bureaucrats.

Yesterday, I listened with interest to what Senator Coulter had to say, as the spokesman for the Democrats on this matter. He said that he strongly supported a review of the situation. If that is the case, why do the Democrats not do the honourable thing and support the coalition in disallowing the regulations? If they do that, the situation will be reviewed. Unfortunately, none of the Democrats is here at the moment and so I cannot implore them to change their mind and support us in moving for disallowance of the regulations.

There are plenty of other examples of the Government's having meddled in the privacy of people's affairs over the past 12 months. Right at this moment we have this illegal Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey, which is causing people a lot of concern. One has only to pick up the papers and read the letters to the editor from people who do not know whether the ABS survey is legal. There has been a lot of debate about the matter. The fact is that people in the community are having to fill out diaries, to give up their confidential bank accounts, and to disclose confidential information about their indebtedness, their insurance policies, and all sorts of things which once upon a time most people in Australia thought were private.

If we need any other evidence about what has been happening in relation to privacy and the lack of it in the past 12 months, who can forget the Blewett affair, when we saw people in Dr Blewett's Department releasing confidential medical numbers? Who is to say that this confidential pharmaceutical information that doctors have to give up will not, too, find its way out into the wide world?

Today Senator Crowley accused us of causing concern amongst the sick and the needy in the community. Just how much concern did the Government cause when it saw fit to retrospectively reduce the pension assistance to some 50,000 Australians-people who had retired and thought that they had invested wisely in approved schemes, only to find that in a greedy grab for funds the Government had come up with some other ideas? Had it not been for the fact that the temporary Premier of Victoria was having an election, those 50,000-odd people would now be in terrible trouble and would have been caused great concern by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-who at the moment is telling the rest of the world how to run its affairs. In the meantime, back home, the honourable member for Jagajaga, Mr Staples, and a few others are trying to convince the citizens of this country to take second best health treatment. The honourable member for Jagajaga said:
We are simply asking doctors to think twice before prescribing expensive drugs where there are other possible cheaper alternatives.

Senator Crowley mentioned earlier that the Government is spending some $2m on trying to educate doctors and inform them about drugs. I always thought that doctors educated themselves very well. They spend many years at medical school and universities trying to make sure that they can give the best health care to the Australian people. I am sure that they welcome the fact that the Government is going to spend $2m to inform them about all these drugs. But I am sure that doctors can do without the meddling by the Government in the affairs of doctor-patient relationships-which seems to be the result of this exercise.

If the Government is so concerned about costs, perhaps it should look at the cost of pharmaceuticals in Australia compared to the rest of the world. As a percentage of average weekly earnings, we find that prescription costs in Australia are about 2.6 per cent. In relation to other countries-where Mr Keating is giving advice-for instance, in Canada, the percentage is 4.7 per cent, and in Britain it is 3.6 per cent.

I noticed that again today Senator Crowley tried to shift the blame for all this concern in the community from the Government to the doctors. That does not surprise me. As far as I am concerned, doctors are honourable people, engaged in an honourable profession. However, the Government apparently believes otherwise, because at every opportunity in recent times those people in Government responsible for health issues have attacked the medical profession on any pretext whatsoever. I know that doctors have broad shoulders and that they are used to working under pressure for many hours, but I wonder what sort of pressure their patients are used to working under. That is why the doctors are concerned. There is no monetary value in this for doctors at all. It is a genuine concern, as is the case with the pharmacists. The reason I am standing here today is that a genuine concern has been expressed to me by people out there in the community. It seems to me that this greedy Government does not trust anyone to have feelings of compassion.

If we look at the record, it is evident that the doctors are the people who are copping most of the brunt of the Government's mistrust. As far as I am concerned, a doctor with many years of training and with his professional reputation on the line will prescribe a drug only if he knows that it is necessary and the most suitable course of treatment. Under this new arrangement he will be required to second guess the decision of a bureaucrat in Canberra. That bureaucrat will have no contact with a patient and no access to that patient's medical records. Therefore, the doctor will be in a gambling situation, particularly in cases which may be borderline.

I suggest to the Senate that doctors must be able to operate freely without restrictions, knowing that they can take the safer option rather than the more dangerous option both to the patient and to their own professional standing and careers. It is my opinion that people, whoever they are, deserve the best care and, naturally, the best drugs available to keep them healthy or at least comfortable. Certainly, not just the doctors are concerned about this matter. As I mentioned previously, the Labor Party in Western Australia seems very concerned. I have mentioned some of the concern that has been expressed by Keith Wilson. I just hope he keeps reminding this Government that patients are suffering as a result of these changes. I repeat that no Australian deserves second best.

If the only reason this Government is inconveniencing people is monetary gain, perhaps it should look at increasing the cost of drugs in a small way right across the board instead of selecting a few unfortunate people in our community to carry this burden. The reality of the situation is that 75 per cent of the drugs in question are ACE inhibitors which are used for the treatment of high blood pressure. On the one hand we see the Government trying to cut costs in this way; and yet, on the other hand-and commendably so-it is supporting the National Heart Foundation which is carrying out a massive education campaign. Many senators will remember the Balloons Aloft exercise that was conducted last year from which we raised some $37,000. That is a good example of what the Government can do in a positive manner. But this exercise is going to make it difficult for patients to receive life-saving drugs. As Keith Wilson from Western Australia said, it places them unnecessarily at risk of death.

To sum up, it seems to me that the Government has rushed into another minefield without thought for the welfare of Australian people. It has ignored consulting with doctors and, as a consequence, many important drugs used in the treatment of cancer and hypertension are not as readily available as they should be. This decision is certainly going to create undue stress and concern for a lot of patients who should not be placed in that position. As Senator Walters pointed out earlier, it will create huge amounts of paper work and bureaucratic control which certainly are not needed. But, most important of all, it allows the private relationship between doctor and patient to be open to public scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public scrutiny?
—Public scrutiny.
—Whose public scrutiny?

—The public scrutiny of the bureaucrats. We have already seen evidence of bureaucrats releasing information to the general public. Why should anyone who is terminally ill or who has some disease which he or she does not want anyone to know about run the risk of these sorts of things being made known? Senator Coates knows what could happen in a small city like Hobart in Tasmania. Does a distinguished person like Senator Coates think that bureaucrats would keep their traps shut if he were unfortunate enough to be suffering from a serious disease and needed to have certain drugs? I would hope that this sort of thing would not reach the public arena, but it is a risk which I do not believe that the honourable senator or anyone else could afford to take.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like anyone else in this chamber, would certainly expect the best from my doctor if I needed life saving drugs. I do not believe it should be left up to any paper shuffler in my own State or any file ferret in Canberra to say what we should have. As far as I am concerned, when the chips are down, no-one in this place would accept anything but the best. I do not believe that anyone else in Australia should accept second best either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion for disallowance that the Opposition has moved because we are sick of seeing patients being ripped off and doctors and pharmacists harassed in order to achieve cost cutting in a fundamentally dishonest Medicare scheme. We have heard very few speakers from the Government side because they know the problems that they have with this regulation. Yesterday, Senator Cook made probably one of the most idiotic contributions-that would be a polite way of putting it-that a Minister could ever make. He did not make any sense at all and he did not state the facts as they are.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning we heard from Senator Crowley. It is difficult enough to listen to Senator Crowley at the best of times, but this morning one had to stretch one's imagination to understand anything that she said. Senator Crowley always talks on these issues because, supposedly as a doctor, she thinks she has a special qualification to speak on health matters. Quite frankly, I would have to say that, if I had tinea, I would be disinclined to go to Senator Crowley as a doctor. There is a very widely known story around in Parliament House about Senator Crowley's expertise as a doctor. Not so long ago all the doctors and nurses in this place got together to have a resuscitation course. The nurse who was conducting the course said that if someone collapsed it was wise not to check any extremity pulses but to check the person's carotid pulse, to which Senator Crowley-Senator Dr Crowley-responded, `Where is that?'. I am not a doctor, but I happen to know where the carotid artery is. But she said, `Where is that?'. Now honourable senators know why I treat what she says with disdain and why, if I had the misfortune to have something like tinea or whatever, I would prefer to put up with that condition rather than seek Senator Crowley's opinion.

The great problem is that with only three Government speakers participating in the debate we have not been able to ascertain why the Government wants to persist with the regulation even though the Government Caucus has expressed concern. An article in yesterday's Australian stated:
Federal Cabinet is facing strong opposition from members of its own back bench over contentious changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) announced in the May economic statement.
Sections of Caucus are concerned over the apparent public backlash against the Government's decision to add 53 expensive drugs to the `authority only' list.
Caucus has called for an explanation of the rationale behind the changes . . .
It went on to say that the Minister, Mr Staples:
. . . has been asked to provide the answers at a meeting with the Caucus Health and Community Services Committee on Thursday.
Of course, today is Thursday. That might explain why only three Government senators have been prepared to talk on this matter. They do not know the answer to the problem either.

We know from the patients, the doctors, the pharmacists and so on to whom we have spoken the enormous difficulties that this decision will create. Under this regulation a total of 53 drugs will be obtainable under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme only if a doctor specifically receives approval from the Department of Community Services and Health to prescribe them for patients.

My colleague Senator Calvert just explained in great detail what the great fear is-and, justifiably, what the great fear is-with this Government meddling in such a bureaucratic tangle. We have had repeated examples of how the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett-and might I remind the Senate that he is Dr non-medical Blewett; unlike you, Mr Acting Deputy President, he has no medical qualifications--

TALK.START.PARA: —So?

—I just make the point that Dr Blewett has no qualifications in a medical sense. As Senator Calvert pointed out a moment ago, it is important that Australians should be aware that, because of this regulation, there will be the further risk of bureaucrats knowing their private business. I do not believe that it is any business of a bureaucrat to know what drugs I or anybody else is taking. Therefore I think we should be very cautious in extending any of this. Of course, the great irony of this matter is that it was not so long ago-and time goes fast-in November 1985 Dr non-medical Blewett made an announcement entitled `Changes to pharmaceutical benefits scheme'. I will quote directly from his press release in November 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: Chronically ill patients will be major beneficiaries of Federal Government moves to free up the availability of prescription drugs supplied under the Pharmaceutical Benefits scheme.
The press release went on to say:
The changes will give more freedom to doctors to prescribe as they see fit.
Dr Blewett said this was a much-needed change which would modify the complexity of the approval system and also reduce delays in prescribing which could sometimes adversely affect patients.

That is what he said in 1985. But by 1988 he has done a double backflip, turned a few cartwheels and is now saying, `No way, we are going to put all of these drugs into a more bureaucratic system and tie them up again'. That statement quite clearly shows what the problem was a few years ago. The problem has remained unchanged until now. Following that announcement in December 1985 the Australian Medical Association and doctors generally were written to by the Commonwealth Department of Health. The letter they received stated:
For sometime the Government has been looking at ways of reducing the amount of regulation which currently applies to a number of schemes and arrangements it administers.

In keeping with these moves to deregulation, the Minister recently announced, with effect from 1 December 1985, a number of changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme relating to prescribing and dispensing restrictions. The changes relate to a reduction in the number of Authority Prescription drugs, an increase in available repeats for some drugs and in some cases the removal of prescribing restrictions.

That letter was written not quite three short years ago and yet today we have a complete and utter reversal. In those days the Government saw fit not to have a bureaucratic nonsense tangled up in the prescription of drugs but today all that is changed.

In practical terms the regulation that we have before us at the moment can mean delays of up to a fortnight in obtaining an authority, aside from the fact that it places the bureaucracy in judgment over the medical decisions and health care providers. Of course, it is acknowledged by the medical profession and by patients that if they happen to have the misfortune of living in the country they face possible longer delays than those people living in the city. Patients are faced with the option of obtaining these drugs at prohibitive market prices. The amount of unproductive paper work for doctors and pharmacists will increase enormously, adding to the costs.

Yesterday we heard Senator Cook and this morning Senator Crowley-who flapped her gums on this particular issue; that is the only way one could describe it because I do not think she was particularly serious-say that it would take a doctor only a couple of minutes. Honourable senators should multiply a couple of minutes by X number of patients per day, per week, per month and per year and see how much time it takes to start ringing up for an urgent authority. I thought doctors were trained to treat patients, not to deal with all the bureaucrats, not to be confronted with all this bureaucratic nonsense that has now been placed before them.

This Government has been telling us ad infinitum for the last five years that we have a free health care system accessible to all. What rot! Nothing could be further from the truth. We do not have a free health care system accessible to all. The Royal Perth Hospital in Western Australia is now going through an awful crisis of people waiting up to 14 hours to get treatment. This Government thinks that that is acceptable. The Royal Perth Hospital does not, nor do the recipients of the treatment. I think that it is quite a disgrace that the Government still continues to have a system masquerading as free to all. When patients are looking at obtaining some of these drugs at prohibitive market prices it is small wonder that they are concerned when they are told exactly how much they are and what they would have to pay for them in a time delay situation.

I object most strongly to the dishonesty of this Government that talks about fairness and social justice. It is trying to portray social justice, whatever social justice really means. I am not quite sure what it means, to be honest, because the way in which the Government put forward the referendum proposals was anything but social justice. But the Government is quite happy to spend $46m on a referendum that was soundly defeated by a very sane and sensible public. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thought we were going to be sane and sensible in another way. I object most strongly to the dishonesty of this Government while changing the character of the authority required listing from proper means of monitoring new and possibly addictive drugs to a rationing system. Once again I firmly believe that the medical profession is far better equipped than a bureaucrat to know what drugs a patient should have. It is the old story of Medicare promising the electorate a comprehensive health scheme and as it becomes more expensive it creates barriers to ration services. That is what we are seeing today. Services are constantly being rationed at whatever level of health care one cares to look at. These can take the form of hospital queues or, in this new method of discouraging the use of expensive drugs, by creating artificial bureaucratic delays and expensive paper work.

I make it very clear that we are not talking about exotic treatments in this debate, something that by any stretch of the imagination could be described as medical luxuries. There is an active discouragement of the prescription of drugs of proven effectiveness in the treatment of very serious complaints. Ninety per cent of the costs to the Government of the 53 drugs is represented by seven drugs. I defy the Government to argue that these seven drugs are unnecessary. We have drugs for inhibitors of high blood pressure and for reducing levels of cholesterol. I may just stop there on that point to say that the Government runs programs encouraging people to reduce their cholesterol. Now what does it do? It spends more taxpayers' money trying to prevent the reduction of high cholesterol by making it more difficult to get the drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! You don't really believe that nonsense.

—The Government is making it more difficult to get the drugs. Senator Coates knows it full well and he should not deny it. Then, of course, we have other drugs prescribed for uneven heartbeat. In a society where 34 per cent of deaths are due to heart disease and where in 1984 it was estimated that heart disease cost Australia $600m in hospital and medical services and between $900m and $1,400m in lost production, what responsible government would ever think of discouraging the prescription of those drugs most effective in fighting it? This Government has decided that it will make it more difficult for people to get those drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: The seventh drug in question is used in the treatment of 100,000 epileptics in Australia. This is not just a drop in the ocean-it is 100,000 people. What regard does this Government have for those suffering from this distressing illness? It is inevitable that such drugs will be more expensive when drug companies need to recoup research and development expenditure during patient life and when the decline in the value of the dollar has increased the cost of imports. That is no reason for pressuring doctors to prescribe cheaper alternatives. That is what the Government is doing. It is suggesting that the doctors think twice. They are the Minister's words, not mine. He says that they should think twice before prescribing an expensive but more effective drug and give a patient a cheaper drug. The fact that it is less effective matters not to this Government-just that it is cheaper, because it has problems balancing its books in health and many other areas. I do not think that there is any reason for any government to put pressure on doctors and patients in such a way. Alternative blood pressure drugs can produce side effects such as male impotence. Does this Government care? No. It is just not reasonable for a government, supposedly concerned with improving health care, to encourage the prescription of less effective drugs in greater quantities simply because they are cheaper.

While arthritis may seldom be life threatening, it is most certainly very debilitating. Anyone who knows someone with arthritis or has arthritis himself knows just how debilitating it can be. It diminishes the quality of life for thousands of Australians, particularly the elderly whose generally lower incomes make it imperative for them to obtain necessary medication at a subsidised rate. Ten out of the 53 drugs on this infamous list are used in the treatment of rheumatoid disease. I stress that there are no effective alternatives. But what does this Government do? It makes it more difficult for those people to get relief. The Government is ignoring medical opinion and it will condemn arthritic sufferers in Australia to inferior and ineffective treatment. What an insult to medical practitioners to assume that they would not prescribe the drug most effective in treating the condition of their individual patients and to seize on this artificial means of harassing them. Any estimated cost saving to be achieved in this way at the expense of the health of thousands of Australians has to be offset against the cost of administering three million prescriptions annually.

There is also the wider cost that may result when sufferers from cancer or heart disease, denied proper medication, end up in hospital for longer stays. Surely we should be looking at preventative medicine. That is the way that doctors can best prescribe what drugs are the most suitable for their patients to prevent any hospitalisation-not to exacerbate their condition. It is not good enough for the Government to allege that the placing of the 53 drugs on the authority list will not deny them to those patients who need them. Prescriptions would not be subject to this bureaucratic mechanism if it were not the Government's intention to discourage doctors from prescribing those drugs with proven effectiveness. The Opposition does not object to the placing of drugs on authority lists if their effectiveness is in doubt or if there is any other bona fide medical reason. If this motion for disallowance is passed there may be a case for the Government presenting a revised list of drugs that fall into this category and that are not the most effective form of treatment for common and serious complaints.

The problem is that this decision has been based solely on cost. There is not one of us who would not think that it is desirable to reduce costs of government whenever and wherever it is possible to do so. But what we are talking about today are drugs that account for only 5 per cent of the total health bill. We are talking about a decision that this Government took without any consultation or discussion with the medical or pharmaceutical professions. That was highly undesirable. They are the people who know best-not bureaucrats. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Peter Staples, drew attention in his statement to what he said was the alarming increase in the prescribing of the 53 drugs in question over a six-month period to November 1987. I would not call an increase from one per cent to 1.43 per cent an alarming increase, but he obviously would. According to him, an increase of 0.43 of a percentage point is alarming. As I said before, the decision will make the Government's objective of trying to get people to have lower cholesterol levels very difficult. The Better Health Commission and the Health Targets and Implementation Committee have identified elevated cholesterol levels as a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease in Australia. That is no secret to anybody. Yet this Government is trying to make the accessibility of proven drugs more and more difficult. I cannot help keeping on coming back to the fact that I am also very concerned about bureaucratic intrusion into the professional relationship between doctor and patient. Patients expect, and deserve, the best possible treatment available to them. They do not expect their doctor to have to seek approval to give them such treatment. This Government is suggesting exactly that.

My colleagues have already mentioned that the Western Australian Labor Government has come out very strongly against the Federal Government's decision. I suppose a real cynic could say that the only reason it has done so is that it recognises how unpopular the decision is. Of course, it is facing a State election within the next few months and, therefore, it is a popular hobbyhorse to kick. However, I would not like to be that cynical. I would like to say that the Labor Government in Western Australia has probably seen the error of the ways of this Federal Government; so much so that it has put advertisements in the newspaper entitled `Help us get the drugs you need'.
