The Western Australian Government's advertisement stated:

The Commonwealth Government has decided that 53 prescription drugs will require special authority from the Commonwealth Department of Health before they may be prescribed under pharmaceutical benefits regulations.

The Western Australian Government is fighting for an urgent review of the drugs on this list. Some of these drugs are crucial to the treatment of diseases such as cancer, heart disease and epilepsy-and there are no satisfactory alternatives.
I am convinced-
that is, the Western Australian Minister for Health, Mr Keith Wilson, is convinced-
that patients are suffering as a result of these changes.

I remind Senator Coates, who is to speak soon, that that came from a Labor Minister in Western Australia. The honourable senator's silence on this occasion is deafening. Is it not funny that when it is one of Labor's own people who comes out with the collywobbles there is absolutely deafening silence? A newspaper article entitled `Phone-in over drug changes' stated:
A special ``pharmacy protest'' hotline is being launched by the State Government to pressure its Federal counterpart to review controversial changes to pharmaceutical benefits.
The move-which will be officially announced today by the Minister for Health, Mr Wilson-
a Labor Minister-
is aimed at convincing the Federal Government that it should back down on its stance.
I quote his words:
``I hope he will agree-
he is talking about the Federal Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples-
to exclude a number of drugs which are crucial in the treatment of cancer, epilepsy and high blood pressure,''. . .

That came from the Western Australian Labor Government. Yet we have people-few as they might be-coming in here saying, `Do not worry about it; it is all right'. But what the Government has also lost sight of is the fact that the authority only list was first created for medical reasons to monitor addictive or new drugs which might have had deleterious long term effects. That has all changed because what we see today is a list of drugs that are crucial for the treatment of chronically ill patients-not just addictive drugs. We are quite happy, and in fact we consent totally, with restricting addictive drugs, but on this occasion the Government is misusing the authority only list to save money when the efficacy of the drugs has already been approved by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. This is in direct contrast to the Hawke Government's claim that it provides Australians with a fair, free and universal health system. It could not be further from the truth. Hospital waiting lists and now the authority only action are deliberate rationing mechanisms which generally impact most heavily upon the poor and those least able to work the system.

I remind the Senate that the drugs on this list are not exotic drugs, they are simply modern developments which dramatically improve the lifestyles of many sick people. I do not think that this Government has any right to impinge on a more pleasant lifestyle for those who are very ill. Those suffering from epilepsy and cancer do not need to have their condition further aggravated by bureaucratic intervention of the authority only prevention--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or any concern at all about their ability to get drugs.

—That is quite right, Senator Walters, they should not have any concern at all. They are confronted with a problem, a medical condition that gives them enough concern already without governments quite willingly giving them greater concern. As this list stands, however, we cannot regard it as anything other than an attempt to ration medical services to the detriment of thousands of Australians and their health providers. I think that this is a very serious position that we have reached on this subject now. I really do urge honourable senators to support this motion of disallowance. I hope that the Australian Democrats have a further change of mind, as they are capable of doing on any subject over a short period, and that they swing back again to the position where they started a few minutes ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion of disallowance moved by my colleague Senator Puplick. The motion of disallowance, as we all know, relates to 53 drugs that in the May mini-Budget were placed on the restricted list, meaning that the drugs would still be available, as Senator Crowley pointed out earlier in the debate, but that doctors would have to go through extra steps before those drugs could be prescribed for their patients. There is no question that the decision made in May was a rush decision. Much has been made by the few speakers on the other side of the chamber of the fact that this was a recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. In making that comment and trying to blame, if you like, or shelve the responsibility off on to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, they seem to have ignored the comments of the Chairman of that Committee, Dr Wal Grigor. On 7 September he said that the Committee had, in effect, been forced to make hasty decisions when the Government asked it to select the expensive drugs. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We met in Canberra on the Monday before the May Statement, and we didn't get any warning before the meeting. It was the committee's view those decisions were reached in some haste and they would all need to be looked at in the future.

So much for the sensible decision made by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. When honourable senators read what the Chairman of the Committee had to say they can see that members of the Committee were told by the Government what to do. They were not given advance warning of what was going to be requested of them and they therefore had no opportunity to consult with medical practitioners and specialists in the fields affected by these drugs.

I will just give a brief outline of some of the drugs involved. They are predominantly cancer treatments, treatments for epilepsy and for rheumatism. There are 53 drugs which are all, basically, very expensive and new drugs. Since that decision in May we have seen a hot line established and some modification to the Government's initial proposal. That is proof positive that, firstly, concern has been raised in the community-in other words, the Government has not implemented its program sensibly so that people understood what was being done-about this inept and speedy action with respect to pharmaceutical benefits. Secondly, the modifications indicate that there were original errors. If no errors have been made, modifications are not required. When a scheme is modified it is admitted that there were errors in it in the very beginning.

Since then we have also had some pretty facile comments from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is the Minister responsible. One comment that was reported was that some people might benefit more by changing their lifestyle and their diet rather than use these drugs. It is an insult to members of the medical profession to suggest that they would be prescribing very expensive drugs for people whose illnesses could be cured or whose health could be improved by simply changing their lifestyle and their diet. That is an outrageous accusation to be making and simply shows the lack of understanding by the Minister of the serious nature of the illnesses involved. He obviously has not got a clue.

What we have been told by a few speakers on behalf of the Australian Labor Party is that all the Government is trying to do is to encourage better prescribing habits. They are saying that because these extra forms will have to be filled out it will cause doctors to think twice about whether this is the best drug and whether a cheaper alternative would be just as good, if not more appropriate. That is the argument. But the Australian Medical Association tells us that once the forms are filled in-they go off to who in heaven knows how many bureaucrats who will be looking at them and putting a tick and a stamp and putting them in the in basket or the out basket-the only ground the bureaucrats will use for authorities for prescriptions being rejected is that there is some technical defect in completing the Government's forms. In other words, if the doctor completes the form properly, the drugs will be able to be prescribed in any event. So there will not be, necessarily, that much of a saving if that is the case.

An additional point that needs to be made is that one does hope, with the pressure that is on general practitioners, that the extra bureaucratic barrier put between them and these expensive drugs going to their patients is not an incentive for quite the reverse of what the Government says it intends, which is better prescribing habits. One would very much hope that this extra bureaucratic barrier does not encourage some doctors to make inappropriate decisions to give a cheaper alternative that, in fact, is not better. There has been no comment by the Government on how it believes that will not happen.

Senator Crowley this morning made much of the fact that she believes the Government has done the right thing. I was somewhat surprised to hear that because I have in front of me a clipping from the Australian headed `Caucus concern on health'. It is from yesterday's Australian, on page 18. One paragraph reads:
Caucus has called for an explanation of the rationale behind the changes and for clarifications of `misinformation' surrounding the issue from the minister responsible, Mr Staples.
In other words, the Government's own members do not understand what it is all about. We have got so few of them speaking in this debate because they do not understand what it is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley probably doesn't even go to Caucus.

—Senator Crowley may not even roll up to Caucus and probably does not know that Caucus is concerned about it. We have got so few members on the other side speaking because a lot of the senators on the other side do not approve of it either. This was something that was shoved through and Government senators have all got to wear it. I might add that, unlike the Liberal Party of Australia, Government senators are unable to disagree with their Party. They have to sit there like monkeys locked into a cage about whatever their Cabinet decides.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look sensibly at the suggestion by Senator Crowley that this will be an effective cost cutting measure. She said, `Look, when the Opposition wants to cut costs it is a rational thing, but when we want to do it you say that it is an outrage'. We do not always say that it is an outrage, but we do say that this action by the Government is an outrage. The reason we say it is an outrage is that the placement of these 53 drugs on the restricted pharmaceutical benefits list has been done for no other reason than cutting costs. It has not been done to improve health care and it has not been done sensibly. If it had been done sensibly, then we would find when we looked at the drugs that are on the restricted list that there are cheaper and better alternatives. Then we could say that this bureaucratic barrier that has been put up would encourage doctors to look at cheaper alternatives. But when we look at a good number of the drugs we find that there are not cheaper alternatives, let alone better alternatives. There is simply the one and only suitable drug for that particular condition. So there has been no rationale behind this decision other than, as I understand it, any drug costing over $30 a treatment.

If we speak to oncologists, cancer specialists, they will tell us that virtually all of the hormone and cytotoxic treatments for cancer are in the 21 cancer drugs now on the list, and all of them bar one can be used for breast cancer. I am very surprised that the Government, with its concern for women's health, which I acknowledge it has, and its very sensible program to improve breast and cervical cancer screening, seems to have the view that doctors who are treating women for breast cancer do so in such an off-hand fashion that the Government needs to put one extra form in front of them in order to encourage them to make the appropriate prescription. It is a damning indictment of the capacity of the medical profession to suggest that because the doctors have to fill in one extra form the treatment they prescribe for cancer will in some way be different. The cancer specialists say that there was no consultation at all with them about which drugs they could say there were cheaper alternatives for, that they were simply left out and that this was purely a bureaucratic decision.

As I have already indicated, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is not to blame. It was simply handed the list and a Department of Finance directive about what needed to be done. The cancer specialists very much believe that this is simply an increase in bureaucratic paper which will cause inevitable delays and will in the end only inconvenience the patient. I am told that, with virtually no exception with respect to the cancer drugs, there are no suitable alternatives. In many cases it is not feasible or appropriate to contemplate a cheaper alternative. I am sorry that Senator Crowley, in her speech this morning, did not take the opportunity to list what the cheaper alternatives would be to some of the drugs that are on the list, if she believes that that is the net result of putting these drugs on the list.

I am again informed that because the drugs related to hypertension and cardiovascular fields are narrow in nature, in the sense that they are for particular symptoms or illness levels, it is extraordinarily difficult to prescribe them inappropriately. If that is the case-one can only sensibly rely on specialists in that field, which the Government did not-what saving will we achieve by making the doctors fill in another form if there is a very narrow band of suitable drugs in any event? I am also informed that the long term costs have not yet been looked at. The Government would like to save $30 here and there by some other sort of drug being prescribed or, as the Minister suggests, someone changing his diet or lifestyle, but in fact there can be very long term savings in costs and social areas because these drugs could prevent complications early on; in other words, they could prevent a heart attack which quite obviously would result in a cost and social saving.

Again the doctors involved, those specialising in these areas, are concerned that this is simply a bureaucratic delay. They go on and say that some of the older drugs for hypertension, the cheaper alternatives that the Government seems to want doctors to use, have very serious side affects. So I have difficulty in agreeing with Senator Crowley and some of the Government speakers in that area because what we have again been told, in relation to a specific area, is that there probably are not cheaper alternatives with respect to these specific drugs; that in fact in the long term the use of these drugs may be cheaper for the community because problems will be fixed earlier; that again it is simply a bureaucratic nightmare; and that the cheaper alternatives that are available are not appropriate.

I am told that some time last year-you may know when this was, Mr Acting Deputy President, because of your involvement in health care-the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee did moot the question of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors being restricted. There was such a fuss by the profession involved, submissions were put forward by experts, and the decision was changed on therapeutic grounds. In other words, the decision to put ACE inhibitors on the restricted list was not a decision that would improve the health care of Australians and therefore the decision was changed last year under this Government. But now we see a complete change of heart by the Government, to chuck out the advice from specialists in this area, to throw away the therapeutic concerns we might have for whether or not these drugs should be restricted and simply to go on a cost alone decision.

I want to turn to a few remarks that Senator Crowley made, because in my view her contribution this morning was somewhat outrageous. Apart from referring to a number of senators on this side as being straight-out liars she made a few other remarks that I think need to be challenged. As I have indicated, Senator Crowley said that this move to place the 53 drugs on the restricted list will both cut costs and improve health care. By the few examples that I have raised I have tried to show that that is not in fact the case. As Labor members have agreed, doctors will still be able to get these drugs, so if they are the most appropriate and they are still prescribed, there will not be any cost saving. But if they are not the most appropriate drugs, the doctors will go to the cheaper alternatives. What I have tried to show, by referring to advice that I have had from specialists, is that in most cases there are either no cheaper alternatives or no suitable cheaper alternatives.

It seems that the whole goal of this proposal is for Australians to use less of the more expensive, modern, better and more effective drugs. That is what the Government is on about in this case. Senator Crowley admitted that if there were difficulties the Government would look at them. I think that bears some consideration, because what she is in fact saying is that the Government has thought this proposal through very carefully, that it is a very sensible proposal to put these 53 drugs on the list, but in the next breath-almost without taking a breath-she says that if the Government has done the wrong thing it will look at it. It seems the Government has done the wrong thing and Senator Crowley would be well advised to consult with her Caucus colleagues, who obviously are concerned about this measure. She would also be well advised to consult with not only members of the Australian Medical Association but specialists in the particular fields to see what they have to say about it.

An additional point that Senator Crowley made, again within the space of one breath, was that this move would not affect prescribing habits because the drugs would still be available, but in the next breath she said it really would because doctors would change their prescribing habits as they would not want to fill in the extra form. That is in effect what she said. I have made that point before. It is a somewhat damning indictment of the medical profession by this Government to suggest that the simple filling in of an extra form will occasion doctors to prescribe other or inappropriate drugs.

I have already mentioned that Senator Crowley, while saying that doctors would shift to cheaper and, she thinks, more suitable alternatives, did not take the opportunity to give a few examples of what are cheaper and more suitable alternatives. She referred to the potency of drugs that are involved, the very high powered anti-cancer drugs, and she pointed out how they were prescribed with great care. In the same breath she said that despite the care that is involved in the prescribing of these drugs, they should be shifted onto the restricted list. She said that putting them on the list makes doctors more thoughtful about prescribing. The same sort of insult keeps coming up. It came up not only in Senator Crowley's speech but also in the speeches of many other Government senators involved in this debate. As I say, it is somewhat of an attack on the thoughtfulness that doctors put into their prescribing now and implies that cheaper alternatives exist.

I am sorry that senators do not get the opportunity to speak twice in the one debate, because I want to give an invitation to Senator Crowley. I will extend it to her through Senator Coates. I refer to the drugs tamoxifen and medroxyprogesterone, other wise known as provera. I notice Mr Acting Deputy President shaking his head. I suspect that I have pronounced those names wrongly. Those two drugs are for the treatment of breast cancer and uterine cancer in women. Perhaps Senator Coates will take the opportunity to tell us what the cheaper alternatives are. If he is so well-informed in this area, so competent as to be the last speaker in this debate on behalf of the Government, let him take the opportunity to tell the chamber what the cheaper alternatives are for the treatment of cancers that affect women. If he can manage that, why does he not tell us what the cheaper alternatives are in every other area? Speakers from the Government side have been noticeably silent in this debate on what the cheaper alternatives are. The reason they have been noticeably silent on the cheaper alternatives is that primarily there are not any. Government speakers have presented a most ill-informed debate which only confirms the view that we are debating a rushed decision that they are now forced to back.

In conclusion, although I do not wish to stray from the question of disallowing this ill-informed and hastily made decision to put 53 drugs on the restricted list, I want to raise the question of whether this Government believes it needs to have a rational pharmaceutical drugs policy. Clearly, it does not have one. It seems simply to believe that the only concern it needs to have with pharmaceuticals is that of their cost, and that it can tamper with that by putting drugs on the restricted list, altering the number of prescriptions that are allowed or changing the number of prescriptions one has to have filled before one is entitled to free drugs. They are all cost related measures. I do not hear from the Government of any therapeutic based health care decisions with respect to pharmaceuticals.

I want to cite a number of examples that could have stood, if the Government had let them, as warning posts to the Government that something needs to be done in this area. In November 1987, a survey on tranquilliser usage found that 10 million prescriptions are dispensed, with the staggering figure of one in six women in Australia being on prescription drugs. In March 1988 the parents of a 23-year-old Sydney man who died of a `legal overdose' demanded a strengthening of legal measures to monitor legal drug use. In May this year diuretic drugs, which promote weight loss, were shown to be regularly abused by women and athletes, according to the Australian Prescriber. Again in May this year, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia accused the Government of short-term bandaid measures that represented false economies over the pharmaceutical benefits scheme pricing and regulatory policies.

In June this year the National Health and Medical Research Council released a very disturbing report on the extent of mood altering drugs being used amongst children. In September this year, the Chairman of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee confirmed what we already knew-namely, that the decision we are debating today was made hastily with no prior consultation with specialists. Also in September this year, we found from the Australian Consumers Association that a disproportionate number of prescription drugs is being used by the aged.

All of these matters should concern a government which is concerned about health care rather than costs. I would like to see the Government put forward a rational pharmaceutical drugs policy-directed not just to costs; in part, of course, it has to be, because the coffers are not endless; there is a limited supply of money. But money is not the only factor to be taken into account in terms of health care. Therapeutic decisions or factors should be taken into account and the Government should come up with a rational pharmaceutical drugs policy. I very much support the motion of disallowance moved by my colleague Senator Puplick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with an Opposition motion to disallow a regulation about pharmaceutical benefits, which has turned into a deliberate attempt by the Opposition to frustrate the Senate's legislative program. I would like to answer the accusation by--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is an unnecessary, unfair and unreasonable attack to suggest that we are attempting to frustrate the Senate. If the Government does not see that this is an important measure to be debated, I am sorry that it has missed the point of the debate.
—There is no point of order.

—As the Opposition Whip knew, of course, that was not a point of order. She may not have heard her colleagues making a big fuss about the fact that there were only three Government speakers in this debate. I would have thought that three speakers from each side would be enough to avoid repetition on this issue and to allow honourable senators to put their arguments adequately. But we have had something like nine Opposition speakers spinning out the debate over two days and, in the process, preventing us from getting on with the program. Virtually all those speakers from the other side have taken their full time. Instead of giving a relatively brief and effective speech, most of them have taken all or almost all of the time available to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I just make that point in answer to the repeated comments from the Opposition about the fact that there are only three Government speakers in this debate, suggesting that this means that we really do not oppose the motion. Of course we oppose the disallowance motion. It has been adequately dealt with by the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, and by Senator Crowley, and is now being dealt with by me. Since the debate started a further Opposition member has been added to the speakers list. Who is to say that, if we listed nine speakers, the Opposition would not say, `Oh well, we will have to have another nine to show that we really mean what we say more than you do.'? It is a ridiculous situation.

The issue is about the 53 drugs that have been added to the authority list for approval under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. We have had a whole lot of infuriating misrepresentation about this matter, and a whole lot of emotive phrases to the effect that this means divulging private medical information to unknown bureaucrats, that it involves harassing doctors and dying patients, and that the Government is meddling in people's private affairs. Of course bureaucrats are involved when we have a scheme of publicly funded health services, including pharmaceuticals. What does the Opposition really suggest-that we have an open slather scheme, that anything that a doctor prescribes is subsidised from the public purse?

If the Opposition wants to have no bureaucrats involved in these matters, it really wants no pharmaceutical benefits scheme at all. I acknowledge that parts of the medical profession take that attitude. They say, `We want no government involvement at all-totally free activity for practitioners. We will prescribe what we want and people can pay for it'. But we have a situation in which very expensive drugs are needed by some people and, as with all sorts of drugs-those that are on the authority list and those that are not-practitioners can get into the habit of too easily prescribing some of these drugs. Therefore, on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, 53 drugs have been added to the authority list. I emphasise that they have been added to the list, because this is not some totally new scheme. There has for many years been an authority list of drugs which require special approval before they can be prescribed. It is just that 53 more drugs out of the thousands that there are have been added. All that is now required is for the medical practitioner to make an extra notation that a particular drug is essential and special authority is requested.

The Senate has heard a lot of emotive nonsense from the Opposition about unproductive paperwork and waste of time and so forth, but very little time is involved. If there is no urgency about the matter, the practitioner can merely sign the authority request and state that there is no cheaper alternative available or that the efficacy of the particular drug is such that it is the only one suitable for the particular patient and mark it off. If there is urgency, there are two options. The practitioner can telephone the Department if unsure about what has to happen to get immediate approval by telephone or he or she can sign the prescription so that it can be dispensed immediately and follow it up with a request for approval by mail. It has been suggested by the Opposition-the most outrageous suggestion being made by Senator Walters last night-that these options for dealing with this matter urgently are not available.

I hope that by reminding the Opposition of these provisions we have dealt with the accusations about the Government risking the lives of patients and so forth. I think it was Senator Calvert who said that the addition of these 53 drugs to the authority list will make it difficult for patients to receive life saving drugs and it introduces the danger of death and undue stress and concern. The only undue stress and concern has been caused by the political campaign by the Opposition and others who are trying to make patients think that they will miss out on the drugs that will improve their life expectancy.

The Australian Medical Association has also tried to sabotage the addition of these new drugs to the authority list. I am happy for the Association to indulge in a political campaign. It does it all the time. I have no great objection to doctors encouraging their patients to contact their members of parliament or take whatever other action they wish, but I do object to their doing it without their patients having full knowledge of the situation. I have had concerned patients contact me about the matter, saying that they have run out of the drug that they have been dependent on and the doctor has said it is going to take two weeks before they can get more supplies. There we have a situation where doctors are deliberately causing unnecessary worry to their patients and encouraging them to become involved in that sort of political campaign. Perhaps some doctors have done so in ignorance-I acknowledge that possibility-but there ought not to have been ignorance, for practitioners were fully informed. There should be no concern about drugs that are urgently needed being immediately available. The point of the matter is to ensure that there is full consideration by the practitioner of what is being prescribed, rather than just getting into the habit of always prescribing a particular drug, especially one that is so expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think there are cheaper alternatives?

—I suppose I had better answer Senator Vanstone now or she will continue to harass me throughout my comments. She made some nonsense challenge before for me to say what are the alternatives to specific drugs. I am not going to answer that question.
—You cannot.

—It is not my place to answer a medical question. It is a matter for the medical practitioners and for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. For some of those 53 drugs there may not be an alternative. In some cases there are alternatives. All that has to happen is for the practitioner concerned to certify that there is no appropriate alternative. I am not going to get into debates about particular drugs. It is not my place and it ought not to be Senator Vanstone's place to do so. It is a matter of making sure that there is consideration, that practitioners think twice about the drugs that they prescribe.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is mixed up, I suppose. It is trying to make a political point about this matter. In effect it is saying that there should not be any limitations on drugs at all. It wants no controls because they interfere with the precious doctor-patient relationship. The doctor-patient relationship is one thing; but public funding of the consequences of that relationship is another. It is important that where such high cost is involved and, as has been acknowledged by the Opposition, such potency and danger with some of these drugs, extra authority should be required to ensure that the doctor considers the matter properly before prescribing those drugs. The Opposition seems suddenly to have exempted this kind of public expenditure from its general campaign of saying that the Government spends too much on everything. It is continually bleating about reducing public expenditure. Here is a relatively minor but legitimate attempt to control the very expensive area of pharmaceutical benefits, and members of the Opposition use terms such as Senator Calvert did that this is a greedy grab for funds and it will result in second best health treatment and all sorts of things.

The arguments that have been raised are pathetic. Let us never hear again from the Opposition about health costs. This debate over two days has taken away any legitimacy it had in arguing that sort of point. The stress that has been caused to patients by misleading reports and misleading statements from the Opposition and from medical practitioners has upset me when I have heard about it. It is important to emphasise that patients have nothing to fear from this decision. They are not being denied necessary medication. The decision does not involve removing any drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme list. All these drugs are still on the list. I think Senator Vanstone acknowledged that, even if some of her colleagues did not. And there are the procedures I mentioned earlier to ensure that the drugs can be obtained in cases where they are urgently needed. That issue has been of concern, I acknowledge, to organisations such as those representing people suffering from epilepsy, who know that the drugs sometimes are needed urgently. But they can be obtained just as quickly as before by using the fast track method of obtaining approval.

It is important that there be incentive for doctors to consider costs when they are prescribing. I appreciate the problems they have. They are continually being bombarded with aggressive promotion by drug companies. It is important for them, busy as they are, to consider continually whether it is absolutely necessary for an expensive drug to be prescribed for all patients with a particular disease rather than thinking about whether it really is appropriate for a particular patient, whether an alternative, preferably cheaper drug would be just as satisfactory, or whether perhaps even non-drug therapy would be just as good. At the same time as having this authority mechanism, we have an educative program encouraging more appropriate prescribing activities by medical practitioners. There is no requirement for doctors to try cheaper drugs first. Again, it has been suggested that it will be said `No, such and such a drug is not available, you must try the cheaper alternative first'. There is no such requirement. There is only a requirement for the practitioner to consider whether the cheaper alternative might be just as good. It is a prompt mechanism to require this extra certification. Patients will not miss out on anything that is necessary for them. The drugs have not been removed from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) list. All that is required is an additional authority.

Turning to the issue of faceless bureaucrats getting involved in doctor-patient relationships and telling doctors what to do, there is no role for officers in telling doctors what to do. Their role is in checking that the authority is properly completed and that the prescribing restrictions have been complied with. They have no role in actually determining the appropriateness of the prescribing doctor's judgment in choosing drugs for their patients. The doctor simply needs to state that the alternatives are inappropriate or that there are no alternatives and the authority will be approved. There is no question of bureaucrats-the word spat out by the Opposition in a most offensive way-trying to tell medical practitioners what they should do with patients.

Of course, this reference to bureaucrats has led the Opposition on to its track about privacy. There is no change in the privacy situation. If honourable senators opposite stopped and thought for a moment they would know that, even with an ordinary PBS prescription, the name of the patient and the drug is part of the information. This makes sure that the payment subsidising these drugs out of the public purse is correct. There is no additional question at all about privacy. In any case, there has to be a compromise in these matters. If we are to have a system of public subsidy of drugs and prescriptions and so on, it is important to make sure that that information is secret. To suggest, as one of the Opposition speakers did, that because this information is in the authority forms it is in the public domain is just ridiculous and an insult to those who administer the system.

The other suggestion that was made by the Opposition is that somehow or other this arrangement is totally set in concrete forever and a day. It is open to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to change its advice to the Minister for Community Services and Health whenever it likes. It does that all the time. There are drugs coming on and off the PBS list all the time. The Committee, both on its own initiative and on advice received from practitioners involved, is able to reassess things. No doubt, because of the representations made to the Minister by organisations and individual practitioners and patients, there will be a reassessment of some of these things, especially epilim and some of the cancer drugs, and the Committee will consider these representations in the normal way and make recommendations accordingly. I imagine that over time, and depending on developments of drugs and new information, drugs will go on and off the authority list all the time. That should not be a surprise to any of us. It ought to be the way the system works for continual review of these restrictions.

I can only suggest that the Opposition is not really serious about this motion for disallowance. It has been introduced for purely political reasons to stir up patients, who are being misled about the circumstances of having drugs available. I urge the rejection of the motion for disallowance so that we can get on with some other business and get some legislation passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am at the tail end of the debate, I presume that I am the additional Opposition speaker Senator Coates has just deplored. Not only did he deplore the number of Opposition speakers on this motion for disallowance but he also deplored the content of their speeches. This indicates that he has missed the whole point of the depth of concern we have over the Government's action in putting these drugs, many of them most important ones, back on the restricted list. As a sheer matter of logistics it is estimated that this action by the Government will necessitate the processing of an extra three million applications in a year. That might be very good news for the bureaucrats but it is very bad news for everybody else, particularly as the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) said in his speech that they will all be approved. Why have the applications if they will all be approved? I can tell honourable senators why the Minister made that statement. He is aware of the depth of concern people have about restricting the prescribing of these drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: This decision was announced in the May economic statement. Among other things, this particular action was really a flying flip at the moon, and instead of winding up in the Sea of Tranquillity the Government has wound up in a sea of illogicality and inconsistency. I think that the Government will reap the whirlwind for what it has done. Senator Coates must be aware of the depth of concern within his own Party. Those people have realised how illogical and inconsistent this decision is.

Community concern is mounting more and more. The honourable senator accused the Australian Medical Association (AMA) of sabotage of the Government's action. I do not know how he can accuse the AMA of that, because it was not consulted at any stage. A lot of the drugs involved relate to the specialities within the AMA, and plenty of advice would have been available to the Government had it sought that information. Indeed, over a long time the AMA has always said that it is perfectly willing to consult with the Government on matters such as this. I might say that, in my view, it is a fault of the AMA to keep going back to the Government which has put it in the mess that it is already in. It is like going back and back to the same doctor who is making you sick. The AMA is still willing to go back to the Government and negotiate, not only in this area but also for a whole restructuring of the pharmaceutical benefits system in Australia today.

Concerning the illogicality of the whole situation, the Government has laid stress on the priority that it gives to preventive measures. It has a Better Health Commission going, it has very expensive procedures in process to prevent illness and injury in the work force, and it has the National Health and Medical Research Council in operation. The drugs that have been restricted are largely for preventive measures and they could save the Government a lot of money. The big cost with many of the illnesses that are treated by these drugs relates to costly complications and effects. For example, treatment of cardiovascular conditions, strokes and heart attacks, is very expensive. However, such conditions can be prevented or delayed with the treatment that is now available. Huge campaigns are now being undertaken in the community to promote healthier lifestyles and to urge people to adopt a healthier diet and to watch their blood pressure. However, here is the Government restricting access to the very preventive measures that would result in saving a lot of money in the long run.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that they should be given to every patient?

—I am not suggesting that at all. It was ridiculous for Government members to say in debate that doctors would prescribe these tablets willy-nilly and that there would be an explosion of prescriptions. That is entirely wrong. Almost every one of these drugs is specific for what it does. They are at the frontier of medicine; they are state of the art drugs. They have fewer side effects than previous medications, and they are safer.

SPEECH.PARA: In the matter of preventive medicine, these drugs are specific in what they do. Doctors are not likely to give cancer drugs to an epileptic. They are not likely to prescribe drugs willy-nilly in the treatment of the various diseases. Indeed, most of the illnesses relate to the specialised areas of the medical profession. Most of the patients involved would have seen a specialist, have obtained advice and have been put on a regime, and perhaps then sent back to their general practitioner. Now, the general practitioner has to do extra paperwork in order to get drugs for these patients.

As to the extra paperwork involved, ridicule was heaped on the profession-here were these doctors complaining that they were being asked to fill in just five to 10 extra words on a certificate. However, just the name and address of the doctor and the patient would amount to more than 10 words-and then there is the rest of the form to fill in, with the number of repeats, dosages, and so on. It is a longer job than just a few extra words. The important thing is that the doctor already has a lot of paperwork that is generated by the Government. In most surgeries the doctor's desk is cluttered with forms-red forms, green forms and blue forms-because, to a large extent, doctors have become `referologists'. They have to refer people for all sorts of tests or examinations, and there is a form for everything.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.30 to 2.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I note the Minister's reluctance in Question Time earlier this week to make any prediction about interest rates. But I draw his attention to today's Melbourne Herald report that a Reserve Bank of Australia spokesman has said that it is accurate to claim the Government is holding down interest rates until after the Victorian election. Will the Minister confirm that this is the case? Will he tell the Senate when the monetary policy brakes will be taken off?
—I have not seen that report. I do not know who it is from. I regard it as a totally unauthenticated sort of comment. I have no comment to make.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VICTORIAN AND SOUTH AUSTRALIAN ELECTRICITY GRIDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the project for the interconnection of the Victorian and South Australian electricity grids. What progress has there been to date on this vital scheme involving a power line from near Portland in Victoria to Mount Gambier in South Australia? What is the timetable for completion of this important project and what are the major benefits estimated to flow from it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1985 the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia announced an agreement to interconnect South Australia's electricity grid with the combined Victorian-New South Wales grid at a cost of $155m to be shared between South Australia, with a contribution of $102m, Victoria $46m and New South Wales $7m. The interconnection is now under construction and is planned for completion in, I think, 1990. The Commonwealth Government facilitated this project by supporting, in the Loan Council, additional borrowings by the South Australian and Victorian electricity authorities of up to a total of $8m over the proposed period of construction.

ANSWER.PARA: The interconnection, as implied in the honourable senator's question, was recommended by the Commonwealth initiated inquiry into electricity generation and the sharing of power resources in south-eastern Australia-the Zeidler report-in 1980. The project will provide total annual savings of at least $14m by allowing the exchange of electricity when generation in one State is cheaper than generation in another State. There would also be savings from the sharing of reserve generating plant capacity. Studies indicate that the capital savings to be achieved from the reserve generating plant capacity could be around $75m.

Any student of Australian resources or Australian constitutional law who has travelled, particularly by rail, between the States knows how difficult it has been to achieve cooperation between State governments in areas where there are overlapping or interconnecting services. They know how difficult it is to combine those services and work out a sane and sensible system. I think it is a tribute to the Labor governments of Victoria and South Australia that they have been able to put aside whatever constitutional obstacles have prevented governments in the past reaching this sort of agreement and, with the assistance of the Commonwealth, come to a conclusion like this which will be of great benefit to all consumers of electricity in both Victoria and South Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice whether he has seen the statement of the Deputy Prime Minister, Attorney-General Lionel Bowen, in the Weekend Australian of 10 September 1988 in which he is quoted as saying that for a referendum the Electoral Commission:

QUESTION.PARA: Can't get to the polls in under 15 weeks. If I had been able to get there in 8 weeks I might have had a chance.

With the implicit meaning being that the people can be fooled for eight weeks but not for 15, will the Minister now admit that the Australian people are good, sensible people who refused to be duped by the Government's motherhood questions and false rhetoric, or does he believe that the Australian people were stupid and swayed by arguments which the Chairman of the Constitutional Commission said `would disgrace a nine-year-old school child'?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read that article. In general, the Government accepts that, as is proper in a democracy, a question put to the people and answered by them concludes the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments made by Senator Alston in the adjournment debate on Tuesday night? Can the Minister inform the Senate of action taken by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in response to claims made against the Latrobe Valley Morwell Migrant Resource Centre? Is there any truth in Senator Alston's claims of mismanagement at that centre?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —This particular migrant resource centre commenced operations in November 1984. Within its catchment area there are over 16,000 overseas born residents, including about 9,000 from non-English speaking backgrounds. The area serviced by that migrant resource centre covers some 7,000 square kilometres.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of reports of internal dissension within the board of management of that migrant resource centre and its impact on ethnic communities in the area. My Department is already working in close contact with the board of management of the migrant resource centre in an endeavour to resolve these problems as soon as possible. Our priority is to ensure that the services of the centre are continued in an uninterrupted way.

Because of the inference drawn by some board members and others that the Migrant Resource Centre funds have been misappropriated, an officer from the Internal Audit Section of my Department visited the Migrant Resource Centre last week at the request of the Chairman of that centre, Mr Ferguson. The report of the officer concludes:

All expenses incurred by the centre were duly approved by board members. Although receipt of certain money was not recorded in the receipt book, they were all reflected in the bank statements. From the records examined, audit is satisfied that the funds were expended with proper approval being given by the board and that such expenditure was consistent with departmental guidelines. Whereas audit has identified some scope for improvement in the accounting procedures followed by the Migrant Resource Centre, these are not such as would expose the organisation to risk of undetectable financial losses.

The internal audit report is being made available to that migrant resource centre. Senator Alston's claims about the Department's auditor's findings relating to that centre including cutting back funds, banking in Canberra, indiscriminate payment of travelling expenses, failure to identify income, existence of an unidentified bank account and payments to cleaners under fictitious names are all unsubstantiated and untrue. In addition, contrary to Senator Alston's claim, the centre's books are audited each year by a qualified chartered accountant who is certainly not a member of the board of management. The Government is committed to the migrant resource centre program, under which voluntary community based organisations assist migrants to settle in Australia. Whilst essential controls and guidelines should be and are enforced, there must be some flexibility in dealing with elected representative management groups. In this case the board of management of the Latrobe Valley Migrant Resource Centre is elected by and from the Latrobe Valley ethnic community. Membership of the community group is open to members of the public and I understand that its annual general meeting is scheduled for early November.

In conclusion, I understand that Senator Alston's comments are made in the background of the Victorian State election. Nevertheless, I think it was incumbent on him to check his source of information and maybe a prior check with our Department would have allowed him to avoid making some outrageous allegations that have proved to be fictitious.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware that some Australians who meet their Medicare levy are suffering discrimination when their medical claims are refused because the Department arbitrarily decides their particular practitioner does not hold suitable views about how to treat his or her patients, and therefore Medicare benefits will not be provided? Does the Minister consider this to be a breach of contract with the patient who has paid his or her Medicare levy in good faith, then received medical care from the legally recognised medical practitioner of his or her choice? Is the Minister aware that these patients-I know of 12 in one practice in my electorate-many of whom are sick and therefore less able than usual to deal with stress, are being summonsed over the non-payment of medical bills? Does the Minister believe it is appropriate that these people now have to seek legal aid, challenge Medicare in the courts and bear the associated stresses and distresses in order to achieve a rightful Medicare claim? What immediate action does the Minister intend to take about this shameful situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has raised a number of allegations and I do not have sufficient detail from him to enable me to check and answer specifically the particular cases to which he referred. I make this offer to Senator McLean: if he makes the particulars of those cases available to me, I will investigate them and see that there is a reply in each of the circumstances. However, it is nonsense to suggest that Medicare refunds are decided on the basis of the views of the treating medical practitioner. Medicare benefits are paid for all medical services rendered by or on behalf of a medical practitioner in accordance with the Medicare benefits schedule. When a particular medical service rendered by a medical practitioner is not listed on the schedule, the mechanism exists for the practitioner to claim for payment of benefits to be determined by the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee. The Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee also makes recommendations about items which should appear on the schedule.

ANSWER.PARA: When a doctor bills a patient for medical services rendered, the patient needs a properly itemised account and receipt, or combined account-receipt, to enable a claim to be made for Medicare benefits. Information on that account needs to include a description of the professional services sufficient to identify the item that relates to that service. Many practitioners use the Medicare benefits item number: others prefer to write descriptions. Unfortunately, a small number of medical practitioners do neither, usually for reasons of ideology or of opposition to Medicare itself. It may be that this is what has happened in the cases to which Senator McLean referred in his question. However, as I have said, without specific information I am unable to be certain about that.

Senator McLean would appreciate that when the Government is involved in the expenditure of very significant amounts of public moneys under Medicare it is incumbent upon it to ensure that a description of the service performed is included on accounts to ensure that Medicare funds are spent properly. It is disappointing that some doctors refuse to comply with this requirement, as the people who are being hurt are the very patients that they, the doctors, are supposed to be caring for. If patients find themselves in that position they should ask their doctor to itemise the accounts properly. If the doctor refuses to do so they should go to a different doctor and have the matter attended to properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pose a supplementary question, Mr President. I acknowledge the detail of the answer. Will the Minister undertake, in investigating the matter further, to refer to the two previous questions without notice that I have asked on this matter; the numerous questions that I have previously asked on notice; and the Minister's response to those questions on notice? Will he also refer to the Hansard record of a debate which took place in the Appropriations context about 10 months ago? Will he acknowledge that some medical practitioners who prefer to pursue a line of medicine which is preventative rather than curative, and who are approached in good faith by Australians who choose to have that line of medicine applied to them, are now finding that their bills are not being honoured by Medicare and their patients have to pursue the matter under the law?

—I have already offered, if Senator McLean gives me the relevant material, to have the matter investigated fully. That offer stands. I invite Senator McLean to do that. I notice the references that he has. I might say, since I am representing Minister Blewett, who is by any measure the most outstanding Minister for Community Services and Health that this country has ever had--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-Oh, come on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four shadow Ministers have been moved off him. What has happened to Porter, Michael Baume, Wilson Tuckey and the other shadow Ministers for the portfolio of health and community services? Neal Blewett has put in a Hawthornlike performance as the Minister for Community Services and Health in this country. All the players that those opposite have had shadowing him have been moved off him into other and often lesser portfolios because they just cannot hack the pace. To answer Senator McLean's question, if the material is available, we will have it properly investigated and an answer will be given.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that the United States Government gave a unilateral assurance to Canada in 1969 and to New Zealand in 1976 that it would accept liability if an accident involving a United States nuclear weapon occurred in their territory? Has the Australian Government sought or received a similar assurance? If so, is the Government satisfied that this assurance is binding, given that the United States Congress has not legislated to accept the financial burden of such liability as it has in the case of nuclear reactor accidents on transiting warships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief, the answer to the first part of the question is yes and to the second part no; but I might expand on the second part of the question. In some circumstances, of course, United States allies accept stationing of nuclear weapons in their own territories. United States nuclear weapons are not stationed on Australian territories. This is forbidden by the Treaty of Rarotonga.

ANSWER.PARA: The unlikelihood of a nuclear weapon accident in an Australian port was a matter I covered in the Senate on 27 September. Australia does not therefore have the need for assurances from the United States similar to those given to allies on whose territories United States nuclear weapons could be stationed. Any claims for compensation resulting from a nuclear weapons accident would be dealt with through diplomatic channels in accordance with customary procedures for the settlement of claims under generally accepted principles of law and equity. In the case of the United States, settlement of claims would take place in accordance with Article 12 of the agreement between Australia and the United States concerning the status of forces in Australia. The Government is confident that the United States Government would promptly settle any proper claim for damage in the highly unlikely event of a nuclear weapon accident in an Australian port.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: If the Australian Government has not requested or received such an assurance, can the Minister explain why not, given that these two allies-New Zealand and Canada-have found it necessary to protect their citizens from the possible catastrophe associated with a nuclear weapon accident, and that the United States has found it possible to respond positively to their concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —For some reason I had anticipated that supplementary question and answered both questions as a whole. I just refer the honourable senator back to that answer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the large number of ships which either have had to be diverted to other ports or have had to leave behind export cargo because of disruptions to the Sydney waterfront caused by stoppages and pickets by members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, the Transport Workers Union of Australia and the crews of tugs? Has the Minister been informed of the amount of export cargo that has been affected and the repercussions of this for our export industries? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the time that it will take to clear this new backlog, remembering the disastrous delays earlier this year in the Sydney depots which seriously affected almost all small businesses which relied on imported goods for survival? Do the September disruptions to our waterfront mean that, yet again, Australia has turned out to be an unreliable supplier of much needed export goods? What is the Government intending to do to repair the damage done to Australia as an exporting nation and to our balance of payments crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that recent industrial action by the Transport Workers Union, not the Waterside Workers Federation as Senator Hamer says-I think that is indicative of his general state of knowledge of this industry, notwithstanding the rhetoric to which we are constantly subjected-has severely disrupted container movements on the Sydney waterfront, although the dispute does not relate directly to waterfront conditions. The dispute did take an unfortunate turn for the worse when pickets were imposed on the waterfront by owner-drivers, apparently without the authority of the Transport Workers Union. The dispute is a State matter involving truck drivers covered by a determination of the New South Wales Industrial Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: A couple of days ago a Full Bench of the Commission recommended that the pickets should be lifted so that negotiations could proceed on the owner-drivers' claims and, if necessary, could be expeditiously arbitrated. I understand that meetings were being held yesterday-I am not sure what the outcome was-in the light of that particular decision. The situation is that stevedoring employers, faced with a complete stalling of their cargo operations, have been granted stand-down provisions in major stevedoring awards. The implementation of stand-downs is not proceeding at this stage, as I understand it-there may be some supplementary information required to this answer and, if so, I will provide it later-so that the Industrial Commission proceedings and other actions aimed at resolving the present impasse can be pursued without this added complication. Some limited movement of cargo is happening on the waterfront, as I understand it, pending a full resumption of work by owner-drivers.

It is incumbent upon the parties to this dispute to make every endeavour to resolve their differences without causing further disruption to the economy, adding to the costs incurred by importers and exporters, as this sort of action does, and imposing the hardship of stand-down upon the waterfront work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to assertions made yesterday by the shadow Minister for finance, Dr Hewson, that the Treasurer is manipulating interest rates to hold them down, specifically the housing loan rate, until after the Victorian election. Has the Minister seen assertions that the opposite is in fact the case? Is the Government taking any actions which would give substance to either of these sets of assertions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Hewson was succinctly described by Senator Stone once as a mere meretricious player flitting across the stage. Even those people who believe that Senator Stone is almost always wrong in his economic judgments all acknowledge that he has a flair for the use of the language, and he certainly demonstrated it when he described Dr Hewson as a mere meretricious player flitting across the stage. Yesterday the meretricious player had his big day in the House of Representatives, or so he thought. He moved a motion about this and went through the allegations that we have become accustomed to hearing from the Opposition, that is, that the Government is manipulating interest rates, et cetera, and that this is all being done because of the Victorian election.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose it is appropriate that the mere meretricious player should be put down by Senator Stone, and he was put down by Senator Stone in Senator Stone's article in this morning's Australian. I have already said that many people believe that Senator Stone is almost always wrong in his economic judgments but that he does have this great flair for language, although this is quite a straight statement and does not have that sort of flair and does not mention meretricious players or anything like that. Senator Stone wrote amongst other things:
The Reserve Bank has thus been forced to lever up short-term interest rates in order to head off any `hot money' flight-

TALK.START.PARA: —Lever up, did he say?

—Yes. Senator Stone said that the Reserve Bank of its own volition was pushing up interest rates to stop hot money leaving the country. Dr Hewson, the mere meretricious player, says that the Government is leaning on the Reserve Bank to keep interest rates down until after the Victorian election. I leave it to the public to decide whom it will believe-whether it will believe Senator Stone or the mere meretricious player who is flitting across the stage of the House of Representatives.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware that the Commonwealth Government is helping to fund a job training course for long term unemployed in which, under threat of losing their dole payments if they do not comply, the unemployed build card houses, lie on the floor to meditate, and pretend to be blind in public parks? The course also involves basic sex education lessons which these unemployed people, some of them in their forties, find highly embarrassing and which are of no use at all in helping them to find a job. They are also taught how to use wire coat-hangers as divining rods to judge people's auras, and undergo other ridiculous indignities. The course, which lasts up to four months, is certainly being run on the Gold Coast and, I understand, at several places in New South Wales. Will the Federal Government take immediate steps to stop this ridiculous program?

—I understand that a course which roughly fits the description Senator Sheil has given is being run by an organisation which calls itself the Southport Human Resources Centre. I will be making some further inquiries about it.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Has the Minister read an article in today's Age newspaper which suggests that women should not be involved in decision making positions, should not have parliamentary careers, should not be employed in many areas of the work force because of their incapacity to mix family and career and they do not have the strength and tenacity of men?
—But they are allowed to win gold medals.
—Exactly.

—Order! I am aware that there is some trouble with the microphones. I ask all honourable senators to speak up. There seems also to be a pause of two or three seconds before microphones are switched on. I ask honourable senators to take that into account.

—As Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, will the Minister comment on the effect of views such as these on the women of Australia and whether in her consultations with community groups such opinions are widely held-outside, I might add, the lunar fringe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to the article which appeared in the Age. It represents the views of none other than Mr Ross-Edwards.
—Who?

—Mr Ross-Edwards, in Victoria. It appears that the National Party in Victoria is about as antiquated in its attitudes to women as the National Party in Queensland. It does not really surprise me, because I have had a number of years to witness at close hand the attitudes of the Queensland National Party in regard to the absence of policies--
—What about Florence?

—Yes, Senator Bjelke-Petersen is an exception. I will not go into that. When it comes to policy, obviously the National Party in Victoria does not have any policy at all in regard to equality for Victorian women. Mr Ross-Edwards says, for instance, that the National Party does offer complete equality, but everything he is reported to be saying in the remainder of the article goes on to contradict that statement. For instance, he says that for women children are an unavoidable impediment to political success. I ask women members and, indeed, male members of this place: Have we ever regarded children as an impediment to our being involved in the political process? I notice that Senator Bjelke-Petersen shakes her head. I wish that she could bring some of her good influence to bear on the Queensland National Party. It is obviously needed in the Victorian National Party. Mr Ross-Edwards goes on to say that children are not the only impediments to political life. He says that men are stronger physically and that women would be conquered by fatigue after a long day's campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: I find those remarks absolutely extraordinary, first of all, because Mr Ross-Edwards does not recognise the work that elected women throughout this country are doing on the campaign trail and the contribution they are making to Australian parliaments. Equally, he does not recognise the role of all Australian women. All Australian women are fatigued at the end of the day by the work they do, whether it is work in the home, out in the work force, or a combination of both. Mr Ross-Edwards is so out of touch with the electorate that he seems to think that a bit of running around on the campaign trail would be too much for the so-called weaker sex. Obviously Mr Ross-Edwards has not been watching the television coverage of the Olympic Games and the contribution of Australian women in that regard.

As for employment, I would like to continue with the views of Mr Ross-Edwards, because I think it is important for Victorian women to be aware of those views. He said that equal employment opportunity and the anti-discrimination policies of the Cain Government could not be expected to last long under a coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you, Senator Boswell. That is very interesting. I am not surprised that my counterpart, Senator Hill, who is Opposition spokesman on the status of women, is looking rather uncomfortable. To come back to Mr Ross-Edwards, he said, `I have never had a woman press secretary because I would not have the heart to say no, she could not leave if something was wrong with her children'. He then went on to talk about the fact that he had employed a single parent male on his staff and he was quite surprised that that male was able to balance the two roles. Not only do we now know that a coalition government would do away with anti-discrimination policies-and we have got from Senator Boswell a commitment that the National Party does not support anti-discrimination policies-but also we find that Mr Ross-Edwards is in breach of the Victorian Government's legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: What I find most offensive about the article by Mr Ross-Edwards in the Age yesterday is his attack on the Country Women's Association. I notice that Senator Chaney is groaning. I hope he is not groaning about the contribution of the Country Women's Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am groaning at the length of the answer.

—I do not believe that the length of my answer should be criticised when we are talking about the contribution of the Country Women's Association. Mr Ross-Edwards said in his comments that he dismissed the Country Women's Association, as the Nationals were `on about bigger and better things'. He obviously believes that the Country Women's Association is not--

—On a point of order: Mr President, there is an element of humour about this over-lengthy answer, but I ask you to remind the Minister that she is not to debate the question. I think we all understand the context in which she is seeking to debate the question, but I ask you to call her to order.
—There is no point of order, but it is a very long answer and the Minister should answer within the areas of her responsibility.

—I apologise if the answer is a little long and I can understand the discomfort on the Opposition benches. I finish by saying that I totally reject the views that have been put forward by Mr Ross-Edwards. I am sure that Victorian women would be well warned by the comments that he has made and they will know not only that a vote for the National Party is a vote for the demise of equal employment opportunity in Victoria and for the demise of the women's policy unit in Victoria but also that a vote for the Liberal Party means exactly the same because, regardless of what the Liberal Party's policies might be, if it is in coalition it will have to accommodate people like Senator Boswell and Mr Ross-Edwards who are totally opposed to equity in social policy.

—I have a serious question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to the Budget decisions, first, to cut from private business colleges the scheme of assistance which has been in operation for 14 years and which provided some subsidy for business and secretarial courses; and, secondly, the decision not to provide Austudy to students attending such courses. I ask: Is the Minister not aware that about 15,000 students are enrolled in such courses, of whom about 90 per cent are young women? Is she not aware that many who are disadvantaged or are from the country are already under enormous financial pressure and, because of this Government's Budget decision, will be forced to terminate their studies? How did the Minister allow such policy decisions that blatantly discriminate against young women and further reduce their educational options to get through the Budget process? What will she do about it?
—I will take that question on notice.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women concerned about the impact on social cohesion of anti-multiculturalism statements by Opposition spokesmen? Has the Minister received any feedback from non-English speaking women on the effect of this backlash, particularly on women and their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated by the response of honourable senators opposite. I am sure, as I have said before in this place, that Australian women are most unimpressed by the raucous behaviour on the other side when questions relating to serious issues such as the status of women are raised. Senator Childs raises a very important question about women from non-English speaking backgrounds. It is certainly true that women from non-English speaking backgrounds are extremely concerned about the breakdown in bipartisan policy and the attacks on multiculturalism that have been made in this place and generally in the community in the last two months.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind honourable senators opposite that it is women who have to bear the brunt of the breakdown in this bipartisan policy. It is women who have to deal with children who are teased at school. It is women who have to deal with the situation when teenagers are frustrated. In some instances young Asian teenagers in Sydney and Melbourne have been forced off buses because of this general breakdown in bipartisan support and the attack that has been made on multiculturalism. It is also women who have to deal with hostility out in the community and, particularly, it is women who have to explain to older members of the family, who are often not as able to go out and participate because of lack of English skills, that the Opposition has been attacking multiculturalism and their ready acceptance in the Australian community.

It is certainly of great concern to women from non-English speaking backgrounds. I say to Senator Vanstone and Senator Hill, who are trying to interject, that I am in a good position to know because in the last couple of months I have had consultations with about eight different organisations in all States except South Australia. I guess I thought that I could leave that in the capable hands of Senator Vanstone. She was doing a very good job in regard to her consultations until there was an unfortunate reshuffle.

A number of important initiatives have been taken with regard to women from non-English speaking backgrounds. First, in the announcement that I made about the National Women's Consultative Council about four weeks ago, I said that four of the 19 members of that Council came from a non-English speaking background. I think that has been a very significant step in reassuring women with a non-English speaking background that the Government, at least, is very concerned to communicate and consult with them. Secondly, the Office of the Status of Women and the Office of Multicultural Affairs are arranging for a joint meeting, to be held on 20 October, of Commonwealth, State, community, union and employer representatives, to discuss a new approach to better consultative measures to ensure that women from non-English speaking backgrounds feel that their views and concerns are being taken seriously at all levels of government. Furthermore, a very important initiative that this Government has taken is in regard to the 008 national toll-free number for the telephone interpreter service, with about 60 per cent of the clients who use that service being women. I believe that I can safely say to Senator Childs that the Government is very concerned about addressing the needs of women from non-English speaking backgrounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the document from which she has read.
—The Minister can table the document if it is a public affairs document or, if she claims it is confidential, she does not have to table it.
