—On a point of order, Mr President: in the light of your ruling yesterday about a speaker's notes, where a Minister-I think it was Senator Cook-voluntarily tabled some handwritten notes, and in relation to which you read a ruling of the Standing Orders Committee, I simply draw your attention to the fact that we are not talking here about the same sort of document. We are talking about the official briefing papers which the Minister has brought in, with such papers having been tabled on numerous occasions in this Senate in response to a request.
—I said that the Minister could table the document or she could claim it was confidential. She has that choice. Will Senator Reynolds table the document from which she was quoting?
—I am quite happy to table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Local Government to a speech that she made earlier this year at a local government and economic development seminar in Adelaide. I ask whether the Minister made the following comments:

QUESTION.PARA: Local governments will have to learn how to mobilise their skills and resources to work with financial institutions to lever additional funds into the local economy . . . Potential exists here for local governments to enter into planning investment type agreements with local firms. By taking a more direct role, councils would be able to become more involved in management decisions.

Is the Minister advocating that private enterprises be subjected to the same form of intervention which has been made infamous by the electorally hard-pressed Cain Government with the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC) investments, from which the Labor Government is now desperately trying to extricate itself?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr President. I would not like to say that it is the exact wording, but the general tenor of what the honourable senator has read out is certainly a common theme in a number of speeches that I have made to local government. It is well recognised that local government--
—Not general-is that what you said?

—I do have a reasonable memory, but I cannot recall the text of that speech word for word. However, we certainly encourage local government to develop its economic development strategies and to adopt an entrepreneurial role. I believe that that is very important, not just for local government but, indeed, for the Australian economy. I do not at all deny that that is one of the strategies that the Office of Local Government is adopting to try to encourage local government to move away from some of its more traditional roles, in which it is concerned only with the collection of rates and rubbish, to a much more entrepreneurial role. Local government bodies should try to attract industry into their areas and work hand in hand with the private sector, where appropriate.

—I ask a supplementary question. In the second part of my question I asked whether the Minister was advocating investments which would lead to the same sorts of problems which had been associated with the VEDC.
—I think the honourable senator is drawing a very long bow. No, I am not prepared to make that concession at all. I have absolutely nothing further to add to the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Melbourne Herald on Tuesday, 27 September, headed `Postal votes key to poll result'. In that article, Federal Liberal, Mr Roger Shipton, questioned the secrecy of postal voting. Can the Minister assure the Senate and the Australian electorate that all necessary and adequate measures are used by the Australian Electoral Commission to ensure the secrecy of a voter's ballot paper?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did read the article in the Melbourne Herald referred to by Senator Foreman. I might say that that article fits a pattern-that in the last week or two of every election, State or Federal, some outrageous statement is made by some member of the Liberal Party of Australia. There is cheap publicity pertaining to such statements. Those members never check the facts and they know that immediately afterwards any investigations will clear up their claim.

ANSWER.PARA: May I instance just two or three examples. Before the 1987 election Mr Ridley came out and claimed that a how to vote card arrived with a postal ballot paper. He argued that this was a general pattern. That matter was fully investigated and the charge was dismissed.

Before the New South Wales State election Senator Bishop, who is sitting on the other side of the chamber, jumped up and down about 400 people whom she believed had voted although they were buried in cemeteries. She has never taken that charge any further. I have written to Mr Greiner on two or three occasions, seeking a response and an investigation. All that has happened is that I have been fobbed off. If that allegation had any substance, not only would it be a breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act but also it would be a criminal action. Mr Greiner and the rest of the Liberals know that this was just a slimy stunt before the last State election.

The third example was raised in the Melbourne Herald. Mr Shipton says that he has taken out a postal vote overseas and he believes that that system is open to abuse. I might say that that is the same system that has existed for the last 50 years. That is the same system which existed when Mr Shipton's party was in government-from 1971 to 1972 and from 1975 to 1983. There is no evidence that anyone opposite-anyone who was in the Fraser Government, the McMahon Government or the Gorton Government-tried to alter that system. They were totally satisfied with the integrity of that system.

There is, if you like, an extenuating circumstance in regard to Mr Shipton. Coming from the electorate of Higgins, he would never have supervised or organised a scrutiny of postal votes. When Higgins falls to the Australian Labor Party, civilisation as we now know it will certainly end. As well, Mr Shipton would not be involved in the normal process of organising scrutineers for Electoral Commission ballots. He is much more interested in organising scrutineers for the internal ballots of the Liberal Party in the electorate of Higgins because all the big businessmen who aspire to get into parliament have to try to white-ant the jewel in the crown-the seat of Higgins-because the Liberals hold so few seats in Victoria. I am really surprised that Mr Shipton has taken the time to go on a tour of Europe. Now that the cat is away, I wonder what the mice are doing back in the electorate of Higgins.

Let me go to the actual method of counting postal votes, and some people here at least would have been involved in that. Postal votes come in in an outer envelope. Scrutineers are invited to be present during all parts of the count. Votes are never counted individually; they are always counted in bulk so that no-one can detect who has voted in a particular way. They are cut open. When the ballot papers are extracted they are turned upside down, so there is no viewing of the ballot papers. Scrutineers can be present at all times. Ballot papers are counted only when there is a substantial pile.

So the accusation by Mr Shipton that in some way we could correlate the name on the back of the envelope with the actual vote is really an extremist sort of view. I would suggest that if he is back from his jaunt in Europe he scrutineer in an electoral office just once-after the State election-because the same method is used as that following a Federal election. He should acquaint himself of how things have been done for the last 50 years.

What has happened in this case fits the classic pattern. Somewhere the Liberal Party has a manual entitled `How to win elections'. That manual has been reprinted a few times. It has to be updated a bit, given past failures. But one of the pages in the manual states, `Pull some cheap stunt in the last week that implies a lack of integrity by the Electoral Commission'. That is what it says and that is what those on the other side do election after election. I am just sorry that newspapers are gullible enough to print these stories.

I will say that the article in the Melbourne Herald, unlike a lot of others, went on to quote the Chief Electoral Officer in Victoria, Mr Lyons, and actually give the answer to this problem to prove what a lie this proposition is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to you, Mr President, refers to the behaviour of an Australian Labor Party senator for Queensland. Are you aware, Mr President, that last night in the non-members bar of this building Senator Burns abused a female bar attendant and called her `a wog'? Are you, Mr President, also aware that, because of Senator Burns's action and behaviour, the catering staff of this building are considering industrial action? Will you ask the senator to apologise to the lady he called a `wog', which, incidentally, reduced her to tears?
—I am not aware of the circumstances referred to in the honourable senator's question. I was not given notice of the question. I will investigate it and make a reply at the appropriate time.

—I address my question to the Minister for Finance. In his personal explanation on Tuesday afternoon, Senator Messner asserted that $56 a week, which we have heard so much about, was the sum required to restore in 1989 the real household disposable income of the average Australian family to the level it had been in March 1983. Can the Minister provide any information to the Senate regarding that $56 a week? Is that the sum required to restore the real household disposable income of the average Australian family to its level of March 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a, to say the least, confused statement on Tuesday afternoon, Senator Messner said-and it appears in Hansard as a quote from Mr Peacock:

ANSWER.PARA: I am concerned with assumptions about wages and inflation over the next 12 months. By 1 July 1989 Australian families will require about $56 a week to restore their household real disposable income to what it was in March of 1983 when this Government came to power.
What that is asserting, of course-and the honourable senator was quoting that other well known innumerate, Mr Peacock-is that living standards have fallen, that real per capita incomes have fallen--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. It is offensive to refer to the honourable member as innumerate. I ask for a withdrawal. I think it is objectionable to the honourable member.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition says that there is an imputation. Will the Minister withdraw what he has just said?

—I will withdraw it if Senator Chaney is upset by it. I observe for the record that the Opposition had a $1,500m error in its shadow Budget in 1987. If that does not constitute decisive evidence of innumeracy I cannot imagine what would. Words have no meaning.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked a question about changes in real incomes per capita since 1983. I have some data addressing that question. `Household disposable income' is a term used in national accounting and, as even Senator Messner may be aware, it has a very precise meaning which is defined in the Australian national accounts. The published national accounts do not provide figures for real household disposable income or for average real household disposable income. The standard practice employed by statisticians and economists is to get real household disposable income by the use of a private consumption deflator and to get average real income on a per capita basis. Senator Stone would be well aware of that and even the mere meretricious player may be aware of it. The real average household disposable income of Australians has been calculated and presented in Budget Papers for a number of years. On page 56 of this year's Budget Paper No. 1 there is a very interesting table. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is already published; it is taken from the Budget Papers. The pathetic creature who leads for the Opposition will not allow it to be incorporated in Hansard. That is a measure of the desperation to which he and the Opposition have sunk. I invite people to look at page 56 of Budget Paper No. 1, which shows household disposable income per capita. For every financial year from 1982-83 to an estimate for 1988-89 it shows that in all but two of those years there has been an appreciable increase in per capita household disposable income in real terms. There was a big decline in 1982-83 of per capita household disposable income. That was the consequence of the last Budget that the discredited former Treasurer brought down.
—Where was John Stone then?

—I am sure that Senator Stone was assiduously working in the Treasury to try, unsuccessfully and in a completely futile endeavour, to make the Fraser Government and the then Treasurer have some economic strategy in the 1982 Budget. That Budget stands out among all Budgets presented in Australia as having absolutely no economic strategy. The Opposition had a political strategy only which the discredited former Treasurer and his then Prime Minister thought might just get them over the line in a premature election. They were wrong about that as well.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1982-83 average per capita household disposable income fell by 1.8 per cent. In the following years it went up by 2.6 per cent, 1.1 per cent and 1.4 per cent. It did fall in 1986-87 by 1.3 per cent. But when we look at those figures in total we see that over the five-year period of 1982-83 to 1987-88-I have not included the estimate for this year-there was an increase in real per capita disposable income of 4.4 per cent. It is a great mystery where Mr Peacock got the $56 from, which he claims average households have suffered in household disposable income.

The final point I want to make is that those figures do not take into account the Medicare effects. That is an essential item of expenditure for most Australian families; and health insurance is no longer essential.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In view of the Minister's recent pseudo-virtuous pre- tence that the Australian Labor Party is always anxious to uphold the electoral law, could he explain on what possible basis he justifies the failure of the Victorian Cain Government to prosecute the State Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Peter Batchelor, who was blatantly and wilfully responsible for the printing and publication of a fraudulent and misleading how to vote card in the recent Victorian by-election for the seat of Nunawading? Is it also true that such disgraceful failure to act flew in the face of eight separate legal opinions which advised that serious electoral offences had been committed? Is this the standard of electoral fair play that the Government now espouses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision not to prosecute Mr Batchelor was by the Electoral Commissioner of Victoria, Mr Richardson. Mr Richardson was appointed by a previous Liberal government. In the time in which he exercised those powers over a number of years he made a variety of decisions, all of which were regarded as fair. I did not like all the decisions in terms of the way some of the boundaries were drawn. That is where the chips fell. I did not like the way Mr Richardson ruled on informal votes in Nunawading in 1985 or Werribee in 1976. The fact that I did not like it does not mean that I impugned his integrity. Senator Alston automatically assumes that there was a strong enough legal case not based on his legal knowledge but I suspect based on his partisanship as a member of the Liberal Party of Australia and as a former President.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw Senator Alston's attention to a similar case. That is the case in Petrie in which the candidate and others put out a how to vote card as though it was an Australian Democrats how to vote card. We had to take out an injunction against them. We then sought legal advice from the deputy prosecutor's office as to whether that person could be prosecuted. The advice said no. It was a very analogous case. The legal implications of that case are also applicable to Victoria.

If Senator Alston thinks that someone should just be prosecuted, not on the basis of an assessment at law but on the basis of his partisan political position, albeit with some legal training, I reject that. There was an upper House inquiry into this matter which Senator Alston forced through. He stacked the committee 3 : 2 and he still could not get three votes. We had two Labor people on the committee. Senator Alston had two Liberals and a National Party member. It was meant to be a star chamber and he could not even get the evidence there, with its unlimited powers to get anywhere near a conviction of Mr Batchelor. Even when he stacked the odds 3 : 2 Mr Batchelor was eventually, in a de facto sense, cleared 3 : 2 the other way.

Senator Alston has raised this issue time and time again and he has got nowhere. I suppose that if I had it in my power I would have preferred the matter to go through the legal process and Mr Batchelor would be cleared as he should have been. But I will never support a system that says, `Because he holds a political position we will not treat him the same as any other citizen'. Mr Richardson, the one who made the decision, was an appointee of a Liberal government which presided over the Victorian electoral system for at least 15 years. He made a whole series of decisions. Never once did our side or the Opposition side attack his integrity until the Opposition did so in the last few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Boswell asked me a series of questions. I have already put on the record this morning a correction to part of his questions and I am still waiting for an apology from him.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Peter Baume-Did you give him a copy of it?

TALK.START.PARA: —He was here. I asked him to be here. But there are no hard feelings: I have a much more extensive answer on the rest of the question. The Bundaberg Rifle Range became surplus to Commonwealth requirements in 1983. Consistent with the then Government policy, rifle clubs in occupation were offered first option to purchase at Commonwealth valuation. Their financial and legal problems delayed this process for some years. The most recent valuation by the Australian Valuation Office on 20 October 1987 was based on advice from the Bundaberg Council Town Planner on the likely future zoning that that Council would apply and other relevant market evidence. The Council's advice appears to have been drawn from the town plan and the strategic plan. The valuation was $270,000. The Bundaberg Small Bore Rifle Club accepted a priority offer to purchase the property for $270,000. Settlement occurred on 11 July 1988 after Brisbane-based officers of the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) Australian Property Group had signed the disposal authorisation on 4 May 1988. So it was a priority sale to the rifle club based on the Australian Valuation Office valuation. I now table the valuation report and the disposal authorisation.

ANSWER.PARA: On 29 August Mr West became aware of the transaction when the Department of Administrative Services Australian Property Group advised him that the Bundaberg Small Bore Rifle Club had immediately on-sold the property for $370,000. Mr West immediately requested further briefing and, on 6 September 1988, in consultation with DAS Australian Property Group, he initiated an independent internal review. Mr West considered that review on 27 September 1988. The review confirmed that the Bundaberg Small Bore Rifle Club on-sold to a private company-Eskrose Pty Ltd-for $370,000, with the intention that the property be developed for purposes other than shooting.

Mr West is further concerned at suggestions that the rifle club may have had prior intention to on-sell and may have received funds additional to the $370,000 purchase price from Eskrose Pty Ltd. Mr West has been advised by his officers that press reports of multimillion dollar price tags, however, are inaccurate. Nevertheless, Mr West is concerned, firstly, to establish beyond doubt the probity and competence of DAS Australian Property Group and Australian Valuation Office officers who handled the transaction and, secondly, to investigate whether the on-purchaser may have had knowledge of any proposed zoning changes; that is, information not available to the DAS Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office.

Therefore, on 27 September 1988 Mr West requested referral of the matter to the Australian Federal Police for internal and external investigation and consideration of possible tax evasion aspects of the alleged extra payment to the rifle club over and above the $370,000 purchase price. Mr West also ordered that the matter be drawn to the attention of the Australian Taxation Commis- sioner. In view of this, and the Government's current policy to dispose of surplus properties on the open market, Mr West has instructed the Department of Administrative Services to withdraw offers for priority sales of rifle ranges to other rifle clubs where there is no legal impediment to doing so.

In the publicity surrounding this event the role of Mr Brian Courtice, the local member, has been very confused in the press, and very unfortunately so. I must place on record that it was Mr Brian Courtice, the member for Hinkler, who drew the problems with the sale of this rifle club to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services. That was his first involvement in the matter. He has acted with great honour and propriety in drawing these problems to the Minister's attention. I think that the press coverage of his role in it has been quite distorted.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to make a few comments in relation to that part of the paper which refers to the Office of the Status of Women. I am very pleased to now have that responsibility on behalf of the Opposition and I intend to carry on the good work of my colleague Senator Vanstone. I do want to say that I intend to adopt a somewhat different approach to this matter from that being carried on by the Government. Regrettably, in this area the Government is strong on rhetoric, strong on propaganda, and works well with the interest groups and the professionals in the field, but unfortunately it seems to me, as an objective observer, it neglects the real questions that concern enhancing the status of women.

I think the Senate could not have received a better demonstration of that than in Question Time today, when I had the opportunity to put to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Reynolds) a very genuine and important question in relation to the education of young women and the educational opportunities that are going to be lost as a result of changes that occurred in this year's Budget, changes that particularly affect business colleges and that are going to mean that young women within Australia are going to be less able to afford training in private business colleges. The Minister indicated that she would have to take the question on notice. In other words, she had no idea what I was talking about. I find that incredible in circumstances where some 15,000 young people in Australia are being educated and trained in these private colleges, of whom 90 per cent are women. Therefore the Government's decision is clearly going to have a major and detrimental effect against the interests of those young women. That is the type of important area that the Government should be addressing its attention to and clearly is not.

I thought that as part of my education in this area perhaps the first places I should visit are the types of places I would not expect Ministers in this Government to visit, and I talked to women in the cities of Port Augusta and Whyalla in South Australia. I did that last week and was astounded to learn from women's groups in Whyalla and Port Augusta that they estimate that in Whyalla between 30 and 40 per cent of women under the age of 25 who wish to be employed are in fact unemployed. There could be no better demonstration, I would have thought, of the failure of government policies in relation to young women than those appalling unemployment figures. When I asked the women in those cities, `What is the most important thing that could be done to enhance the status of women?', they said, `Provide employment'.

I have used this opportunity to draw to the attention of the Minister the fact that if this Government concentrated more on ensuring financial security and financial independence for women, rather than on pursuing some of its highbrow rhetoric, the women of this country would be better off. For the benefit of the Minister, I will take the matter one step further. The Women's Refuge in Whyalla was the first in South Australia and is carried on by the Young Women's Christian Association, a very fine organisation with a wonderful record of service in the best traditions. When I visited that refuge last week and talked to the women who run it concerning their clients-those women who have to call upon them for help in situations of domestic violence-I found that practically 100 per cent of women who need to call upon the refuge for help are unemployed and that approximately 80 per cent of their partners or spouses are unemployed. That simply demonstrates even further the fact that, if this Government concentrated in the critical area of unemployment among women, the women of this country would be better off.

I urge Senator Reynolds to give that matter greater consideration, to give greater consideration to the question of education and training, and perhaps to look at the effect on women of this Government's high tax policies for lower income groups. The Government has increased taxes on lower income groups at the same time as reducing taxes on high income earners. The Minister would not then find that disadvantaged and lower income women in such seats as Adelaide and Port Adelaide, as we saw on a very recent occasion, are turning away from this Government because it is simply out of touch and no longer represents their interests.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Australia is an ageing country. People are having fewer children and living longer, and this has important consequences for the future revenue base of the nation and the capacity of governments to pay pensions. As the demographics of the Australian population change there will be a smaller proportion of young people earning wages and paying taxes to support a growing number of people who retire at 60 years of age or thereabouts. The cold, hard fact is that governments will have to wake up to this fact now and not in a few years.

I believe that it is time to evaluate the need for a national superannuation scheme. New Zealand has such a scheme. It was developed by the late Sir John Marshall because, as an accountant and an actuary, he foresaw that that nation did not have the population base to provide pensions and benefits to the increasing aged percentage of the population. I am not suggesting that such a scheme would not have problems, but I would like to see a committee established by the Government to investigate all the options and to look at the demographic changes that are occurring in Australia through the eyes of an actuary. I think it is timely to consider such a report into retirement incomes, specifically in the light of the actions of the Government, which has been found out in its greedy attempts to dip much more deeply into people's pockets and particularly into the investments of retired Australians.

I believe that the Senate, as a legislative chamber, has a responsibility to make sure that the laws we pass are technically correct, but even more important is the impact that they have on society as a whole, particularly the aged section of the population. I believe that superannuation guidelines and rules of a long term nature should be established, because superannuation affects people's security in retirement, and policies should last for a working person's life. It therefore gives me great concern to witness in this chamber the introduction of a whole host of legislation affecting pensions-in fact, the whole gamut of retirement incomes and retirement taxes which nowadays seem to be constantly chopped and changed by this Federal Government.

The Government's changes to the taxation of superannuation include such things as the 15 per cent tax on the investment earnings of superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and roll-over annuity funds; and the new tax on employer contributions to superannuation funds. There also now are restrictions on the level of benefits payable for both lump sum and pension options. Unfortunately, this regular revision of superannuation and retirement laws and pensions means that many people are very wary about taking out superannuation policies and the like. Many could decide not to do so because they do not know what future laws could be from this Labor Government.

All too often in the taxation legislation minefield the rules are changed, often by a complex series of amendments which are hard to follow even for parliamentarians or the experts in the field, let alone the ordinary retirees of this nation or those facing retirement. Those concerns also occur with superannuation legislation. I am firmly of the belief that people have the right to take out a contract with a reasonable expectation of what the result will be and what their future benefits and taxation obligations will be. I am not talking about minor changes, because these will always occur, but governments do not have the right to say to a working man who has worked for 30 years, within five years of his retirement, that there will be significant changes which could affect his status in his retirement. I believe that the report before us today is another manifestation of the many changes that have occurred in the superannuation area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDE TO THE ASSESSMENT OF RATES OF VETERANS' PENSIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Section 29 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The new Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions (GARVP) tabled today is a complex document on any objective assessment. Essentially, it provides the basis for determining disability pensions for veterans. It also relates to the controversial lifestyle questionnaire. In particular there is considerable concern among veterans in relation to the determining system and the guide. Firstly, considerable delays in making determinations on veterans' applications are resulting in some veterans dying before the completion of their case. Justice delayed in this situation is justice denied to those who served their country in times of war.

Secondly, there has been a steady reduction in the level of the general rate of disability pension increases as the system has been toughened up against the veteran, especially in relation to the criteria for eligibility for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension. The recent report of the independent monitoring committee strongly recommended a series of reviews and investigations in relation to the additional aspects of the repatriation disability pension determining system and the Government's response. By and large, this response has been merely to throw the matter to the Repatriation Commission's ongoing review of the guide. Undoubtedly, this can be a method for procrastination. As the shadow Minister for veterans affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, pointed out, by far the better alternative would be to re-create the independent monitoring committee and issue specific terms of reference to it from time to time. The recently released coalition policy in relation to veterans affairs, entitled `A fair go for veterans', gave a categorical commitment to retain the independent monitoring committee for this purpose.

Thirdly, many veterans have despaired at the complexity of aspects of both the guide and the lifestyle questionnaire, which is to be doubled in length, but which I concede is necessary to help bring about consistent determinations on behalf of veterans. It seems that the new guide and the lifestyle questionnaire are an improvement and will provide some increase in the level of determinations-for example, 5 to 10 per cent in respect of cardiology patients.

Because of its complexity, any new guide and lifestyle questionnaire will need to be monitored very closely to ensure that it does not impact harshly on veterans. The Senate, in any subsequent consideration of the guide, must take into account the fact that Service personnel and their service in times of war cannot be equated with civilian experience. It is very much a different circumstance, requiring discerning legislation which discriminates in favour of and not against the veteran. The Liberal and National parties will now study in detail the new guide and the lifestyle questionnaire and determine any further action which might be required, after further consultations with many organisations, including the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL), Legacy, the War Widows Guild and the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council.

The RSL has already indicated its independent assessment that the GARVP 2 represents a significant improvement on GARVP 1, but it has also indicated its very real concerns over many aspects of repatriation in recent times. Veterans are sick and tired of the series of cutbacks and complex changes that they have faced in recent years. They now want a consistent, fair guide, not only for veterans but also for war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of Senator Tambling in relation to this very important document which is referred to in veterans circles as the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions or GARVP 2. It needs to be read in conjunction with the monitoring committee's report which was tabled earlier in this session. Honourable senators will be aware that a special committee was set up to monitor the application of the new Veterans' Entitlements Act. The committee, in making its recommendations in its report, cited GARVP 1 in its first form, in which it was applied subsequent to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1987, to be a major source of dissatisfaction among veterans. It made a series of recommendations in relation to a variation. What we are looking at here today is the tabling by the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) of that variation on the guide for assessment which is referred to as GARVP 2. It is accompanied today by an explanatory statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Ben Humphreys.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in the day I was approached by a senior officer of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) and I have had discussions with other members of the veterans community and they have asked me to convey to the Senate their reactions to this document. They reflect very much the comments that were made by Senator Tambling. In essence they urge quick assessment of this document. They cite the fact that it is absolutely critical to the welfare of veterans and if it proves to be as unsatisfactory as GARVP 1 they would like the Minister's attention and reaction to be prompt and urgent. We need to be aware of the fact that this is the set of guidelines which determines the fortnightly income of veterans. It is on the basis of this set of criteria that judgments are made about the entitlements of individuals. Many of these individuals are aged and infirm. There has been widespread dissatisfaction with this process in the past. So the RSL and other veterans groups consider that GARVP 2 represents a significant improvement upon GARVP 1 and, therefore, they would not seek its disallowance. However, any commitment that could be obtained from the Government-specifically from the Minister; perhaps in the very near furture-for a greater degree of urgency in undertaking the reviews recommended by the monitoring committee would be very helpful.

Further, the monitoring committee recommended-and the RSL and other veterans groups support this recommendation-that the adequacy of GARVP 2 will be able to be assessed only from the operation, experience and application of it. The monitoring committee had difficulty in obtaining data on which to base its assessment of GARVP 1. So it will be important for the Government and the Minister to commence a deliberate program for the collection of objective statistical data relating to assessments under GARVP 2 from the commencement date of 1 December this year. In essence, what the veteran community is saying in relation to this variation in the criteria of assessment of pensions is, `Please regard it with urgency. Please see that it is a matter of day to day significance to veterans', and it calls upon the Minister to report quickly-they hope within six months-and to initiate immediately a data collection base to allow a valid assessment of the adequacy or otherwise of GARVP 2.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together, and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I would like to refer to the experience involved in printing this report of the Senate Industry, Science and Technology Committee. The report deals with the topic of revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing industry. Its subtitle is `Making it together'. Its basic theme is the need for all Australians to lift their game if there is any chance for future economic prosperity via the manufacturing sector.

This report was due for delivery from the printers on Monday of this week so that it could be presented to the Senate on Tuesday, 27 September. On Monday, 26 September, the secretariat was informed by the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) that it would not be ready in time. The reason given was that some shift workers had not turned up for work. I have made my own inquiries about the situation and have discovered that: firstly, an old machine broke down on Friday, 23 September; and, secondly, a maintenance man from Melbourne was expected to be in Canberra on Tuesday, 27 September, to fix the machine-a four-day delay.

Our secretariat had checked progress as recently as Friday, 23 September, and had been told that delivery would occur on Monday, 26 September, as previously promised. The fact is that an officer of the AGPS told us a `fib' as to the reason for the delay-that is, blame the workers. The breaking down of an old machine and a four-day delay in obtaining maintenance are typical incidents that occur in industry and they are unacceptable. Our report addresses these problems.

This report is the result of the Committee's examination of the prevailing attitudes to manufacturing and the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing. It deals with the attitudes of governments, business organisations, trade unions and individuals within the Australian community towards manufacturing industry. In pursuing its inquiries, the Committee confined its attention to the single objective of the revitalisation of manufacturing in Australia. Given the substantial downturn in agricultural and mining markets, manufacturing must be seen as Australia's chief means of economic revival.

Currently Australia imports more than 70 per cent of its machinery and equipment. Ninety per cent of Australia's imports are manufactures. Australia's main hope of recovery lies in spending much less on the importation of manufactured goods and in earning much more from their export. To achieve larger slices of both the domestic and export markets, niche markets need to be identified and developed and goods of high quality need to be produced.

Australia must create its own unique manufacturing culture. It can restore its international competitiveness only with the support and cooperation of all sectors of the community. This support and cooperation can be obtained only if Australians have appropriate attitudes.

The need for more positive attitudes towards manufacturing industry was stressed to the Committee in the course of the inquiry. Numerous witnesses and submissions described attitudes which have an impact on manufacturing sector performance. The report emphasises the negative aspects of these attitudes. By identifying and discussing such aspects the Committee hopes to encourage further discussion and action that will help overcome the detrimental effects. Their general recognition and discussion are an essential prelude to the revitalisation of manufacturing industry.

The Committee has drawn attention to the tip of the iceberg. Much more research needs to be done in the general area of attitudes to manufacturing. The Committee considers it very important that all those involved at government, industry management and employee level-in fact, the community at large-should address the question of attitudes. The Committee, having identified a number of attitudes whose existence affects manufacturing industry performance, looked at several critical areas of the manufacturing sector where attitudes are important.

In the light of the increasing competitiveness of world trading conditions and the rapidity of change in products and markets, the need for initiative, creativity, dynamism, flexibility, vision and self-reliance on the part of business management is greater than ever. To help management become more enterprising the Committee recommends consistent government leadership and involvement in specifically targeted programs such as industry plans. The Committee also recommends ways for management to improve its performance by looking beyond the domestic market and actively seeking the cooperation and involvement of its work force.

The Committee considers there is much evidence in the manufacturing sector of the positive results of harmonious industrial relations. Industrial democracy policies which allow appropriate employee participation encourage the development of positive attitudes. For Australia's manufacturing industry to become strong, the cooperation of employees and their informed involvement in the workplace are essential. The Committee supports moves to rationalise unions and to break down the barriers between employers and employees in the interests of healthier, more efficient industries. The media can also help to spread the news about positive developments in manufacturing industry. As we all know, they have a large audience and can do much to influence and shape community attitudes.

Reorganisation of manufacturing systems can have a big influence on the productive capacity. The Committee recommends the adoption of techniques which speed up production times and ensure that factories are operating at maximum efficiency. These include, of course, value adding management techniques such as just-in-time, total quality control, the use of computer-aided design and manufacturing, and flexible manufacturing cells. Management should not try to do it all on its own. Professional assistance from such bodies as the Technology Transfer Council, the National Industry Extension Service and the Australian Productivity Council is available and should be made use of when reorganising production processes.

One area which cannot be ignored is that of the education and training needs of the manufacturing industry sector. The Committee found that, even though there have been recent moves to link education and training more closely to the needs of industry, there remains a great deal to be done. I will mention only some of the recommendations here. The Committee recommends that the Government inaugurate a review of the effectiveness of skills training in Australia. In addition to work experience programs for students, there should be opportunities for teachers to familiarise themselves with the reality of working in industry. All students, regardless of their sex, should be encouraged to study the full range of subjects. Both governments and the manufacturing industry should work towards breaking down the education system's attitudinal bias against manufacturing training.

Australia's research and development effort is another critical area for manufacturing sector performance. If Australia is to lessen its dependence on the volatile commodity markets of the world it will need to expand its production and exports of elaborately transformed goods. To achieve this expansion, industry needs to increase substantially its research and development effort. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government at least maintain its direct expenditure on research and development and special provisions for tax deductibility and the grants for the industrial research and development scheme. The Committee would also like to see the encouragement, wherever possible, of innovation from the shop floor and regular interchanges between government, academic and private research bodies to facilitate exchange of information and development of new ideas.

The Committee gave some attention to the macro-economic environment. We consider that Government policies should continue to be directed towards the substantial reduction of unemployment, interest rates, inflation and the balance of payments deficit. In addition, we believe that specific measures are sometimes necessary to help industry adjust to the more competitive world trading conditions now prevailing and to stimulate investment in new industries. The Committee specifically recommends the use of industry plans where there are special problems, provided that they incorporate clear objectives.

We also recommend that a review be undertaken by the end of June 1990 with a view to an extension of the management and investment companies program past June 1991 if it is justified in the light of experience to that date. The Committee recommends continued support by the Government for organisations which promote the development of manufacturing industries such as Austrade, the National Industry Extension Service, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Technology Transfer Council, the Australian Manufacturing Council and the Australian Science and Technology Council. Foreign investment in Australia should be strictly monitored to ensure that it is beneficial to Australia. Immediate attention also should be given to other areas which affect industrial productivity such as transport and handling arrangements, labour on-costs, business regulation and takeovers.

There are many other conclusions and recommendations contained in the report. What I have tried to do today is provide honourable senators with an overview and a taste of its contents. The Committee hopes that the report will be a positive tool for influencing and changing attitudes of all Australians to the manufacturing industry. We have even gone so far as to state that a doubling of manufacturing productivity levels in five to seven years should not be beyond Australia's capacity.

In conclusion, I would like to thank all those who made submissions to the inquiry and those who gave evidence. As a final word, I remind the Senate that when the former Committee on Industry and Trade commenced this inquiry it was described as a threshold inquiry. The aim was to examine attitudes so that we could all gain a clearer understanding of the views and the reasons for their persistence. The reasoning was that only then would it be possible to address in a more purposeful manner the issues of manufacturing growth and investment. I hope we have gone some considerable way towards not only understanding the views but also offering positive ways of stimulating manufacturing industry growth. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking today on the waterfront investigation of the Inter-State Commission, I wish to make a number of initial remarks. First, this is a massive report. In a way it is a pity that we have only a short time to deal with it. Secondly, I think it is fitting that this follows the report from Senator Childs on the revitalisation of the manufacturing industry. Everyone knows that if we are to get this country back on track we have to revitalise the manufacturing industry in respect of both import replacement and exports. A key part of that is to be able to use the waterfront in an efficient way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) put out an excellent report, but basically its conclusion was that there should be a five-year scheme to streamline the waterfront. We are confronted with three options. The first is to do nothing and leave the status quo-which would be an absolute guarantee of a banana republic and what has been commonly termed the white trash of Asia. The second alternative is the five-year proposal, as suggested by the IAC. The third option is to act now. I believe that we have no option other than to act now, if we are going to get this country back on track.

The Australian waterfront is renowned for its lack of productivity, its inefficiency and the enormous costs that apply to industry as a whole. The Inter-State Commission's report summarises this aspect as follows: it suffers from ineffective management, it has poor work force training and career arrangements, it has an introspective industrial attitude, a poor response to user needs, poor information flows to users and between links in the transport chain, a lack of supply and demand balance-often reflected in congestion and queues or in under-utilisation of expensive facilities-diffusion of governmental responsibility, and it is an abuse of monopoly power.

I think that last item sums it all up. We have a monopoly situation on the wharves. Unless there is an alternative method of transportation, such as the airlines, an importer of manufacturing goods will be disadvantaged. Senator Childs has indicated that, of all machinery used in Australia, 70 per cent is imported and it has to come through a very expensive wharf situation. Of all imports into Australia, 90 per cent are manufactured goods.

As an indication of the problems that we have, the cost of shipping milk powder, for example, from Tasmania to Taiwan is $72 a tonne, while the cost of shipping it from Tasmania to Melbourne is $82 a tonne. That is an incredible situation, and one that we cannot allow to continue in this country. There are many other similar examples. Adelaide Brighton Cement obtains supplies of cement clinker for its plant in Darwin from Japan rather than its own operations in Adelaide. The relative freight costs are $12 a tonne from Japan and $20 a tonne from its own operations in Adelaide. This applies across the board in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about what the Queensland Government did to the Adelaide Steamship Co.

—We are talking about the problems of the waterfront. Senator Maguire is diverting attention on this issue because of industrial rorts which are a plague on this country and which have arisen due to the actions of people like those who put Senator Maguire into this place. We have heard Senator Robert Ray admit to me that the Australian Labor Party is the political arm of the trade union movement. We all know about that, and yet honourable senators opposite sit there and allow the destruction of this country and make it totally impossible to revitalise the manufacturing sector. Until they get this right, there is no hope. I am asking the Government to address the question. Senator Maguire, for example, should not throw red herrings across the path of those who want to draw these matters to the attention of the Parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The most significant thing that has happened to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) since the presentation of its last annual report is that it has been moved from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Treasury. I hope that this power grab by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to the anger of Senator Button, will not mean that the Treasurer will begin to form industries assistance policy in the same way as general Treasury announcements-that is, by Press release instead of by substantive announcements made to parliament and then supported by timely legislation.

Because of Senator Button's lack of comprehension of economic issues, as was certainly displayed during Question Time in the Senate on Tuesday-when it became apparent that he was not aware of the linkage between terms of trade and the exchange rate and the effect that this would have on the international competitiveness of Australian industry-it is therefore not surprising that he was stripped of this IAC responsibility.

The move of portfolio responsibility for the IAC brings a most unusual situation to the fore. Whilst Senator Button and his Department retain overall responsibility for industry policy, Senator Button has lost control over references to the most powerful body in the field of industry assistance. It is rather like having an Attorney-General having no say over the Australian Law Reform Commission.

I welcome the change of thrust of IAC investigations, but I question the Government's priorities in relation to cutting staff from 360 to a little over 200. However, the more lean commission has shown that it can still function adequately with fewer staff and provide competent advice to the Government. But I am concerned at the quite dramatic fall in the number of reports from the IAC in the current year. In 1987-88, there were only 10 references, with 11 last year, while in 1982-83 there were 20 references, and 33 for 1981-82. The last two periods were Fraser years. So, there is less commitment by this Government in looking at efficiency generally so far as it affects industry efficiency.

I believe that issues, such as the inquiry into the Government's non-tax charges, are just as important as those relating to manufacturing efficiency. Perhaps it is time to change the name of the Industries Assistance Commission to something that reflects more adequately its current inquiries and certainly its wider responsibilities under its new Minister-the Treasurer. Perhaps we could call the IAC the Efficiency Advisory Commission-which I think would be more appropriate in terms of its meeting its wider responsibilities. The wide ranging report also focuses on changes in industry protection. Judging from the speeches that have been made in this chamber, not everyone is aware that, for example, in the clothing and footwear manufacturing industry tariffs have fallen by 17 per cent in the past 12 months, while in the motor vehicle industry tariffs on fully imported cars have been cut by 12.5 per cent.

It is unfortunate that the Government's response to the Commission's draft report on coastal shipping was disappointing, with the Government actually distancing itself from the findings and the recommendations made at that time. However, the final report, which I think was tabled in the Senate yesterday, appears to have received greater government approval, even though, strangely, it canvasses the same issues as did the previous report-but perhaps the more moderate language has helped the Government in its relationships with the unions. In the past, restrictive union policies and the Navigation Act have prevented competition in the coastal shipping area. These problems must be addressed urgently to enable industries to be competitive overseas.

I thank Senator Parer for his comment in which he compared freight charges between Tasmania and Melbourne with the charges between Melbourne and Taiwan. I give as a further example the fact that it is far cheaper for an Australian industry to transport a manufactured product by sea from Melbourne to Tokyo, offload it at Tokyo and transship it back to Port Moresby than to send it direct from Melbourne to Port Moresby. Such a situation is quite ludicrous and very damaging to Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chapter 1 of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) annual report is devoted to a discussion of micro-economic reform. The Commission emphasises the urgency of the situation, an urgency of which one wishes the Government would take note. For example, the Commission states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to remove impediments to efficiency is made more urgent by the rapidity with which such reforms are now spreading through many other parts of the world.

I think this is the crux of what is wrong in Australia. There is still not a recognition among certain power groups, and certainly within the Government itself, that we are on the world scene and that we must adjust to that scene. All sorts of noises are made. Senator Button makes nice noises about all this. He says, `We are in there doing our bit'. But, when it comes to the hard decisions, one does not see much happening. The report goes on to say:
. . . Australia will need to move faster than its competitors if gains in international competitiveness are to be achieved.

Of course it will because we are so far behind. We have an inflation rate which is two to three times higher than those of our competitors overseas. We have interest rates which are substantially higher. In recent days we have debated the punitive level of interest rates which affect not only business but also every home buyer who has to make mortgage payments. I think it is patently obvious that the Government has become arrogant and has totally lost touch with the ordinary aspirations of ordinary people.

The report mentions the need for greater flexibility in labour markets but, of course, does not offer any judgment about the Government's current efforts. The report can be interpreted as making an implicit criticism of the pace and extent of adjustment. The coastal shipping episode, which honourable senators will recall was the subject of a report put out by the IAC and denigrated by the Government, and the current IAC amendment legislation could indicate-and this is of great concern-the Government's intention to muzzle the IAC because it is saying things that the Government does not want to hear and will not act upon. If this is true, it is a very retrograde step.

Of course the IAC is not perfect but it has shown itself to be an independent body. The Government does not like independent bodies. Hence, it stacks bodies with its own people at all levels. Of course, the comment is made around the Australian Capital Territory these days that the Government is stacking the Public Service at all levels. The IAC has done a lot to expose publicly the cost of protecting certain groups. It might be true that the IAC's recommendations pay little heed to the political implications of their implementation. But we all appreciate that the IAC is an independent body and politics is not and should not be its job.

In the short time left to me, I commend the IAC on its annual report. This extensive report is a great reference document in many areas. For instance, in the appendices to the report, the IAC talks about the steel industry. It draws attention to the fact that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd committed $800m to a plan, spent $1.5 billion and that its only reward was a poor productivity performance because of the attitude of the trade union movement. I recognise that the performance has improved in recent times as it must.

The IAC discusses superannuation and draws our attention to the fact that this year the Government is going to gain $980m in revenue on superannuation and $1.4 billion in 1990-91. Yet, the Government has the audacity to say, `We are going to rip this out of the system but in the end you will get the same amount of money you would have got on retirement if we had not done so'. That is an impossibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I draw attention to some of the features of the Australian Maritime College which, as I think is well known, was established by a Liberal-National Party government. The Australian Maritime College not only has become a top college in Australia but is amongst the top maritime colleges in the world. The college features three distinct schools-the school of engineering, the school of fisheries and the school of nautical studies.

I pay particular tribute to the work of the Council, which has served the college very well. In particular, I make special mention of Mr Fred Connell, the Chairman of the Council. I have known Mr Connell for many years, mainly through his interests in fishing in Western Australia and his membership of the Australian Fishing Industry Council. He has done enormously valuable work for the college. His dedication is illustrated by the fact that he travels to and from the college from Geraldton in Western Australia, which is not a small task in itself. I think the dedication that has been shown by Mr Connell and the Council should be noted and appreciated by all.

The college continues to grow. The report points out the fact that there is now a staff of 135 and 566 permanent students. The college produces a range of courses in all three areas and has produced excellent graduation results. There are 23 full courses. As of last year there were 35 short courses which operated over 35 sessions with 886 participants. One of the interesting areas in the college has its operating company, AMC Search Ltd, which now manages maritime technology contracts. I notice in the report that it includes work done in the development of a mechanical minesweeping device for the Royal Australian Navy (RAN). It also did work on the testing of a design of a 16-metre transitional speed motor yacht. In another RAN project it undertook a survey of Australian based fishing vessels and compiled a computer database on those. It also provides teaching experience for staff of maritime colleges in developing countries and short course programs for fishing industry personnel in these countries. The work that has been done has been greatly appreciated all over.

I mentioned the work done by the research operation. The report also lists a complete schedule of the work that the college did in approximately 15 different areas. The work in that search area is growing. It is producing overseas capital. It is making valuable contracts in many of the countries that we need to be in close touch with. I am sure that the development can proceed. Australia is a natural maritime nation. We have a role to play in the whole of the western area of the Pacific. We now have graduates who are demonstrating their skills very widely. We look forward to an ever-improving future for the Australian Maritime College. In light of the comments of one of my colleagues, the college welcomes parliamentary visitors. I suggest that when members of the Parliament are visiting lovely Tasmania they call on the Maritime College.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that the existence of a special purpose institution to train merchant mariners had its beginnings in a 1973 commission of inquiry under Mr M. M. Summers. The then Whitlam Government accepted the commissioner's advice that training for the fishing and shipping sector was inadequate and that a comprehensive maritime college be established. In 1976 a preliminary Act became law under the Fraser Government and in 1978 the Australian Maritime College Act was passed which provided for an autonomous national institution of marine education. It is important to note that the intention of the independent commission and of both the Whitlam and Fraser governments was that the Australian Maritime College be autonomous and of high quality. To that end, almost $40m has been spent to develop the twin campuses of the college on each side of the River Tamar at Newnham and at Beauty Point.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned that the recent pronouncements by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, regarding higher education have totally compromised the Australian Maritime College and could destroy its integrity as a specialist national institution. In fact, the college has been ordered by Mr Dawkins to enter into discussions with the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology (TSIT) and the University of Tasmania with a view to the amalgamation of the three institutions. I am not blindly opposed to tertiary amalgamation in general. My point is that the people who should decide whether or not it takes place are the members of the relevant councils and staff of the tertiary bodies. The Australian Maritime College is a specific purpose college and has close links, as Senator Archer has said, with the fishing and shipping industries. The Government should be aware that the shipping industry has said that it supports the Maritime College only because it is a national institution specifically dedicated to that field and that it would hold grave fears for the college if the amalgamation, which comprised the basis of the Australian Maritime College, was forced. It is essential that the finance and governance of the Australian Maritime College remain separate even if there is to be some merging in other aspects with the TSIT and the University of Tasmania. I know that shipping and fishing industry groups have already written to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), and Mr Dawkins, strongly making these points.

What is not always appreciated in the Canberra bureaucracy is that the Maritime College cannot be directly equated with other tertiary institutions because its courses range from basic marine apprenticeships to post-graduate degrees in shipping and fishing fields. We have already seen the divisions that are emerging with the mooted amalgamations in Armidale and Canberra. I am fearful that this battering ram approach by the Education Minister could also be applied to the Australian Maritime College. I note that the Government already has the power to appoint 12 of the 22 members of the council, two of whom are the chairman and the deputy chairman. The forum for discussion of the future of the college is the college council, not a ministerial directive to the principal. If the reports of Mr Dawkins's directive are true, then it indicates to me serious doubts about the Hawke Government's attitude towards the vital question of academic independence.

It is worth noting that the Australian Maritime College is a truly national entity even though it is situated in Launceston. Only 12 per cent of its students come from Tasmania. The rest come from each State and Territory across the country and even from overseas. In 1986 the number of overseas students studying at the college was 39. I notice from the figures in the report that this year it has increased to 69, showing the growing interest from overseas countries in the courses offered. I also noted that the number of students enrolled in short courses has significantly increased, by about 60, since the 1986 report was presented to the Senate. These courses are designed to supplement areas of knowledge for people already assigned to ships or involved in shipping. They also provide groundwork in other areas such as first aid at sea and proficiency in survival craft.

The continued growth and development of study courses specifically related to industry needs is to be commended, as is the dedication of the Council and staff. The college is involved in a wide range of teaching experience programs of maritime colleges in developing countries, particularly in South East Asia and the South Pacific region. College staff have been involved with many research and development activities and their work is to be commended.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I ask you, Mr Deputy President: How can the meteorology division be siphoned off into the Department of Administrative Services? What an absolutely ratbag operation this is to wind up with an institution of this nature shovelled into Administrative Services. Out of sight, out of mind. There is no logic, no sense, no relationship whatsoever in shuffling off the meteorology people into the hands of Administrative Services where, I suggest, the Government hopes they will be lost. We are more affected by weather and the effects of weather than any other continent in the world. Very solid action is absolutely essential.

The situation in meteorology has been degenerating for some years. When I look at the excellent staff that the Bureau of Meteorology has and the responsibilities we place upon them, it is really appalling. Dr Zillman, the head of staff, is a first class operator. He has certainly been as loyal as anybody can possibly be within the constraints that have been placed upon him. I read the press statement put out by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) yesterday. I thought I must have read the wrong statement because it did not really relate to the report at all. The Bureau of Meteorology is operating against totally unreasonable odds, but it is very cost effective in spite of the constraints placed upon it. With reasonable equipment it could do ever so much better. The money that is being spent could produce a lot more if we looked after it properly.

At present all we face are forecasts that are less accurate than we would like to see both in the short and long term. Over the years there have been requests and pleas, and for what? I understand that this year there is to be some dribble of extra finance, but that will not do anything towards getting the equipment and the facilities generally up to date. For an annual report it is quite extraordinary to see the list of requests and recommendations that it contains. Page 2 of the report notes:
the achievements of the Bureau . . . and, in particular, the good start that has been made on accelerating the Bureau's capital requirement program . . .
the importance of sustaining the re-equipment and warning service upgrade programs . . .
The Committee's concern that pressures for increased cost recovery . . .

And so it continues. The report outlined all the things that have to be worked out by the Government, what it is prepared to fund and what it expects to get from the Bureau. There are enormous pressures in terms of cost recovery. While we believe in cost recovery, we do not see how it can be achieved with a meteorology department. Page 18 of the report states:

. . . the Committee believes it is also important to identify clearly those basic services which, under its Charter, the Bureau is required to provide in the public interest and for which the most efficient and equitable method of funding is through normal budget appropriations.

We need to be able to determine what we expect of this organisation and we need to know what the people of Australia expect in meteorology, because they are certainly not getting much now. Over and over again the report talks about the shortage of high-speed computer equipment. We are in a deplorable situation. A graph in the report shows our position relative to West Germany, the United Kingdom, Canada, India, Japan, and the United States. We just do not figure in any comparable way whatsoever; yet we expect more from meteorology. Do we want reasonable forecasting? Do we believe that that comes without cost? Is weather forecasting regarded as being important in Australia? Can we determine what, in the public interest, we can reasonably expect and what we must do without?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The final report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on coastal shipping is a scathing indictment of Australia's shipping and stevedoring industries. The draft report, when it was issued, brought forth a scathing attack from the then Minister responsible for shipping-Senator Robert Ray-and a less stern rebuke from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Anne Davies wrote in the Australian Financial Review of 8 September:

The Government's reaction raised questions about its intestinal fortitude in taking on the more difficult areas of micro-economic reform, of which shipping and the waterfront are probably the most crucial.

Without a shadow of a doubt, the most critical question confronting Australia today is that of shipping and the waterfront. Australia is an island continent with a great trading economy. We should have one of the great merchant navies in the world; yet our coastal shipping has declined because of inefficiency, featherbedding and all the other restrictive work practices that have grown up over a number of years.

I was visited by members of the Seamen's Union of Australia for whom I have some sympathy. They asked that we consider doing everything we can to restore coastal shipping. I pointed out that they had a long way to go-not because of their actions but because of the actions of people who have represented them over the past 10, 15 or 20 years. Those people destroyed Australia's coastal shipping industry to the extent that it is used only when it is absolutely necessary to do so; for instance, for the transportation of goods between the mainland and Tasmania and around the coast when there is no alternative mode of transport.

The report states, among other things, that the reduced manning levels are a significant improvement on past Australian standards. That is correct. However, we are still behind the practices that exist in other maritime countries with similar standards of living. Honourable senators will know that our crewing costs are higher, for instance, because of generous leave provisions. The IAC found that Australian ships need to employ 2.2 crew per berth to maintain a year-round crew, compared with 1 1/2 per berth for west European vessels. Even the tugs have similar crewing conditions, particularly those which have to go across an artificial line which is called open sea. For instance, if a tug goes from Sydney Harbour to Botany Bay once a year the vessel has to be built with full accommodation facilities. If a tug has to go from Mackay to Hay Point in Queensland-there is an artificial boundary from Mackay Harbour to Hay Point Harbour; a small piece of open sea-it has to be classified as an open seagoing vessel with all the conditions that apply to vessels that ply the international trade.

The report referred to the most serious problem facing the industry and I drew it to the attention of the men from the Seamen's Union; that is, onshore costs. It is appropriate that several reports have been placed before us one after another; for instance, that of the Inter-State Commission, this coastal shipping report and another IAC report. Mr Deputy President, in the last Parliament you introduced a Bill that sought to take away what is called cabotage; that is, the total reservation of Australian shipping to Australian ships and Australian crews. I suspect that the only way we will do something about shipping in Australia and the coastal trade is to introduce a bit of competition into it.
