Since the period covered by this Christmas Island Services Corporation annual report, there have been many fundamental changes to the administration of Christmas Island, changes which make this report obsolete and somewhat irrelevant. The Christmas Island Assembly, set up by this Government as an elected body to act on the wishes of the Christmas Island community and as the body responsible for the running of Christmas Island, was dissolved on 3 November 1987 and an Administrator and temporary manager were appointed in its stead. There is no sign of democracy being re-established on Christmas Island. So much for one vote one value and fair and democratic elections.

The main income earning industry for the island, the phosphate mine, was closed in November 1987. The Government, at the Opposition's prompting after the outrage felt by Christmas Islanders, was forced reluctantly to call for expressions of interest in future mining operations. The Government set conditions that it would no longer subsidise many of the service functions of the Christmas Island Services Corporation. The Government appointed a liquidator/assessor and chose Elders Resources Finance Ltd which said that it would provide 40 to 50 jobs. After reports which suggested that the original intention by Elders was to fly workers in from Australia, the company then agreed to use Christmas Islanders. The assessment process continued to be questioned as Elders leading rival bidder, Century Metals and Mining, had promised 189 people jobs. Moreover, it had the support of a large number of Christmas Islanders. Century Mining subsequently challenged the whole assessment procedure by asking for a judicial review of the decision. Legal argument was put before the Federal Court of Australia in Perth. Yesterday Justice French reserved his decision, to be handed down within seven days.

My predecessor as shadow Minister for Territories, Mr Ray Braithwaite, has attacked the Government for refusing to permit scrutiny of the processes involved in choosing a successor mining operation for Christmas Island. External territories failed to fulfil two freedom of information requests within the specified period and only belatedly complied once a complaint was lodged. Elders has recently expressed doubts about the viability of proceeding. I hope that it does not withdraw. Christmas Island now has a new Minister, the Hon. Clyde Holding. It is hoped that he makes more progress than his predecessor, Mr Punch, who in his six-month period made absolutely no tangible progress in establishing a successor mining operation on the island. Negotiations are still in limbo. There is very little employment there at the moment.

This Government's handling of Christmas Island concerning the period before, during and after the time of this report has been characterised by inexcusable delays, turnabouts and a lack of understanding of Christmas Island's resources and needs; and, most importantly, the Government has not shown itself to be open and above board in its dealings. As the shadow Minister for this portfolio, I urge this Government to keep on its toes and act in the best interests of the Christmas Islanders.

The Government certainly appears to be holding an axe over higher education in the Australian Capital Territory, particularly over the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). I think it is most unfortunate that the Government has abolished the semi-independent Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and that this body, the Canberra College of Advanced Education, has to provide an educational profile and deal and negotiate directly with the Government. Now we have an example of the Government seeking to intervene in the manage- ment of the college, in fact of all universities and colleges, many of which fall under the responsibility of the States.

I believe the Federal Government must be strongly condemned for threatening to stop funding to tertiary education institutions unless they conform to certain criteria. Mr Dawkins has said that universities must have at least 8,000 students and colleges of advanced education must have at least 5,000. These figures are purely arbitrary and could lead to efficient regional colleges being closed down. At a time when the Hawke Government proclaims better access to education, the realities of its policy are quite the opposite. This is just another example of the Government's attitude to education being based solely on cost-benefit terms, and I believe it is not in the best interests of students. I believe few of the students who will be graduating from the Canberra College of Advanced Education will realise that the graduate tax, which was announced in the Federal Budget, is actually indexed for life, and those CCAE students who will be paying it off may never know the final amount until they have paid their very last instalment.

Young women in particular from this college will be disadvantaged because when they leave the work force soon after graduation to have their families and subsequently go back to work the inflation factor will have continued to accrue even though they were not earning. I think this is reprehensible and it could well result in a frighteningly big surcharge on the original amount that a graduate from this college must have to budget to repay.

The Government has also instructed this institution and others to provide individual enrolment information, which is fed into the Australian Taxation Office computer network four or five years in advance of its need in expectation of future tax liabilities. Here is another area which is tantamount to a tax file number type syndrome, with a central register recording information on all the students across Australia. Even though students from this college may receive a discount, as with all similar CAEs and universities, there is supposed to be a sweetener of 15 per cent if this graduate tax is paid off during studies. Unfortunately this discount is completely withheld even if only a small amount of the repayment is deferred. It makes no allowance for people who are attempting to pay it off as they are studying but who do not have the financial resources to note the final payment before finishing studies.

The Government must act immediately to resolve these sorts of inequities because they only increase the burden of the already unpopular, ill-conceived and regressive graduate tax. I believe that the decisions that are being made by the Government will have a regressive effect on education. It is reprehensible that this important issue is being considered purely in cost-benefit terms. It is unfortunate that, under the proposal, if this institution is judged to be overfunded it will have to seek and take on many more students. The emphasis now appears to be on quantity rather than quality of education, particularly in the Canberra College of Advanced Education. It is a reprehensible move.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator CRICHTON-BROWNE (Western Australia) (5.36) I move:
That the Senate-
(a) welcomes naval vessels from around the world which have come to take part in an international Naval Review in order to share in Australia's bicentennial celebrations;

(b) expresses the hope and desire that this Review will promote greater goodwill and understanding amongst naval nations and will reflect and support Australia's aim of fostering lasting world peace; and

(c) acknowledges that peace can only occur through security and, therefore, supports the continued development and maintenance of a strong navy, for both Australia and our allies, which is able to meet the future needs of not only the Australian nation, but also that of the western alliance.

I say as I commence my comments that it is predictable, but again disappointing, that we find that the one senator who purports to represent a group of people in the community who themselves purport to have a mortgage on peace is again not in the chamber. It seems to be the habit of Senator Vallentine, whenever there is debate on motions such as this or legislation such as the South Pacific nuclear free zone legislation, not to be here. She is not here again today. I do not know whether she is in the building. Presumably, if she is, she is in her room scribbling anti-American notes to herself. The truth of the matter is that she is never here to express the views of those she purports to represent. I notice that her name is somewhere-I think eighth-on the speakers' list. There are to be 11 speakers in an hour and a half of debate. Senator Vallentine finally struggled to put her name eighth on the list, which means that she will not get a chance to speak on this matter today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could be shorter in your remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate is quite right. I could be shorter in my remarks, but if I spoke for only five minutes and not 35 minutes Senator Vallentine would still not get to speak today, because she is eighth on the list. —What about Senator Dunn?

—The second XI has just arrived carrying the drinks-yes, so it is. I take particular pleasure in welcoming the naval warships from around the world which have come to our bicentennial celebrations and to take part in the international naval review. It was with pleasure that I recently accepted an invitation from the United States Navy to sail from Cockburn Sound to Albany in Western Australia on the United States battleship New Jersey. It was a pleasure to respond to the United States Navy's hospitality.
—A bit of a risk, though.

—It was no risk. How could anyone feel at risk on a 58,000-tonne battleship equipped with Tomahawk sea-launched cruise missiles, with 16-inch guns capable of hitting a Volkswagen at 23 miles, and with Harpoon weapons?
—I feel safer already.

—Absolutely. The battleship is equipped with the sort of gunnery that the Americans, as our allies, offer to us as part of our defence alliance. The only sour note on that very pleasant two-day and one night voyage was learning, as we steamed south, that there had been an incident in Albany. The USS Brewton, another United States ship, was in Albany at the invitation of the Albany residents. As honourable senators can imagine, the ship was well received. There were literally hundreds of people visiting the ship every day, enjoying the hospitality and the pleasure of the company of the American Navy. But, of course, things had to be disrupted. One of those grotty, smelly, long-haired people who purport to stand for peace-as long as it is their peace and nobody else's-came aboard, climbed the mast of the ship, tied himself to the ship and totally disrupted everybody else's day.

SPEECH.PARA: If that were not bad enough, on the second day there was an incident in which two protesters illegally sought to gain entry to the ship. The captain of the ship, to preserve the integrity and safety of his ship, gently sprayed a bit of salt water on the protesters. What did we see? We saw Senator Vallentine flying down to Albany, not to apologise to the United States Navy for the conduct of some of her more loutish supporters, not to apologise on behalf of decent Australians for the conduct of a couple of ratbags: no, she went aboard the ship and demanded an apology from the captain because he put the water hose on the protesters. Can you believe it? When the captain of the ship quite properly told her that he had nothing to apologise for, Senator Vallentine then wrote to the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, and demanded action against the captain of the ship, for goodness sake! I think that the great offence of the captain was that he gave these guys a bath for once in a month. Can you believe it-a member of the Australian Senate conducting herself in that way in the name of peace?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you are verging on criticising Senator Vallentine. This motion is not critical of Senator Vallentine. In order for you to do that you have to have a substantive motion to that effect.
—Mr Deputy President, you are quite right. If I am verging, I am doing it badly.
—If you do it any better I shall have to call you to order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I have to say that it is a sad day for Australia when the Americans, as allies, cannot come to this country without being disrupted and harassed by a small group of ratbags. Can honourable senators imagine the reaction of one of these ratbags if an American sailor who had climbed through his window then departed and rang the American consul to complain because somebody had hosed him down? The logic is absolutely absurd. It is symptomatic of those who pretend that they are for peace-it is peace for themselves and nobody else. SPEECH.PARA: One ought to note that the person who is to take the salute for the review, His Royal Highness the Duke of York, who is on one of the British ships, will also be subject to a protest, as was the Ark Royal. We ought to understand the effect of these protesters. Let me give an example relating to the New Jersey. The New Jersey steaming at 18 knots takes three miles in full reverse to stop. It has no steering at less than 12 knots, so when it gets into the Heads at Sydney and has these protesters--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not doing 18 knots when it goes through Sydney Heads, surely?

—No, I did not say that. I said that it has very little steering at under 12 knots. It is very difficult for the ship to manoeuvre. There is a very small response on the rudder. —You cannot be in favour of peace if you want the boats to run people down.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an interesting observation that it is those who claim peace that most often disrupt the peace of others. When they say peace, they mean peace for themselves but disruption for everybody else. When they talk about their intrinsic rights as Australian citizens they mean rights without responsibilities. When they talk about passive protest, they really mean specific infringement upon the rights of others. When they talk about tolerance for them, they are talking about intrusion into the rights of other people. It means, for them, acting above the law and trampling on the rights of other people. One can only speculate about the reasons, but it demonstrates the arrogance, and perhaps, sadly, the ignorance, of those who think their will, their right, is special and unique and superimposes itself upon anybody else's. —I still oppose it; but I had a voice and I had a vote. Senator Vallentine was in New Zealand, causing trouble with the rabble over there. If she is not there, she is in the United States; or if she is not there, she is in the Western Australian Parliament causing trouble, or she is in gaol in the Northern Territory somewhere.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne is infringing again in regard to Senator Vallentine.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The truth of the matter is that in the case of the INF there was an opportunity for these people to speak. In that case we saw the benefit and the effects of peace through strength. We all know that, in 1977, west of the Urals the Soviets had most of the SS20s and they would do nothing about moving them, notwithstanding requests from the Americans and their Western allies. It was only after the Americans and Western Europe deployed the Cruise and Pershing II missiles that we saw the beginning of peace.
—Really?

—Yes, the two-track system-by negotiation and a threat of locating the Pershing II missiles. The Soviets then came to the peace table, because they suddenly found that although they had SS20s that could strike into West Germany in 20 minutes of flying time, we had the Pershing II, which could fly into Soviet Union airspace in four minutes with a 550-kiloton warhead. That is peace through strength. We suddenly found the benefit of deploying Pershing II missiles at Greenham Common, where all the lesbians and all the troublemakers and all the protesters had been before. Suddenly we saw the benefit, did we not? Of course we did. What was said about that? Not a word. No mea culpa. Absolute silence-which is the way of the peace group. They do not want peace. They want Soviet superiority.
—How did you know they were lesbians?

—If you want to know whether they were lesbians, ask Senator Tate. He has had a personal experience, on the lawn outside Parliament House. Let me say that one should not be confused by the Soviets' recent apparent change in foreign policy. It is purely pragmatic. It is purely driven by economic necessity. We have seen their withdrawal from Mongolia, the withdrawal of troops from the Sino-Soviet border, and the withdrawal of troops from Kampuchea and Afghanistan. We have heard talk of the early commencement of the strategic arms reduction talks (START). All of this is not because we have a born-again libertarian Gorbachev who has recognised all the sins and all the failings of the political system of which he is a creature, but simply because the Soviets understand that one cannot be a first-class world military power and at the same time have a Third World economy. One of the reasons that I, for my money, always supported the strategic defence initiative (SDI) was that it was a whip hand to ensure that the Soviets came to the negotiating table on a whole range of other things. The Soviets are in a real dilemma. They could not afford to compete with SDI. They could not risk it failing or succeeding. They understood, when the peasants in this country could not, that it was going to provide enormous technology for the American economy and the American community. It was going to make them economically much stronger than they already are. The Soviets understood that.
—Which peasants are you talking about?

—What is the expression about the cap fitting? The truth of the matter is that the only way the Soviets can continue as a first-class military power is to have a strong economy. That is why they are now prepared to negotiate on these defence matters, as Senator Schacht will accept and acknowledge. If they do not, they cannot continue to compete and they cannot continue to be the dominant force that they are as a world military power. The question we have to ask ourselves is whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. Do we want a strong Soviet Union or a weak Soviet Union?
—What do you want?

—I want a strong Soviet Union. The only way it will be strong is by being part of world trade. There is no question that that will be to the benefit of all the world. I will come back to our own region for a moment. I am reminded of what Paul Dibb said just two short years ago-I think in March 1986. Let us remember his view:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's area of primary strategic concern-South East Asia and the South West Pacific-is one of the most stable regions in the world.

He did not give evidence to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. He could not have been further from the truth. I do not expect that he should have known what would happen, but if one reflects upon it with 20-20 vision, given their types of economies, their isolation and their vulnerability, I suppose the potential was always there. In the last 18 months in that so-called region of security and stability we have seen two coups in Fiji, civil violence in New Caledonia, political unrest in Vanuatu, and a signalling of intent by Libya to exert a greater influence than it already does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Couldn't you get a better bogyman than Libya?

—I am so sorry, but Senator Sanders, as he is on all his subjects, is with the fairies. He ought to go back and tilt at his windmills again or peddle his water power. It is significant that Vanuatu broke off its discussions with the Libyans on the issue of establishing diplomatic relations. I think it is realistic to say that it was primarily as a result of the exerting of influence by New Zealand and Australia. Without doubt, the strategic situation within our sphere of relative influence is deteriorating. Our relations with Fiji, as the last few weeks have shown, are at rock bottom.
—Look who has turned up.

—I am as pleased as anybody to see Senator Vallentine here. But of course it is like all these things: she is too late to fire a shot. She is a passive traveller again, sitting here and observing the events that are going past her. It is very sad, is it not? I am glad that I do not know anybody who voted for her because they sure got robbed.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you are again transgressing.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Surely that is regarded as reflecting upon the character and integrity of a senator.

—I have just ordered Senator Crichton-Browne to desist from that line of speech. You have the call, Senator Crichton-Browne, but you must not involve yourself in personal criticism of another senator.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. What causes more alarm than our deteriorating relationship with Fiji is that this deterioration is occurring at a time when the Soviet Union is quite openly expressing an intention of expanding its role in the Pacific region. In his Vladivostok speech--
—How do you connect the two, though?

—I can understand why Senator Sanders cannot connect the two. Unfortunately, he is stuck with a thought process that runs on only one line at a time. But if he reads my speech afterwards he will probably be able to draw it together in the darkness, lying on his couch. In his Vladivostok speech on 28 July 1986, Gorbachev made it quite plain that the Soviet Union is an Asian and Pacific country. Gorbachev was formally declaring the Soviet belief that it has a legitimate role in the entire Asian-Pacific region. I will not comment upon whether it is legitimate to put that proposition or not. But the truth is--
—The Soviet Union has a Pacific coastline; you have a Reader's Digest atlas.

—Sadly, I do not, but Senator Schacht can send me a copy of what he has read. The truth is that the Soviets are here. It is even more explicit when Gorbachev says that he wishes to expand ties with member nations of the South Pacific Forum.
—What is wrong with that?

—If Senator Sanders can just draw breath and wait, it will come to him-I promise. These ties are reflected in the Soviets' drive to negotiate fishing agreements with Pacific islands, the first agreement being with Kiribati in August, I think, of 1985.
—How long did it last?

—It was withdrawn but 12 months later, I think, in mid-1986; but then the Soviets proceeded to conclude a similar agreement with Vanuatu in January of 1987. When they negotiated these agreements the Soviets sought, and one can understand it, port facilities and landing rights for Aeroflot, in the case of Vanuatu. Such rights and such access are important to the Soviets in their efforts to establish and maintain a presence and an influence in the region. It is not without significance for us to note that they have made overtures to Papua New Guinea in respect of fishing agreements. Further evidence of Moscow's wish to expand relations in the Asian-Pacific region can be found in the visit last year by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, to Australia, Thailand and Indonesia. It is significant in its timing because it is the first time, if I am correct, that a Soviet Foreign Minister has visited Australia.
—Did you oppose that visit?
—Of course not. Why should I?
—You have been giving them a belting for 20 minutes.
—No, I have not. I have not given them a belting; I am putting their position. We need to understand it.
—Some of those wheat farmers in Western Australia who vote for you don't mind their wheat going to Russia.
—Why does Senator Schacht always imagine that, because I talk about the Soviets, I am saying it is wrong. I am putting it to honourable senators as it is.
—But you are frothing at the mouth when you do it.

—No, I am not frothing at the mouth. I accept that the Soviets are trying to destabilise our relations with Japan, they are trying to uncouple our relations with America and New Zealand, and they are trying to destabilise our relations in the South Pacific. If Senator Schacht says that that is not right, he should put his hand up so that we can all see him. There is not a hand to be seen, is there? I do not think the Foreign Minister has been to Indonesia since Suharto took power in the 1960s. The Soviets are seeking to exert greater influence, not only for economic reasons but also for defence reasons. In their case it cannot be argued that the two are necessarily coupled; of course they are not. During his visit to Australia, Shevardnadze is reported to have said that the Soviets were seeking to gain political influence through their fisheries agreements. They were hoping this would lead to normal commercial, cultural and sporting contacts.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a significant strategic advantage for the Soviets to be able to conclude fishing agreements. That comes about-I hope that even the Australian Democrats would accept this-because the Soviet fishing fleet is simply an extension of the Soviet naval effort. The Soviet presence in the Asian-Pacific region is not limited in its efforts to developing commercial fishing agreements in the South Pacific. For instance, in return for essential Soviet support since 1979, Vietnam has allowed the build-up in Cam Ranh Bay of the biggest naval base, I think, outside the Soviet Union. I am having an argument with my colleague as to whether Aden in South Yemen is larger. Whatever, it is a very large presence. This allows the Soviet Union to exert both a political and a military influence in the region. Because of Australia's position within the Asian-Pacific Basin, there is no doubt that we ought to have a major role to play in maintaining the stability and security of the region.

I am overcome by time, but let me conclude by saying that we have a two-pronged approach to our defence capability-our own reliance and that of alliance. To think otherwise is to be intellectually very crude. It is an absolute imperative. The bringing of naval forces to Australia is, again, a reflection of our commitment to our alliances with the Americans, the British and others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Soviet navy can come along for the visit.

—Well, the Soviet navy does not have a ship here but it surely has rocket launchers and it surely has missile launchers sitting on the Indian aircraft carrier that is lying in the harbour. One should not imagine that the Soviets do not have a presence of some sort here. I believe that all Australians support the presence of the naval forces, the naval tasks, which have come here to participate with us, at our invitation, in our bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a motion from Senator Crichton-Browne that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . welcomes naval vessels from around the world which have come to take part in an international Naval Review in order to share in Australia's bicentennial celebrations;
expresses the hope and desire that this Review will promote greater goodwill and understanding amongst naval nations and will reflect and support Australia's aim of fostering lasting world peace; and
acknowledges that peace can only occur through security . . .

The international naval review might reassure some people. I am certain that this visit has been successful in the terms of the motion. I think we should be thankful to have Senator Crichton-Browne in the Senate and that he is not Admiral of the Fleet because there is a danger that he and other people would be a threat under certain circumstances. Be that as it may, and although I think the motion is not serious in itself, it raises for any thinking person a very serious issue. We must look at the deeper issues that arise when naval ships of this type come to Australia. They remind us of the need to be concerned about the way we are going and the way the world is going, particularly with the development in the Pacific and Indian oceans of a naval arms race of alarming proportions. More attention, in a sober way, should be given to this problem. While `pacific' means peace, in recent years the United States and the Soviet Union have repeatedly accused each other of relentlessly expanding and modernising their military forces and presence in the Pacific region.

Amitav Acharya, a research fellow at the Institute of South-East Asian Studies, has written about the military balance in the Pacific. Table 6, which gives details of the Pacific naval balance, is included in his article entitled `The United States Versus the USSR in the Pacific: Trends in the Military Balance'. This article was published in the Contemporary Southeast Asia journal of March 1988. I seek leave to have this table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The article concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: The US strategy in the Pacific is focused on a vigorous build up of its Pacific fleet as part of a markedly offensive naval war fighting strategy aimed at ensuring the `containment' of the Soviet naval power at its source in the northern Pacific . . . the superpower military balance in the Pacific will continue to favour the United States for the foreseeable future.

I believe that that is a fairly accurate assessment of the situation. We must ensure that in this area every effort is made to bring the superpowers to the conference table. The Australian Government has been very active at disarmament negotiations in the world forums. These efforts are recognised outside of Australia-and I refer to that specifically because, unfortunately, many Australians do not realise the good favour that Australia has for its role in nuclear disarmament negotiations. Like Senator Crichton-Browne, I have been to the United States and the Soviet Union this year. I am certain that the Australian Government has a very high reputation. Of course, the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty has encouraged confidence that new steps are possible in nuclear disarmament. I believe that the examination of nuclear disarmament requires that special attention now must be given to the critical role of naval warfare in the nuclear context. I was going to refer very briefly to the peace movement, but I feel that I have got to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them a serve.

—No, I will not give those people a serve because I know them too well. I appreciate the peace movement as a mass movement of ordinary Australians, comprising a cross-section of our society. It cannot be described as a movement supported by Soviet funds, as Senator Crichton-Browne would have us believe. I have no doubt that among the hundreds of thousands of people who participate in the Palm Sunday rally there would be someone who is sympathetic to the Soviet point of view. There is no question about that. However, I want to put on the record here, and even bring the voice of the peace movement into this chamber, if I can, by indicating that hundreds of thousands of Australians are involved-people with differing views, some of whom would not necessarily agree with me. They have different approaches as to how the problem can be solved. Many of them are very sober and sensible people trying to find a solution.
—All of us want peace-they do not have a monopoly.

—Yes, but they have been attacked by Senator Crichton-Browne as being idiots and fools, and stooges of the Soviet Union, to coin a phrase. I have had some experience of this movement in my home city. I have seen it grow in the past decade. I have been involved as the convener of the nuclear disarmament coordinating committee, which is an umbrella organisation that facilitates the bringing together of the various organisations. I want to express the views of that committee, because only recently at its annual general meeting it adopted a theme for the next Palm Sunday rally, to be held in Sydney-and that is `Disarm the seas'. That was adopted as a concept for the next Palm Sunday rally.
—I suppose we will see them at Vladivostok.

—Senator Crichton-Browne cannot help himself; he has got to believe that the whole thing is a communist plot. Having regard to the fact that 90,000 people marched in a rally in Sydney this year, I defy anybody to believe that these people are communist agents, stooges of the communists, or anything else. Of course, every imaginable slogan is expressed in that mass movement of people.
—All the people in this chamber are in favour of peace-no-one has a monopoly on it.

—That is very good, and I certainly hope that that is the case. I know that the all-party committees on disarmament have had very successful meetings. That is fine, and I certainly hope that that activity continues. However, I want to take up the challenge for ordinary people-not the experts, not politicians and not people who are favoured in society-to express their concern. And they do. In particular, once a year some 100,000 people come out to express their views-and there are many different views. I am getting excited like Senator Crichton-Browne and I am getting off the point, and I will take longer than I mean to if I go into too much detail. However, ordinary people at various levels are expressing a view. For example, in adopting a slogan such as `Disarm the seas', some of them will understand that at a very superficial level, seeing it as just something they want to achieve, but many others will now start to work at solving the problem. As Australia is surrounded by the seas, particularly the Indian and Pacific oceans, that is the way that the peace movement is going. It is not an organisation with only one voice-and that is the point I am making. In berating the peace movement, Senator Crichton-Browne is just showing how ignorant he is of the movement that he is attacking.

SPEECH.PARA: I intended to spend some time drawing attention to another matter which is thrown up by the visits of warships to our shores, particularly to Sydney Harbour. I am aware of the work that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is doing in conducting its inquiry into the adequacy of current contingency planning by Federal and State authorities to deal with the accidental release of ionising radiation from visiting nuclear-powered or armed vessels in Australian waters and ports. I look forward to the report because I am very concerned about the danger, no matter how unlikely a nuclear accident in Sydney Harbour may be. There will be a danger in other ports or harbours, but I confine my remarks to Sydney Harbour. Senator Robert Ray indicated in response to a question asked this week during Question Time that the Government had at an embryo stage plans regarding nuclear-capable ships. He indicated in his reply that the Government is looking at plans similar to the proposals for nuclear-powered warships.

I express some concern about the dangers that exist, no matter how remote. I am informed that there is a 10,000 to one chance of an accident per year. That is the order of the threat. A Lloyds of London analysis shows that, for ships over 7,000 tonnes, 30 per cent of accidents occur in rivers and harbours, more than 50 per cent in coastal waters and only 10 per cent on the high seas over 25 miles from the coast. When we consider the danger of terrorism, sabotage or a whole range of other things which we do not normally think of, we realise that we have a problem.

In Sydney Harbour, in the case of a nuclear accident a safe berth would be a remote berth. Unfortunately all the planning has been done on the basis of what can be done in four hours. The reality is that the child thyroid dose limit is 150 rems. That limit would be reached in two hours in the worst sort of example. The only base which would have the minimum safety requirement of a five-kilometre radius would be Jervis Bay. So there are a great number of problems associated with Sydney Harbour.

I do not want to take all of the time to which I am entitled. However, I should point out that the three major berths in Sydney Harbour are the oil wharf at Garden Island, No. 2 Naval Buoy and Athol Bight dolphins. Within the danger area surrounding at least two of these berths-Garden Island and No. 2 Naval Buoy-are 40 schools, a number of hospitals and child-care places and establishments. So the problem is immense in terms of evacuating these areas should an accident occur. I think most people know the Elizabeth Bay area in Sydney in which Garden Island is located. When we consider that half a million people work and live in the central business district of Sydney and that the prevailing winds are from the north and east for 50 per cent of the time, we can see the real danger that accidents on nuclear-powered, armed or capable ships present to the population of Sydney.

I could make out an argument in some detail of the dangers that exist. I think the other side of the issue is the concern that people have about their harbour. Many people-and this happened this week-have expressed a genuine concern for the harbour. Even more importantly, they have a genuine concern for life. They are genuine in their desire not only to make a symbolic protest about nuclear-capable warships but also to express their concern that nuclear-powered ships should not come into our harbour. Other countries which do not allow nuclear-powered ships to enter their harbours are just as loyal as Australia is to the United States alliance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing Senator Crichton-Browne's motion, I would like to begin by asking the honourable senator a rhetorical question. If he really believes that deploying nuclear missiles encourages disarmament, as he claims has occurred in Europe, does he believe that Australia should obtain nuclear weapons and deploy them in Darwin to encourage peaceful relations with Indonesia? I do not really expect a reply from the honourable senator. I would like to let him know that not everyone welcomes naval vessels to Australian ports and certainly not everyone welcomes nuclear-armed vessels to our ports. Not everyone welcomes the idea of about 200 Hiroshimas floating into Sydney Harbour this week for the naval salute.

SPEECH.PARA: The public opinion poll conducted by the international market research company, Frank Small and Associates, has shown that those Australians who do have an opinion are about two to one against the visits of nuclear-armed ships. There are very good reasons for their opposition to the visits of these vessels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite you to get in the queue. You will be a week getting onto the ships.

—I have already been on board some of the ships. I received hospitality from the American captain of the Ingersoll and his crew. I am certainly not anti-American by any means. But I am very much opposed to nuclear weapons. I am not funded by the Soviets; I am paid by the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are very good reasons why such ships should not come to this country. One of the reasons which most concern the Australian population and which should concern every responsible member of the Government of Australia is the very devastating consequence of an accident in one of our harbours. The Australian Ionizing and Radiation Advisory Council, in evidence before the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, gave evidence of the most likely scenario. Senator Childs has referred to the number of accidents which have occurred in our ports. While the likelihood is certainly remote, the consequences are so devastating that finally the Federal Government has acknowledged the necessity of planning for such an accident.

The state of planning in Australia at the moment is really dismal. In fact, it is a national scandal. Even the United States Navy acknowledges the need to plan for such an accident. About a month ago the New York City Council released a plan dealing with a nuclear-armed vessel accident in the Port of New York harbour. Who better to help the New York City Council in developing such a plan than the United States Navy because, of course, the United States Navy would know about such accidents. We do not because of the secrecy surrounding such matters.

Originally the Department of Defence told the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, of which I am a member, that there was no need to plan for such a weapons accident in Australia. Last week, when I was in Brisbane visiting the State emergency services, I was told that in fact the Department of Defence had changed its mind and had indeed prepared guidelines for such a draft plan to deal with accidents on board nuclear-armed vessels visiting Australia. This week Mr Beazley, the Minister for Defence, said in the 7.30 Report:
Accidents do not happen on board these ships that come into Australian harbours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I ask the honourable senator to complete the quotation to make it quite clear that Mr Beazley was not as confined as that quote indicates.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—As a matter of courtesy, I inform the Minister that that is the complete quote and I have the transcript with me.
—Give me the transcript. I will give the quote.

—The Minister is welcome to have it. As I said, the United States Navy certainly sees the need for planning for such an accident. I wonder whether Mr Beazley has access to more information than the United States Navy. I do not think he does. The situation in New York is identical to Sydney. There is no movement of weapons in New York harbour. There is no storage of weapons anywhere other than on the ships.
—There is no storage in Sydney Harbour.
—That is exactly what I am saying; they are on the ships. The situation is the same in New York as it is in Sydney Harbour.
—Where would you like them, my love?
—I do not think I can say.
—Do they allow nuclear-powered warships in New York harbour?

—No. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which has been examining contingency planning for accidents on board nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships visiting Australia, I am really appalled that the Department of Defence has not seen fit to give us a copy of the guidelines of this particular plan, neither has the New South Wales Government seen fit to give us the plan that it suddenly came up with this week. I do not imagine that our report can be at all comprehensive or complete without access to these particular plans. Certainly, I do not think that we will be in a position to advise the Australian Government or the Australian people of the adequacy of existing planning if we do not take these particular plans into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I wish to mention about these plans is that they are top secret. There is absolutely no reason for these plans to be secret except for the fact that they include personal phone numbers of the personnel involved in the evacuation procedures and the other emergency procedures. It is very easy to take a page out of the plan and then make that plan public-as the New York plan was made public-for full comment. It is only when all the emergency services, the unions and the public know what is contained in the plan and know what they have to do in the event of an emergency that we can really be sure of having an adequate plan. Let us take the New South Wales plan. This week Premier Greiner announced that he had such a plan but he said he was not going to release it.

Honourable senators should look at the history in New South Wales for planning to cope with such an accident. Premiers Wran and Unsworth told the Committee that there was no plan for a nuclear weapons accident. Mr Paciullo, the former Minister for Police and Emergency Services, told the New South Wales Parliament that there was a plan called Plan Point Piper to deal specifically with an accident on board a nuclear-armed vessel in Sydney Harbour. During the most recent New South Wales election the present Minister for Environment, Tim Moore, told the Parliament that the coalition Government would release the plan if elected. When it was elected the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Pickering, immediately withdrew the plan before it was made public and said that there was no need for one. Why did he withdraw it? He withdrew it because the contents were completely unsatisfactory and in no way resembled anything like an emergency plan. Last week the New South Wales Attorney-General, John Dowd, announced the existence of a plan to deal with such accidents. That too is still secret. That plan has not been given to the Committee.

With such a history in New South Wales is it any wonder that Sydney citizens feel a little apprehensive about their Government's ability to deal with an accident in Sydney Harbour? It is irresponsible of both the Federal and New South Wales governments to allow these ships into the harbour without an adequate plan in place, to allow thousands of people to go aboard these ships and to allow these ships to be tied up in berths where there is no easy access for them to be towed away. It is really irresponsible to expose so many Sydney citizens and visitors to Sydney to such a risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why they are demonstrating in their herds, rather than lining up to get on the ships and meet the visiting sailors!

—I point out to the honourable senator that while thousands may visit the ships thousands more stay at home. These ships also become nuclear targets in times of conflict. In the nuclear age we cannot and do not have the same definitions of wartime and peacetime as applied 40 or 50 years ago. With nuclear technology the lead time in firing weapons is only minutes away. A conflict in another part of the world can bring these ships into war service immediately and from that time on they can be targets. The Federal Government has recognised that there are sites in Australia which would become targets for the Soviet Union in the event of a conflict. That is why the Natural Disasters Organisation is planning for an attack on Pine Gap and Nurrungar.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, these ships could easily become nuclear targets. The Government has already recognised that the three United States bases in Australia-Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape-are possible subjects of Soviet attack and has instructed the Natural Disasters Organisation to prepare accident plans, namely, evacuation plans, in the event of attack on those three places. It must be recognised that, in a nuclear age, the lead time is so short when nuclear weapons are fired and delivered that no bases are safe. The ships fall into the same category as the bases: they will become objects of attack. They are not safe simply because the conditions under which we allow them to enter have been described as peacetime conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne's motion calls for the development and maintenance of a strong navy for both Australia and our allies. If he were in the chamber I would ask him what he means by the word `strong'. Does it really mean that we should support the rapid escalation of the nuclear arms race at sea? Does it really mean that we should support the decision by our ally, the United States, to deploy 3,994 naval Cruise missiles by 1992, including 758 nuclear missiles? Those Tomahawk Cruise missiles are aboard the United States ships, the New Jersey and the Ingersoll, which are currently in Sydney, having been invited here by the Federal Government. These missiles, and their Soviet equivalent, are currently the major obstacle to a new strategic arms control agreement. They are very difficult to verify because the nuclear and the ordinary versions of the missiles look the same. One would have to open them up in order to tell the difference.

The United States resisted negotiating limits on these sea-launched Cruise missiles. Does the Government support that position? If so, is it acting in the interests of Australia or in the interests of the United States? Surely the Government and the Opposition would not argue that everything the United States does is automatically in Australia's interests. Why do we have to accept the United States and the United Kingdom policy of `neither confirm nor deny'? Everybody knows that these ships carry nuclear weapons. Retired United States admirals have given evidence in congressional hearings in the United States that where they are nuclear-capable they will carry those weapons. United States Rear Admiral La Rocque stated:

Any ship capable of carrying nuclear weapons, carries nuclear weapons. They do not off load them when they go into foreign ports. If they are capable of carrying them, they normally keep them aboard ship at all times.

That is because it is well recognised that increased dangers will occur if these weapons are transferred from one ship to another or from ship to port. Commander Alan Robertson, formerly the captain of HMAS Melbourne-honourable senators will remember the terrible disaster in which the Melbourne was involved-acknowledged at a public meeting last Monday that these ships carry nuclear weapons. The Federal and New South Wales governments have virtually admitted that the ships are carrying nuclear weapons by preparing accident plans to deal with an accident on board. The policy of neither confirming nor denying that a ship is carrying nuclear weapons is a farce and should not be tolerated by a country which is supposedly committed to nuclear disarmament. The Government's attitude to the visits of nuclear-armed ships is symptomatic of its inability to take the hard decisions on disarmament. What does one say to a friend who brings lethal weapons to one's birthday party? One tells him to leave the weapons at home and that he will then be welcome but that, if he is not prepared to leave them at home, he is not welcome.

Although the likelihood of a nuclear accident is only very small, the consequences are devastating. In the event of such an accident with a nuclear warhead of five kilograms, a city such as Sydney would be devastated by the resulting fire and the spread of plutonium particles in the atmosphere. Professor Jackson-Davis, who gave evidence before a Senate standing committee, estimated that up to 11,000 latent cancer fatalities could occur. The only real response to such an accident is to get away from it as soon as possible. However, governments can minimise the damage by developing adequate accident plans to deal with such a tragedy. I hope that I will never be in a position to tell this chamber, `I told you so'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate, which has been moved by Senator Noel Crichton-Browne, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) welcomes naval vessels from around the world which have come to take part in an international Naval Review in order to share in Australia's bicentennial celebrations;

(b) expresses the hope and desire that this Review will promote greater goodwill and understanding amongst naval nations and will reflect and support Australia's aim of fostering lasting world peace; and

(c) acknowledges that peace can only occur through security and, therefore, supports the continued development and maintenance of a strong navy, for both Australia and our allies, which is able to meet the future needs of not only the Australian nation, but also that of the western alliance.

I have much pleasure in supporting the motion. Two honourable senators have spoken basically against the motion. The approach of Senator Childs could only be defined as an anti-United States approach. If he is against the United States it follows automatically that he is against the Western alliance. In the time that Senator Childs has been a member of this chamber, this is the first occasion on which I have heard him claim membership of and support for the peace movement. He has never talked about that before, although it is well known that he has been associated with extreme Left causes and other front organisations operating behind the peace banner. I am concerned that the peace movement is moving behind the slogan `Disarm the seas'. If there is one thing that will have a major influence on Australia's peace and security it is any move by the peace movement to restrict the growth or the deployment of sea-borne forces, because so much of the free world's trade turns on ocean passage. The ability to keep the sea lanes of communications free is absolutely fundamental to our continued survival.

Senator Dunn, a representative of the Nuclear Disarmament Party before she was expelled-I do not know which party she stands for now-opened her speech with a very silly proposition that somehow Australia should buy nuclear weapons and site them in Darwin, whereby we would have peace with Indonesia. As someone who spends quite a while in Indonesia, I do not believe that relationships with Indonesia are anywhere near that level of difficulty. I am afraid that I cannot follow the logic of siting in Darwin nuclear weapons targeted against Indonesia --

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither can I.

—Neither can Senator Tambling, who happens to live in Darwin. Senator Dunn was misleading the Senate with her quotation from a pseudo-research organisation, another peace front organisation supported by the Soviets, with respect to Australian support for the banning of nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: The sole point of accuracy in Senator Dunn's speech was when she talked about the difficulty of identification of sea-launched Cruise missiles. I do not wish to spend the limited time available to me debating sea-launched Cruise missiles, but I would draw Senator Dunn's attention to the fact that in a nuclear world and, therefore, a dangerous world, the slower and the more detectable a weapons delivery system is the safer it is, because it can be both detected and intercepted. I would much prefer the Soviets to be armed with sea-launched Cruise missiles than with the horrendous intercontinental ballistic missile armoury they have. We simply have no effective warning time when they are launched. The sea-launched Cruise missile is a reduced threat, and the fact that the Americans have chosen to go down this path-and the Soviets also to some degree-is a matter for support, not for criticism.

The point that Senator Dunn was correct on is the detection of these missiles. It is very hard to detect stored weapons and to run any verification on which ships are carrying them and which are not. A ship might be capable of carrying sea-launched Cruise missiles, but as to actually proving whether those weapons are on board, the verification, which is always involved in arms control procedures, becomes extremely difficult. A ship could be searched and it could rendezvous with another ship later on, a day or so later, or a submarine, and arm with those missiles. I will come later in my speech to the strategic arms reduction talks and how the sea-launched Cruise missiles are one of the sticking points in that discussion.

Senator Dunn was quite wrong to attribute to Commodore Alan Robertson the command of HMAS Melbourne. I think from memory that the commander of HMAS Melbourne at the time of the accident was a Robertson. It certainly was not Alan Robertson, who is known to me. In all, Senator Dunn's approach to it was the usual sort of unintellectual, unilateral disarmament, pacifist stuff that we have heard for the years that we have been listening to the peace movement.

The first part of Senator Crichton-Browne's motion welcomes more than 40 ships to Australia. As an Australian I find it grossly discourteous that some people should take it upon themselves to be rude and to threaten the visitors who have come here at the invitation of the Australian Government. These visitors have made a great effort to come here. One country, Nigeria, simply did not have the money to sail one of its ships to Australia. I presume that it sent its crew in by air. Every nation coming here has been involved at the very least in hundreds of thousands of dollars and, in the case of the United States and Britain, millions of dollars, in sending those ships to Australia. They have done that out of the respect they have for Australia and the people of Australia. We have an obligation to give them the hospitality for which this country is famous-not abuse and not the vilification that some of the uninformed members of this community have given them.

It is a relatively rare event. Fleet reviews occur around the world very infrequently. It is of historical moment that we have more than 40 ships here-I think it was 50 ships on the latest count-which have come to help us celebrate this great event in our history.

The second point of Senator Crichton-Browne's motion deals with the development of goodwill between nations. We have over 17,000 sailors in Sydney. The opportunity is rarely given to the service men and women of a large number of nations-20 or 30 nations-to come together. The element of human contact that the international naval review in Sydney this week provides is not to be lightly set aside, because at the end of the day, if we are concerned about peace-and we all are-it basically gets down to human relations. All the horrible weapons, all the nuclear weapons that we dislike so intensely, are not the cause of the trouble between the various nations and groups of the world; they are but the symptoms of it. The opportunity for 17,000 men and women in Sydney this week, coming from a range of different countries, with different governments, social systems and cultures, to meet in the bars, in the parks and over meals in Sydney is not, as I have said, lightly to be set aside.

The final part of the second part of Senator Crichton-Browne's motion deals with the fostering of a lasting world peace. If we look back over the history of recorded time, we find a frightening number of wars. I forget what the actual figure is, but it is of the magnitude that in the last 3,000 years there have probably been only something like 300 years where peace has reigned completely around the globe. This century that we live in has been characterised by two really massive world wars. The point I would make is that conventional arms have never ever kept the peace. In the 43 years that nuclear arms have existed in the world we have kept the peace. Whether or not we like that difficult and dangerous role that we have in the nuclear age, we cannot deny the argument that the presence and the careful management of nuclear weapons has given us a freedom from a world war and I believe will continue to give us freedom provided we continue an intelligent and careful monitoring of what we are doing.

The third part of Senator Crichton-Browne's motion deals with the maintenance of peace. That is a matter of great complexity. We could be forgiven in here for thinking that somehow or other peace and war were as simple as throwing a light switch-black and white. In reality, it is a matter of enormous complexity. The whole subject of international relationships is not measurable in simple terms. I think the Vietnam war illustrated very clearly the way one cannot see matters in purely military terms. The failure of the Vietnam war came, when the North invaded the South, in not recognising the political complexity of the argument that was involved. Military involvement was essential because the South was being invaded by the North and that could not be countered by any political means. But a political war as intensely fought as a military war was essential if the South was going to be kept free.

Most of the situations that exist around the world of conflicts between nations are extremely complex. They require a great deal of work and a great deal of understanding. Knee-jerk reactions will not solve them, either with slick political fixes or with slick military fixes. Some breakdowns can be prevented by intense diplomatic activity. Sometimes that diplomatic activity has to be supported by military force, or the readiness to use military force to back it up, because at the end of the day foreign policy turns very much on being seen to be able to enforce it. But we have to recognise that some conflicts around the world are insoluble. It does not matter what level of diplomatic understanding and effort is put into them or what level of military involvement is put into them, they are never going to be resolved, because they are basically, for want of a better word, cultural in nature. Some of the problems in the Middle East are quite insoluble. The best that the other nations of the world can do is to exert what influence they can to damp the situation down and create some stability. But one has to recognise that at the end of the day there are those difficulties that simply cannot be prevented from erupting from time to time. The important thing is that they can be localised into small, discrete parts of the world. They need not involve the whole of mankind in a World War III.

Part of the prevention of major conflagrations certainly rests with the armed services. Everyone in Australia owes an enormous debt to service men and women of all the countries of the Western democracies for the sacrifices they have made in their personal lifestyles and at times for the risks they have run in keeping the world free from a major war in the last 43 years.

I go back to the point I made about five minutes ago. Conventional weapons have never kept the peace in the past, it is only the existence of nuclear weapons which has given us that freedom from major conflagration and which will go on keeping us in peace in the foreseeable future. No-one likes nuclear weapons. I do not like them, no-one in this chamber likes them. The risks in possessing them are enormous. We have never had weapons with such total destructive power, but we cannot unlearn nuclear physics, we are stuck with it. We certainly cannot preach a doctrine of total freedom, of the total abolition of nuclear weapons. We have far too many nuclear weapons. But we certainly can make very deep and significant cuts in the armouries of all the nuclear nations. That is, of course, the aim of the Western democracies, and has been for quite a few years-mutual, balanced reductions of nuclear arsenals to the minimal levels required to preserve Western democracies from a strike from the Soviets or any other Third World power which might acquire them.

The resolute approach that the Western nations have taken with nuclear deterrence has paid dividends. It was only last year that we had the enormously significant achievement of the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement. All the INF weapons were removed or are in the process of being removed from the European theatre, and from the Asian theatre where the Soviets had some deployed. That agreement would never have been possible if the Americans had not had the ability and the determination to deploy the Pershing II missiles and the ground- launched Cruise missiles in Europe. It was when those weapons were actually deployed in the ground and the Russians were looking at a counterstrike capability which matched their own that they decided it was time to negotiate. Those negotiations have been successful.

I was in Washington a couple of weeks ago and the view at the highest levels in the strategic arms division is that the Soviets are honouring the agreement to the letter, just as the Americans are. That is of great significance because it is the first time we have seen the abolition of a whole class of weapons, but it is of even greater significance in so far as for the first time the Soviets have permitted on-site verification. The stumbling block on all arms reduction and arms limitation talks has always been the matter of verification, of knowing precisely what one's opponent has. The great breakthrough of the INF talks was the fact that the Soviets and the Americans agreed to allow, with effectively no warning at all, inspection teams to look at their opposing arsenals.

The next round of negotiations is the strategic arms reduction talks, the START talks. For reasons that are not clear the Soviets are not prepared to proceed purposefully with the talks at this stage. But in general what we are talking about with the START talks is very big reductions in strategic nuclear weapons-of the order of 50 per cent of warheads-which is quite dramatic. It will leave the world, in my judgment, still with a great excess of strategic weapons, but as a first move it is very significant.

But there are two sticking points. The first is that the Soviets want the sea-launched Cruise missiles (SLCMs) eliminated and the Americans will not cooperate on that point. Secondly, the Soviets want to maintain mobile inter-continental ballistic missiles and they have already deployed the first mobile ICBM system in the world. The Americans do not like mobile systems because, just like the SLCMs, they are hard to verify. My judgment on it is that both of them will yield on those points. The Soviets will pass on the sea-launched Cruise missiles because they will recognise that verification on them is impossible, and similarly the Americans will pass on the mobile ICBMs. The Americans are ready to negotiate on this and we could see dramatic progress on these talks if only the Soviets would come to the table with the determination to see it through. I believe we could see as rapid a resolution of that problem as we saw with the INF.

This is important because it fits in with the general theme of my speech tonight. I believe we have too many nuclear weapons. We have to work in every avenue we can towards reducing them. But what we could never do is go down the pacifist path, the unilateral disarmers path, of the total elimination of nuclear weapons, because it is simply unreal to believe that the Soviets, the United States, Britain, France and even China will ever put themselves in a position where they could be blackmailed by the possibility of a surprise attack. So we will always have some level of nuclear weapons, but I hope we can reach a position in 10 years' time where we will have far fewer weapons than we have today.

There is room for optimism that there has been some change in the Soviet negotiating position. If there is a change in the Soviet position that will be more than matched by the Western democracies to accommodate any reduction in the Soviet nuclear force. Whilst Mr Gorbachev is a very different kettle of fish to his predecessors, one still has to look at the actions of the Soviets as opposed to their words. There is room for cautious optimism but the Western democracies still have to maintain their care and their caution. Every 37 days the Soviets are commissioning a new nuclear submarine. They are building more tanks, more aircraft and more artillery weapons every week than the West builds in a month or several months. Their expenditure on armaments is about 15 per cent of what is quite a large gross domestic product and their real expenditure on defence is way beyond that 15 per cent level, far in excess of any levels ever reached in the Western democracies.

Not only is the Soviet Government very active in nuclear weapons and conventional weapons, but also it has the biggest arsenal of chemical weapons in the world. We hear a great deal from the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmers about nuclear weapons, but from a personal point of view I think chemical weapons are every bit as horrendous as nuclear weapons. In many ways they are far more dangerous because they involve very low levels of technology, they are cheap and, as we have seen in the Iran-Iraq war, they can have absolutely devastating effects. One matter which I find very disturbing about the Iran-Iraq conflict is that there was good evidence presented that Iraq was using chemical weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Irrefutable evidence.

—Irrefutable evidence, as Senator Puplick says. Where was the community protest? I do not expect anything from the blinkered vision of the Australian Democrats or the nuclear disarm- ament people. However, I am disturbed that the great mass of people in the West raised no comment at all about the horrors of what was going on in Iraq. I really have reservations as to where we are going if the use of chemical weapons, as they have been used in the last year or two in the Persian Gulf area, passes without comment. I am old enough to remember a lot of men who served in the First World War and who were subjected to and crippled by gas attack, which, essentially, is the type of chemical warfare that was used in Iraq. I find it disturbing that we can go back those 70-odd years to the horrors of the First World War and let the use of chemical weapons in Iraq pass without comment. I think that those people who are concerned about nuclear weapons and stridently preach unilateral disarmament should broaden their horizons, educate themselves slightly and discover the horrors of chemical weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I come to the discourteous behaviour of the protest movement to our guests in this country this week. I am appalled that people should behave so badly. Democracies are concerned with the rights of minorities. While those in the lunatic fringe certainly are a minority, they are definitely entitled to their right to protest, to get their point across, to meet and to put their view to the public. But they are not entitled to hazard the lives of sailors on ships and other users of the harbour. It is absolutely untenable to have people in canoes moving into the path of ships which have very restricted mobility in confined waterways. It is just the height of stupidity. They might be valueless human beings intrinsically, but even their lives are worth something. To put themselves between the ships and the wharves in their path is just the height of stupidity. Above all, we have visiting us people who have come from all around the world. They have come out of respect for Australia, they have come specifically at our invitation. What do we get? We get a bunch of stupid, uneducated, uninformed people who, instead of standing aside and writing letters to the captains of ships or to the newspapers, instead of hiring a hall or a truck or holding a meeting on a street corner and spreading the word that way, take direct action against the crews of these ships. On behalf of the Australian people I apologise for the behaviour of those few misguided, miserable, uninformed and utterly reprehensible members of my country who behave in this way.

In closing my remarks I would like to put the point of view of the other side. I have been talking to a number of senior British and American servicemen during the last two or three weeks. In talking about this visit to Australia they expressed great concern that somehow or other some of these demonstrators might be injured. I found that quite embarrassing. Here were people at the level of generals and admirals in other countries who wanted to come to Australia, to do the right thing and to help Australia to celebrate, yet were genuinely worried that some of the protesters might be hurt and that some of the tug crews might be on strike. The whole matter gets quite out of perspective. By all means let these people go to Redfern, Balmain or those parts of Sydney where they naturally come from; let them wallow where they grew up; let them, if they like, write to the Sydney Morning Herald; but, for goodness sake, let them try to acquire some elements of decency and courtesy towards our guests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for General Business has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was interrupted I was speaking both in anger and in sorrow at the action of the Federal Government in putting an additional barrier between patients and their treatment, particularly with regard to preventive medicine. The Government speaks with high energy about its contribution to preventive medicine and considers that it is taking enormous strides in that area. It does not see how illogical it is to put another barrier between the patients and the preventive care which can be obtained with the 53 drugs which the Government proposes to put back on the restricted list.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I cannot condone or understand, nor do I see any extenuation, palliation or excuse for it, the attitude of the Australian Democrats in regard to the Opposition's disallowance motion concerning these 53 drugs. Just yesterday one of the Australian Democrats gave a notice of motion indicating that he was going to move a motion to promote preventive health care in Australia. Yet he got up and spoke in favour of the Government's action in putting these drugs on a more restricted regime for patient access. It just so happens that this afternoon some papers from the Australian Medical Association (AMA) crossed my table. It is too much for me to ask that the papers be incorporated in Hansard, but I seek leave to table them.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is not granted to table the papers? What a miserable attitude.
—Senator Sheil, you asked for leave; it has not been granted.

—Very well, Mr Acting Deputy President. Enclosed with the letter from the AMA was some additional information. The first enclosure was a newspaper advertisement from the Western Australian Labor Minister for Health urging a review of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) changes. The second was an article from the Medical Journal of Australia headed `Pharmaceutical Benefits System: time for radical surgery'-which, I interpolate, it is-and written by Professor John Shaw of the University of Sydney. The third enclosure was a letter dated 2 September 1988 to all AMA members containing the Association's reasons for opposing these changes, and the fourth was a letter dated 2 December 1985 from the Commonwealth Department of Health informing the AMA that the Government would reduce the paperwork associated with the PBS. Also attached was a press release dated 19 November 1985 announcing this `deregulation'. The fifth and final attachment was a press release from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) dated 18 June 1988 announcing the new impositions. I am very sorry that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) does not want to have access to these papers because they indicate in no small way the opposition to the Government's action in further restricting access to these medications.

SPEECH.PARA: Admittedly, once the Government realised the enormity of its mistake in restricting these drugs it took action to try to overcome the effects of what it has done-in true bureaucratic style, I might add. It introduced a 24-hour telephone service by means of which doctors could apply to get access to the drugs for their patients. That would be at no small cost, by the way. It introduced free postal arrangements so that there would be no imposition on doctors making applications to prescribe the drugs, and it introduced special arrangements for pharmacists to make access to the drugs easier. The Government used these and other unsavoury tactics rather than free up the use of these drugs. The Minister has said that he is going to approve all applications for the drugs anyway. Surely honourable senators can see how senseless it is to cause at least three million more applications to have to be processed every year when the Government has decided to approve them all. Why introduce such a ridiculous scheme?

The remark was made during the debate that the Opposition was trying to prolong the debate for some obscure reason. That is not true. The number of speakers from this side of the House is merely an indication of the importance of the need to reject this measure. The drugs involved are virtually disease specific and would not be used for other diseases. For example, it is no use giving drugs that are specifically intended for use in the treatment of cancer patients to people who have epilepsy or arthritis. The drugs for other conditions such as diabetes, cardiac arrhythymia, high cholesterol or high blood pressure are specific for those disorders. It is also unlikely that doctors would be prescribing these drugs willy-nilly to cause a burgeoning of the pharmaceutical benefits system when they are all state of the art medications, disease specific, to which in most cases there are no alternatives. The idea of the Government is purely to create a nuisance to doctors, under the guise of making them think a little bit more about the cost of the medication that they are prescribing.

Why would a doctor want to be overusing these drugs when they are manufactured for a specific purpose? They have fewer side effects than the older medications. The new drugs are superior. They are safer. In many cases there are no alternatives to them. This applies particularly to the anti-cancer drugs. To suggest that a doctor should have to think twice about the use of an anti-cancer drug or even consider the use of surgery instead of drugs is the height of ignorance.

I mentioned earlier-I did not have time to expand on it-the fact that the Australian Medical Association had been willing all along to consult with the Government about what alterations should be made to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In fact, the AMA is willing to have a complete revamp of the system because it has become so unwieldy. But the AMA was not consulted at any stage about these alterations, nor were any of the other parts of the organised medical profession. These include rheumatology, cardiology, oncology and diabetes. All the areas in which these drugs are used have specialised departments within the organised medical profession. I am sure all those organisations would have been willing to assist the Government in deciding what alterations should be made to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. But the Government chose not to do that. It chose a monetary leveller, set at $30, and gave instructions to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to put restrictions on any drugs over $30. That is why the Government has finished up in this illogical position and is trying to defend it as if it is not restricting the availability of drugs to patients.

If doctors have to apply to a bureaucrat for permission to prescribe the drugs, there is the possibility that the bureaucrat will refuse permission and that will cause additional delays. The fact that the Government has later said, `We are going to ratify all applications' makes no difference. The application still has to be made and the opportunity is there for some bureaucrat to refuse it or to delay the provision of treatment to patients. This whole shemozzle results from the Government's unfulfillable promise to provide a free, fair and equitable health care system, the best system of health care delivery in the world. The Government has found that it cannot possibly deliver on that promise. The Government has had a campaign vilifying doctors, the pharmaceutical companies and even patients. It has sought to make out that doctors are willing to prescribe these drugs in an offhanded way in order to qualify for overseas trips.
