There has been no end of red herrings drawn across the trail, across the fact that if this regulation is passed it will make access to drugs for patients just that little bit more difficult. That is a heinous way to treat people. It is almost cruel and inhuman. Even though the Government says that patients are not going to be denied the drugs, there will be an additional obstacle in the way of their prescription.
At this stage, Mr Acting Deputy President, I reapply to have the papers I mentioned before tabled in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any objection?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, could I clarify with you whether the honourable senator needs leave to table a paper or whether he has a right to table it without seeking permission or leave?
—I believe he does need leave. I have taken advice from the Clerk, who advises me that leave must be granted. Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—If the Government does not wish to be edified about the degree of opposition there is to the measure, that is further evidence of the illogical position that it is taking. This kind of refusal of leave to table information for the use of honourable senators is what I would expect from a Fabian socialist such as the Minister sitting--
—Order! Senator Sheil is making a very interesting contribution, and I should like him to continue with it. I am listening very carefully.
—Where did I go wrong?
—The honourable senator was sidetracked by the Minister.

—I am sorry I was sidetracked by that Fabian socialist, the Minister. I can understand that he does not wish to be edified by this information. The Government has accused the AMA of sabotaging this move by the Government, which the Government claims to be responsible economic policy but which is very irresponsible health policy. The AMA can hardly be accused of sabotaging the exercise when it was not consulted. That is why the AMA is circulating the information that I have here. Probably the Government's refusal of leave to have it tabled is an effort to prevent it becoming widely available. However, I can ensure that it has wide circulation and the Government will be exposed for the exercise it is perpetrating upon the patients of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Government is aware of the mounting opposition to its proposal to restrict these 53 prescription drugs that are specific for severe diseases in Australia, but opposition is now coming from within its own Caucus and it is refusing to recognise even that. There is certainly opposition from patient organisations and consumer organisations, as well as from the AMA and other areas of the organised profession in Australia. Why does the Government not take notice of all this opposition when the position it has adopted is absolutely illogical and inconsistent? If it maintains that it is here to institute a major program of preventative medicine in Australia using organisations such as the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Better Health Commission and the work force organisations, why would it put up an obstacle preventing the prescription of these drugs? It is illogical. I find it absolutely incomprehensible that the Democrats are supporting the Government on this issue.

It is with sorrow and anger that I stand up and oppose the measures the Government is taking. They were announced in the May economic statement, when the Government took this giant leap thinking, I presume, that it was cost cutting, which is the end result of these munificent promises. It has said that it will give the best health service in the world to Australia. Finding that it cannot deliver on that promise, it has to restrict the service. There are many ways to restrict the service, but to restrict this part is absolutely ridiculous, particularly when one thinks that the end result, the cost of not treating these diseases, will be a lot more than the cost of preventing them. Yet the Government is trying to maintain that its position is sound in the face of heavy and mounting opposition. We in the Opposition are left bereft of ideas as to why the Government, assisted by the Democrats, should persist with this inconsistent and illogical attitude towards putting another block between the patients and their medication. Again, I make another plea to table the information that I have mentioned before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted. Perhaps the same courtesy can be guaranteed to us next time by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to conclude this debate. It has been an extremely long debate because of the importance the Opposition attaches to the issue that is before the chamber at the moment. I start therefore by thanking those of my colleagues who have participated in this debate and who have made contributions ranging over a very wide spectrum of interests as far as the operation of the nation's pharmaceutical benefits scheme and system is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), the responsible Minister, and Senator Crowley have not in any sense sought to conceal the fact that the Government's decisions in this regard have been primarily based upon an attempt to control costs within the pharmaceutical benefits system. The Opposition has no argument with the Government about the general necessity to curtail government costs and government expenditure. It is, however, a matter of priorities. It is a matter of deciding whether the cost saving, or the reduction in government expenditure that is proposed by this device, is justified when there are other areas from which the Government could be making substantial cuts in public expenditure. For example, the Government could have saved $46m by not conducting the referendum campaigns, which were overwhelmingly defeated in all the States. It could have saved money by winding up that Government propaganda outfit-the National Media Liaison Service, as it is formally called. However, it has chosen to make the sick and the elderly in particular bear the disproportionate cost of reduction in government expenditure through this device.

As I say, it is freely admitted by Senator Cook and those who have supported him-Senator Crowley and Senator Coates-that it is primarily a cost cutting exercise. It is not an exercise related to the better health care of Australians; it is an exercise related to control of government expenditure. We see the pharmaceutical benefits system being used not as a device to bring about a particular health outcome but as a device to bring about a particular economic outcome. We reject that approach. In the first instance, it becomes very difficult to identify where substantial saving is likely to be made. One of two things will occur if the Government is sustained in this course of action. Either doctors will be encouraged to prescribe less costly and, at the same time, less efficacious drugs or we will have a situation in which the bureaucrats in the Department of Community Services and Health will refuse to grant authority permissions. The Minister for Resources shakes his head. Presumably that is because it is a device in which, the Minister says, any script written will eventually get some sort of authorisation.

Where will the cost saving occur when two million extra forms have to be processed somewhere, presumably at some cost? It will occur only if there is a large scale switch to less expensive and less efficacious pharmaceuticals. The less efficacious pharmaceuticals will be those which do not have the same benefits as the expensive drugs which the Government is attempting to restrict or they will be those that have the degrees of side effects which cause non-compliance with medication regimes. We know from the evidence that non-compliance with prescribed medication costs the health care system somewhere between $700m and $800m a year. This will increase the degree of non-compliance because the less expensive drugs are those which are known to have a variety of unfortunate and unacceptable side effects including, as we have said, an increase in the level of male impotency.

The particular point that I make is one that is referred to by Professor Shaw, the Professor of Clinical Pharmacology at the University of Sydney in the editorial of the 15 August edition of the Medical Journal of Australia. Speaking of the Government decision that we are debating this evening, he says:
This decision did not include any assessment of the efficacy or cost-effectiveness of the drugs, simply their monthly costs.

We know that the instructions given to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) were to review all those drugs which cost more than $30 per prescription. That was the basis upon which they were placed on this list. Professor Shaw goes on to say in that editorial:
. . . the decision to add 53 drugs to the authority list is a poorly-disguised attempt to camouflage the restriction of the angiotensin converting-enzyme inhibitor agents . . .

That is precisely the point we have been making throughout this debate. This decision must raise fears in the minds of people as to what is next on the list of drugs to be restricted by some sort of authority only device. Is AZT to be the next drug placed on the list? A year's treatment with AZT costs somewhere in the vicinity of $10,000 to $12,000. That drug is currently available in limited supplies to people suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), but a year's regime costs $10,000 to $12,000 of public expenditure. Is that to be the next drug that goes on the authorisation list?

If one looks at the minute paper written in the Department of Finance-the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is now here in the chamber-by a First Assistant Secretary, Social Security Division, and addressed to the Minister, which was made available as a result of a freedom of information request, one will see that the Minister is advised by his Department:

For instance, total expenditure on over $10 drugs dispensed in November 1987 was 32 per cent higher than in April 1987. This figure excludes the impact of any price increases that pushed drugs over the then $10 threshold.

Apart from ACE inhibitors, most of this increase was concentrated in: penicillins, an 86 per cent increase; anti-epileptic drugs, 26 per cent: non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, 40 per cent: anti-anginals, 26 per cent: insulins, 25 per cent: and anti-asthmatic drugs, 56 per cent.

Of particular importance has been the increase in prescribing of cholestyramine, used to reduce cholesterol levels. Priced at $58 per prescription, monthly expenditure on this drug increased by more than $0.5 million (76 per cent) over the seven month period.
The greater use of authority procedures for some drugs announced in the May statement is intended to stem this growth.

I emphasise the words `is intended to stem this growth'. What is to be next? Already some of the anti-epileptic drugs have been added to the list. We have already had cholestyramine added to the list. Will the anti-asthmatic drugs be the next ones added to the list? Will we be told that the little respirator devices, the Berotecs, the Becotides, the Ventolins, and things like that, which to those of us who suffer from asthma are essential to maintain a status of health, will be the next things to be placed on the Government's hit list because it wants to contain a blow-out in costs? People are right to be concerned and worried about the Government's approach to the way in which it manages cost containment through the pharmaceutical benefits system, rather than cost containment through proper controls on government expenditure.

I now want to turn briefly to some of the contributions that were made by other honourable senators in the course of this debate. Senator Cook has told us-and presumably this relates to part of the Government's cost control expenditure operation-that $2m is to be spent to `re-educate doctors'. They are his words. They are to be re-educated in how to resist the blandishments and the salesmanship of the pharmaceutical companies. They will be re-educated in order to have a better understanding about how to prescribe cheaper drugs. I suppose that in the long run they might well be sent to re-education centres-we might establish a whole new industry of doctors' re-education camps around the place! In fact, what the Government really needs to do is to re-educate some of its legal advisers about attacks on the Constitution-but, no, we can find $46m to waste on that exercise, and here another $2m to re-educate doctors to prescribe drugs in accordance with the Government's economic criteria-in accordance not with public health requirements or the health requirements of patients but with the Government's economic parameters for cost control.

Senator Crowley, in her contribution, said that there would be no undue delays in this matter. Some years ago I was required to find for my family a certain drug, clomid, which was on the authority only list. From personal experience I can tell the Senate that, if the Health Department in Sydney was working at maximum efficiency, an authority could be obtained in two days.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have been in the period of a Liberal government.

—Bad luck, Senator, I am talking about the last two years. If the Department was not working at maximum efficiency, it took five days, unless of course a public holiday or a long weekend were involved. If the Commonwealth Department of Health in Chifley Square was making its normal Public Service holiday arrangements, one could wait longer than that. I have had practical experience, within the last couple of years, of requiring a pharmaceutical item for a member of my family, which was an authority only pharmaceutical and I have personally experienced delays of five and six days in getting an approval for that authority only prescription.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates was asked to address a matter that Senator Calvert had raised. Senator Calvert raised a very important point about the privacy of individuals, but Senator Coates deliberately declined to respond to this matter. The point about privacy is that, in order to complete the necessary bureaucratic form, doctors are now required not simply to put the name and address of the patient and the drug which is being prescribed but in fact to detail the diagnosis for which they have prescribed that drug. I am not aware of any other requirement for a doctor to divulge to the Health Department details of a specific diagnosis of the patient in order to get an authorisation for a drug to be prescribed. Is Senator Cook or Senator Coates, or anybody else, able to say that it is a regular and proper procedure for a physician not simply to provide to the Department the name and address of a patient and the details of the drug that has been prescribed but also to outline the diagnosis that he has made? Of course, the diagnosis might not be correct. The physician might diagnose a certain ailment and prescribe a drug. Later, after other tests have been done, it might be found that it was not that particular ailment but another. It might be a certain type of infection or virus which has subsequently changed, in terms of the diagnosis, after further pathological tests have been done. However, he is now required by government policy to divulge to the Department the personal diagnosis of the individual.

If Senator Cook were able to assure the Senate that there had never been leaks from the Health Insurance Commission about the personal data which is held by that Commission, we might have no concern. But we have seen two or three specific instances of deliberate leaks from the Health Insurance Commission of supposedly confidential data. Senator Calvert's point was that personal and very sensitive information-the diagnosis-has to be disclosed, by compulsion to the Health Department, which we believe does not have an adequate record of maintaining the confidentiality of medical records, particularly those of people with whom from time to time the Government is in dispute. People will remember the deliberate leaking, in I think May 1985, of details of the income of members of the medical profession, and their names, to the Sunday papers in Sydney. We do not believe that the privacy issue has been addressed by the Government. Senator Coates was invited to address this point but he declined to do so.

Senator Knowles made the point, quite rightly, that the Government is changing the nature of the authority only operation. It used to be that the authority only system was there in order to monitor what were addictive drugs. That was the original intention some 30 or 40 years ago-whenever the system was put into place. Essentially, that was to monitor the use of potentially addictive drugs or drugs whose precise nature was not well understood at the time. That was the purpose of the authority only list. It is now being used as an economic tool in the management of the Government's health budget. That was not the purpose for which it was established and we do not believe that it should be used for that purpose.

I want to refer to a couple of points made by Senator Coates. He said that it was not up to him or the Government to indicate to the Parliament what alternative cheaper drugs the Government has in mind. We believe that it is the responsibility of the Government to provide in some form an indication to the Parliament of the alternative drugs that are available. I put it to the Senate that in a number of instances alternative appropriate pharmaceutical products are simply not available. Secondly, Senator Coates told us that the cost saving in all of this, in any case, would be minor. That was actually the word he used-`minor'. If it is minor, how does one justify the amount of inconvenience, trouble and additional bureaucratic involvement, with these two million extra authorities around the place, which is now to be imposed?

Senator Coulter made a point on behalf of the Australian Democrats which seems to me to be quintessentially a statement of Australian Democrat philosophy. Senator Coulter said, `This measure may not be effective but we will support it'. That is the very essence of Democrat politics. They say, `It may not work; it may not be effective; it may not count for very much, but it seems like a good idea at the moment and therefore we will support it'. His actual words were, `It may not be effective but we will support it'. Nothing could more encapsulate the political philosophy of the Australian Democrats than that statement. It is a tragedy and a shame that the Democrats on this occasion have indicated that they are not prepared to be swayed by the basis of argument.

We know full well that when the PBAC meets in October it will get back to this list. Members of the PBAC are as embarrassed as anybody by having been put under the hammer to come up with a hit list purely on the basis of the $30 figure imposed upon them by the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). They know the outrage in the medical community, in the wider community, in the Labor Caucus and this Parliament. Undoubtedly they will try to rescue something of their good name when they meet again in October.

I am not going to refer at length again to the Hon. Keith Wilson, the Minister for Health in Western Australia. We know full well the advertisement that he put in the newspapers which in fact established--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a whinger. He always has been.

—I am glad to have the Minister's assurance that the Minister for Health in Western Australia is a whinger and always has been. Senator Cook was not prepared to say that yesterday, no matter how much he might have thought it. Senator Walsh's intervention to characterise Mr Wilson is greatly appreciated.
—It is obviously an indication that Senator Walsh knows the Minister concerned a great deal better than does Senator Cook.

—I note Senator Chaney's interjection. Mr Wilson set up a hot line. He said that the Western Australian Government was going to fight for the rights of Western Australians not to have their health ruined by this Federal Government intervention. It is a pity that he did not get some help around the place. Where, for example, is the well known Labor Party sisterhood when it is needed?

SPEECH.PARA: A number of drugs on this list are of particular importance to the women of Australia. I will just mention three of them. Drugs which go under the names provera and nolvadex are used in the treatment of breast and uterine cancer. They are of great importance to the management of the health care of Australian women. The drug auranofin, which goes by the brand name of Ridaura and is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, is again a drug of considerable importance so far as women are concerned. These drugs have been added to the hit list of 53 drugs. It is a great shame that, although the Australian Labor Party makes a great deal of noise and goes on with a great deal of nonsense about supporting the rights of Australian women and looking after their particular problems, in fact women are to be singled out for particular disadvantage as far as this list of 53 drugs is concerned.

In conclusion, I wish to make three other points. First, I believe that these restrictions as part of the general approach that this Government takes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in fact are likely to threaten investment in Australia on the part of pharmaceutical manufacturers and pharmaceutical companies. Just as there are lacunal and transitional provisions in the proposed patents amendments legislation before this Parliament to extend the patent life of pharmaceuticals which cause various companies to fall between two tools in terms of regimes for the extension of patent protection, so I believe the continued use of the authority only scheme in this fashion by the Government will cause a diminution in the degree of investment in the pharmaceutical industry and the willingness of pharmaceutical companies to invest in Australia and in Australian industry.

I return to the comments made by Dr Blewett, the Minister, on 19 November 1985 when a number of the authority only drugs, which I specified yesterday, were removed from the authority only list and added to the specified purpose list. Six of those drugs are now to go back onto the authority only list and three drugs which were previously on the specified purpose list, which had their restriction as specified purpose removed in November 1985, have also been added to the authority only list. In November 1985 the Minister for Community Services and Health was at great pains to say what a great job he was doing on behalf of the people of Australia in removing these drugs from both the special purpose list and the authority only list. Now, just a couple of years later, they go back on the list and all of that rhetoric of the Minister for Community Services and Health in November 1985 is shown to be perfectly hollow and perfectly without substance.

I conclude by referring once again to the representations made to me by Professor Priscilla Kincaid-Smith, the professor in the Department of Medicine at the University of Melbourne and the Director of Nephrology at the Royal Melbourne Hospital. I will read again the comments made by Professor Kincaid-Smith, one of the most eminent medical authorities in this country, in her letter. Talking about patients who have been affected by side effects of less desirable, less efficacious medications than ACE inhibitors, she says:

As a consultant, I would only see these patients infrequently when a problem arises and the prescription is provided by the local practitioner. Studies have shown that Authority listing reduces the use of drugs because of the bureaucratic waste of time and effort involved in prescription of drugs restricted in this way.

I understand that the PBAC considered an Authority listing for ACE inhibitors early this year but decided, quite correctly, that such a move was not appropriate. The implementation of an Authority listing now as a government cost-cutting measure is without medical justification. In the long run it will almost certainly cause an increase in cardiovascular mortality and morbidity because of poorer control of blood pressure and poor compliance because of side effects. Authority listing for ACE inhibitors will be a serious blow to all who believe in preventive medicine.

Yesterday Professor Kincaid-Smith's reputation was traduced by Senator Cook who said she was the spreader of alarmist nonsense. I do not believe that she is the spreader of alarmist nonsense. I believe that she is one of those members of the medical community and profession who are fundamentally concerned with nothing more than providing the best health care for the people of Australia and treating patients in the best possible way. She sees how much more difficult her job will be made by this Government decision. She sees the effect which this Government decision will have on the lives of ordinary Australians. She sees the effect which this Government decision will have on the management of serious heart disease in Australia and the way in which it will lead to an increase in cardiovascular mortality and morbidity. She sees the extent to which authority listing as provided for in this Government decision will be a serious blow to all who believe in preventive medicine.

This Government has once again decided to make the poor, the sick, the elderly and women bear an undue and disproportionate burden of its cost cutting exercise. It does the Government no credit and it will do this Senate no credit if we do not disallow this particular pharmaceutical regulation.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988
Consideration resumed from 27 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 as a whole. It has before it Opposition amendment No. (5) moved thereto by Senator Chaney relating to clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are probably waiting not only for Senator Button but also for the advisers. Now we have the advisers and we seem to have Senator Button. I think I am probably out of order because I had just spoken for 15 minutes when we adjourned but I will stay on my feet for a moment until the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is ready. Perhaps while the Minister is preparing his papers I can simply say that to facilitate the consideration of the Bill-which I am sure the Minister would like-I suggest that we vary slightly the approach that was taken at the suggestion of the Minister when we were last in committee, which was the day before yesterday. At the Minister's suggestion we separated amendments (4) and (5) in group 11 which related to the objectives. We have dealt with amendment (4). I had just spoken to amendment (5). I have forgotten what it relates to. Amendments (4) and (5) relate to subsequent amendments because the question of trade union amalgamation or formation is referred back to the objectives.
—You were talking about freedom of association.

—I thank the Minister. I wanted to suggest that by leave we recommit amendment (4) and deal with the whole of block 11 together. I do not wish to reopen the debate on amendment (4) but as a matter of sensibly dealing with the amendments they should be dealt with together as we originally proposed. I seek leave to recommit amendment (4).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we had a very long debate on the pharmaceuticals matter, I would like to facilitate the debate on this Bill. I would suggest that it would help if I spoke to amendments (4), (5), (11), (12), (13), (22), (23), (24), (28), (29), (30) and (31) en bloc. I want to get some indication from the Minister as to whether he sees this as a reasonable procedure. I suggest that if I speak to those amendments and outline them then perhaps we can try to deal with them. The principles involved in them cross into just a small number.
—Would you indicate to the Chair, Senator Chaney, how you want these amendments voted on? Do you want them voted on as one block or as several?
—We wish to vote on all of them together.
—Is leave granted to move all those amendments together? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 2, paragraph 3 (f), line 14, before ``to encourage'' insert ``to provide for freedom of association, and''.
Page 2, after paragraph 3 (b), insert the following new paragraphs:
``(bb) to encourage direct dealing between employers and employees within each enterprise;
``(bc) to minimise interference in relation to enterprises by persons or bodies who have no direct interest in those enterprises; and
``(bd) to facilitate the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units;''.
(11) Page 52, subclause 118 (2), lines 40 to 42, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:

``(2) The Commission may, in relation to a demarcation dispute, order that a ballot be conducted of the employees involved in the dispute for the purpose determining the organisation that should, in the opinion of those employees, represent them.''.
(12) Page 53, subclause 118 (4), lines 16 to 20, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(4) In considering whether to make an order under subsection (3), the Commission shall have regard to:
(a) the objects of this Act; and
(b) the results of any ballot conducted under subsection (2).''.
(13) Page 53, after clause 118, insert the following new clause:
Representation ballots

``118a. (1) Where at least the prescribed number of the employees of a particular employer at a particular place of work make an application to the Commission to change the organisation that has a right to represent under this Act the industrial interests of those employees, the Commission may, if:
(a) it considers that to do so would further the objects of this Act; and
(b) a vote of the employees of that employer under this section has not been conducted in the period of 3 years before the Commission commenced to consider the application;

order that a vote of the employees of that employer (in this section called a `representation ballot') be taken by secret ballot for the purpose of finding out whether those employees wish to change the organisation that has a right to represent under this Act their industrial interests.
``(2) After the conduct of a representation ballot in relation to particular employees, the Commission may, having regard to the results of the ballot, make one or more of the following orders:

(a) an order that an organisation of employees shall have the right, to the exclusion of another organisation or organisations, to represent under this Act the industrial interests of a particular class or group of employees who are eligible for membership of the organisation;
(b) an order that an organisation of employees that does not have the right to represent under this Act the industrial interests of a particular class or group of employees shall have that right;

(c) an order that an organisation of employees shall not have the right to represent under this Act the industrial interests of a particular class or group of employees who are eligible for membership of the organisation.

``(3) Where the Commission makes an order under this section, the Commission shall, unless it is satisfied that no alteration of the rules of any organisation concerned is necessary, refer the matter to a designated Presidential Member.

``(4) Where a matter is referred to a Presidential Member under subsection (3), the Presidential Member shall determine such alterations (if any) of the rules of any organisation concerned as are, in the Presidential Member's opinion, necessary to reflect the order of the Commission.
``(5) In this section:
`place of work' has the same meaning as in section 136;
`prescribed number', in relation to employees employed by a particular employer at a particular place of work, means:
(a) if there are fewer than 100 of those employees-5; or
(b) if there are 100 or more of those employees-5% of the number of those employees.''.
(22) Page 84, paragraph 189, lines 6 to 20, leave out (1) (b), (c) and (d) paragraphs, insert the following paragraph:
``(b) the registration of the association would further the objects of this Act;''.
(23) Page 84, paragraph 189 (1) (j), lines 33 and 34, leave out the paragraph.
(24) Page 86, clause 193, leave out the clause.
(28) Pages 112 and 113, paragraph 237 (a), line 38 (page 112) to line 2 (page 113), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) shall immediately fix a time and place for the hearing of submissions in relation to the proposed amalgamation;''.
(29) Pages 113 to 115, clauses 239, 240 and 241, line 12 (page 113) to line 19 (page 115), leave out the clauses.
(30) Page 115, subclause 242 (1), lines 22 to 35, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(1) If, after hearing submissions in relation to the proposed amalgamation, the Presidential Member is satisfied that:
(a) the amalgamation complies with, and is not contrary to, this Act and awards and is not otherwise contrary to law; and
(b) if the amalgamation took place, it would further the objects of this Act;
the President Member shall approve the submission of the amalgamation to ballot.''.
(31) Page 119, subclause 246 (1), lines 2 to 14, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:

``(1) Where, under subsection 243 (1) or (2), the question of an amalgamation is submitted to a ballot of the members of an existing organisation concerned in the amalgamation, the members of the organisation shall be taken to have approved the amalgamation if, and only if, more than half of the formal votes cast are in favour of the amalgamation.''.

I again thank the committee for that. I would now like to deal with the amendments. Amendment (4) has been discussed at great length. It seeks to add objects to the Act which would encourage direct dealing between employers and employees within each enterprise; minimise interference in relation to enterprises by persons or bodies who have no direct interest in those enterprises; and facilitate the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units. Amendment (5) makes provision of freedom of association one of the objects of the Act. The relevance of these amendments is that they encompass the principles which we say are relevant to the shape that trade unions should assume.

The general thrust of the amendments can be understood by reference to our policy, which refers to promoting cooperative, flexible and productive relationships within enterprises; providing for genuine voluntary unionism and a greater scope for workers to choose their union; and having a change to existing union structures which we see as a significant impediment to improved relations between employers and employees in many enterprises. We suggest in our policy that the structure of registered trade unions in enterprises which operate under the Commission and its awards will be determined by the wishes of the members of those unions. Freedom of association will be preserved subject only to Commission supervision of matters relating to the formation of new unions and amalgamation or fragmentation of existing unions with a view to ensuring that, as far as possible, new union structures contribute to the objectives of the things that are dealt with in amendment (4)-that is, ensuring that employers and employees deal directly with each other; minimising interference by people or bodies with no direct interest in the enterprises; and facilitating the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units.

We say that, where employees wish to form a new union to represent them or to vary existing union structures, there will be secret ballot provisions to enable the wishes of the work force to be determined. We say further that when those wishes are established-in other words, when the workers themselves vote as to the structure they want-the desired structure will be approved unless, in the opinion of the Commission, it will provide a less effective structure to promote the objectives set out in amendment (4) or if there has been a change in or a determination on union structure within the previous three years. That is there simply to stop chopping and changing. We undertake in our policy to legislate to enable employees to approach the Commission if they wish to vary the structure of their union.

Amendments (11) and (12) provide for demarcation ballots and empower the Commission to conduct a ballot of employees involved in a demarcation dispute for the purpose of determining the organisation that should, in the opinion of those employees, represent them. The Bill enables the Commission to issue orders concerning which union should have coverage over a certain area of work and the amendments provide that, in considering whether or not to make an order, the Commission shall have regard to the results of a demarcation ballot and the objects of the Act. The amendments are very much consistent with the policy that I have just read out.

Amendment (13), on representation ballots, provides that, where a prescribed number of employees at a particular workplace apply to the Commission to change the organisation that has a right to represent their industrial interests, the Commission may order a representation ballot of those employees. The Commission may order such a ballot only if it considers that to do so would further the objects of the Act and if there has not been a representation ballot of the employees concerned during the previous three years. After a representation ballot has been conducted, the Commission may make orders concerning which organisation shall represent the industrial interests of the employees concerned.

Amendment (22) alters the criteria for registration. Size ceases to be a criterion for registration, as does whether the association seeking registration is an industry-based association. Instead, each application for registration is to be tested against the objects of the Act that we are seeking to insert.

Amendment (23) deletes the provision that an association may be registered if, and only if, there is no organisation to which the members of the association might conveniently belong. The effect of the `conveniently belong' rule is to make it almost impossible to register new organisations. This is inconsistent with freedom of association and reinforces the monopoly enjoyed by existing unions. It acts as an obstacle to the creation of a more enterprise focused union structure by, for example, effectively preventing the registration of enterprise unions. In the past the `conveniently belong' provision has been defended as preventing the further proliferation of unions. The problem, however, is not the number of unions in the country. After all, Japan is an example of how a union structure with a number of small and very large unions can work satisfactorily. The problem is the multiplicity of unions operating within individual enterprises. It is important to note that our amendment makes the registration of new organisations subject to whether this would further the objects of the Act which, again, focus on that need to promote the single enterprise bargaining unit. Registration can be refused if to do so would fragment bargaining at an enterprise level.

Amendment (24) deletes the provision in the Bill that provides for a designated presidential member to consider whether special circumstances exist that justify the continued registration of small organisations. The existence of small unions is not inimical to good industrial relations. That point was made to us by trade unions, which gave statistics and made direct representations about their experience of industrial disputation being more likely in the larger structures with which they were in contact and sometimes had been involved. To illustrate the view of the Confederation of Australian Industry, I quote from its press release of 26 August:

There is no good reason for example, to require unions to have 3,000 or more members. Such a requirement is based on the false assumption that bigger unions will be more industrially responsible, more receptive to the needs of particular industries or enterprises, or will otherwise improve industrial relations. This ill-advised proposal should be deleted from the Bill.

It is a myth that small unions cause demarcation disputes. Since the beginning of the year there have been over 40 demarcation disputes, and only one of those involved a union whose continued registration would be threatened under this provision. In fact, it is large unions that get involved in demarcation disputes. Those unions with the highest involvement in such disputes since the beginning of the year are the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia, the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia (FEDFA), the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Transport Workers Union of Australia-all large unions. As I have said, small unions have made a series of direct representations to the Opposition. The Australian Government Lawyers Association regards clause 193 as a fundamental interference with the civil liberties of its members, who are desirous of continuing the structure which would be at risk under the proposals in the Bill. The Australian International Pilots Association makes the same point and says that it will simply not accept any amalgamation but will operate as an official body if it is forced to do so.

Amendment (28) provides that, where a presidential member has accepted a properly lodged application in relation to a proposed amalgamation, the presidential member shall immediately fix a time and place for the hearing of submissions in relation to the proposed amalgamation. Clause 238 provides that submissions concerning proposed amalgamations may be made only with the leave of a designated presidential member and in relation to a prescribed matter. Such hearings will provide an opportunity for the unions involved, other unions which might be affected, and employers to make submissions on whether the proposed amalgamation would further the objects of the Act. I am sorry to speak at such length, but as these are all related matters I think that it is better to deal with them in this way. I may need to seek leave to continue or go through the joke of having someone else talk and then my coming back to this. However, I will try to finish.

Amendment (29) deletes the provisions concerning the declaration of a community of interest between organisations proposing to amalgamate. Under the provisions of the Bill, a designated presidential member may, at the conclusion of a hearing concerning a proposed amalgamation, make a declaration that there is a community of interest between the organisations concerned in the amalgamation in relation to their industrial interests. Where such a declaration has been made, a simple majority of votes cast in a subsequent ballot is required to approve the amalgamation. Where no declaration is made, 25 per cent of the members on the roll of voters must actually cast a vote as well.

In practice the community of interest test is very widely drawn. It certainly does not by itself encourage amalgamations that will lead to industry unions. The outcome of the Bill as it is drafted will not be industry unions but fewer larger conglomerate unions with members in a range of industries. There may be a reduction in the total number of unions, but employers will continue to face a multiplicity of unions. Indeed, from an industrial relations point of view the Bill is likely to accelerate a trend away from the goal of unions organised on an industry or enterprise lines. Some unions which largely operate in a single industry and are therefore likely to identify with the interests of that industry are merging with occupationally based unions that operate across a range of industries. I do not think that is the objective that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, would have in terms of, again, his own portfolio objectives.

One example is the proposed amalgamation of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia. The Commission recently found that this amalgamation met the community of interest test because a substantial number of the members of both unions were engaged in the same work in the building industry, and yet most FEDFA members are not employed in that industry. So the Government is producing a large structure, which is certainly the Australian Council of Trade Unions' objective-perhaps it is the Government's objective-but it would be very difficult to claim that that is a structure which meets the description of an industry union; it clearly does not. If in fact the two unions merge, the result will be a union with over 100,000 members employed not only in the building industry but also in the power industry, the mining industry and the manufacturing and public sectors. Other amalgamations in the offing include that between the rubber and allied workers and the storemen and packers. Again, the result will be a multi-industry union. I think the industrial record of the storemen and packers over recent years would not really give great cause for ease of mind in terms of their contribution to industrial peace in Australia. I think again the Minister at the table would have been concerned some time ago when I think 13 storemen and packers at Borg Warner were able to wreak considerable havoc on the motor vehicle building industry, to cause very substantial stand-downs and so on. It is not --

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the right of choice of employees at a particular plant or establishment is concerned, to exercise a right of choice in terms of who their agent or representative will be in respect of wages and industrial conditions, I would like Senator Chaney to address the question of how frequently that right of choice can be exercised. As I understand it, it is once every three years. But let us put the hypothetical situation of the workers at the Caltex oil refinery-who seem to have improved since a few years ago; but let us take that example. They say, `Look, we will have the storemen and packers this time with a big wages and conditions claim, and we will have the storemen and packers represent us'. The storemen and packers do not do the job, so next time they shop around again. They say, `This time we will have the Australian Workers Union'. I am just concerned about that sort of process because it seems to me to be extraordinarily destabilising not only for the employer but for the industry for that sort of situation to take place. I would like some comments from Senator Chaney on that.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing is a comment which I made in the second reading stage of the debate. With these amendments the registration procedures are still left essentially as they are in the existing legislation; that is, the conditions of eligibility for membership of an organisation will still be determined under this legislation. If the Opposition amendments were carried, as I read it, the conditions of eligibility for membership of an organisation will still be determined as a matter of law by the Industrial Registrar, perhaps confirmed by a bench of the Commission. The conditions of eligibility will then be subject to the test of the choice of employees in a particular area. So the law which is laid down as to who shall be a member of a union via the system-honourable senators can like or dislike it as they will-will then be open to some sort of overriding provision based on this concept of choice. I am not knocking the concept of choice. I understand-I was going to say `the logic', but that would be putting it too high-the scheme of what is proposed, but it might be helpful for Senator Chaney to go on with what he was saying before, and if in the course of it he addresses those two questions, I would be grateful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had almost completed going through the amendments that are part of this group of amendments which deal with trade union structure. I was dealing with amendment (29), which provides for deletion of the community of interest test. I made the point that the result of what the Government is proposing is not to produce industry unions but to produce conglomerates which will, in fact, cross industry lines. I gave some specific examples of amalgamations which are being sought. The point has been made not just by the Opposition but also by other observers of the industrial relations scheme. I will quote in this context the Business Council of Australia (BCA) which I think has been adopting a most positive and constructive role in industrial relations over this recent year or two. I think that again it has very much concentrated on trying to improve enterprise level industrial relations. I think that no-one would say that it is approaching industrial relations from an anti-union or a particularly biased viewpoint. The BCA had this to say about this element:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Bill is setting the scene for the emergence of large craft-based conglomerate unions, an example of which is the suggested merger between the Electrical Trades Union and the Vehicle Builders' Union . . .
So we have a proposal for an amalgamation between the Electrical Trades Union and the Vehicle Builders Union. The BCA continued:

. . . which would involve a craft union covering thousands of employees in many industries swallowing one of the few examples of an industry-based union. Mergers of that type will significantly worsen current problems, not solve them.

No-one should doubt that this will occur under the provisions of the Bill. One only needs to look at amalgamations under way and being planned to see that despite ACTU policy which favours industry-based structures, the internal politics of the union movement will probably result in the creation of craft-based maxi unions.

The Government needs to reconsider its whole approach. In particular, it needs to ensure workable ways exist to encourage rationalisation in the workplace to the advantage of the workers in the enterprise and thus of all Australians.

That is all I wish to quote of the BCA for the time being. But to return to amendment (29), the amendment also deletes the provisions relating to objections to amalgamations. Such objections can be dealt with at the hearing under clause 237.

Amendment (30) provides that, if after hearing submissions in relation to the proposed amalgamation the Industrial Relations Commission considers that the amalgamation complies with the law and would further the objects of the Act, then it is to be submitted to a ballot. Amendment (31), provides that, where the question of an amalgamation is submitted to a ballot of the members of an existing organisation concerned in the amalgamation, the members of the organisation shall be taken to have approved the amalgamation if more than half the formal votes cast are in favour of the amalgamation. In other words, only a simple majority is required to approve an amalgamation as long as the amalgamation would further the objects of the Act.

I turn to the specific inquiries that were made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) when he helpfully intervened to enable me to complete my description of this group of amendments. Senator Button expressed concern really about the problem that people might be shopping around. We indicated during his inquiry that the amendments proposed would provide that one cannot make changes if there has been a change within the previous three years, so there is a three-year period. I simply say to the Minister that we believe that that sort of flexibility is a matter of right, a matter of entitlement that we think ought to be allowed. In terms of its practical operation we believe that it will be a spur to the provision of a good and adequate service to the membership by trade unions that they know that their membership has this sort of freedom of choice.

Again this is something which is not outside the range of human experience. I think the development of the Electrical Trades Union (ETU) in the United Kingdom is leading the way, as the Minister would know, in terms of providing union coverage in the new industries which are so vitally needed in the United Kingdom. It is an area where one knows the Minister's sympathies lie, where an employer is seeking to ensure that a new enterprise is being established on a competitive basis internationally and which cannot afford to be trammelled by absurd restrictive labour practices. The ETU is at the forefront of providing coverage, very much on a competitive basis. Whether the ETU gets the coverage is very much a matter of choice of the membership and of the capacity of the ETU to deliver the services that are in the interests of those members.

Quite frankly, we believe that if that sort of environment is provided, where there is greater freedom, there is in fact very great pressure on the elements of the system to perform. I think I made the point earlier in the debate-it may not have been in here as I remember making the point in a speech recently outside this chamber-that the experience in Queensland with the South East Queensland Electricity Board was very interesting, because in discussions there with the voluntary organisation, which represents the contract employees and which is not a registered organisation under the relevant Act, we heard very strong expressions by the representative of that association of the need to provide services to the members' satisfaction if it was to attract membership. I think that is a very much better approach than the process of industrial conscription through the use of preference clauses and the closed shop which is still so much a feature of our industrial scene. In response to Senator Button's first question I do not see that capacity of the work force to choose a union as being a negative in the way he suggests.

In terms of his attempt to describe the amendments generally, he is quite right. Of course, these provisions do not relate to whatever associations employees might form in a work situation which is not subject to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We are dealing here with registered organisations only. In those circumstances, yes, the whole scheme is based on an overriding provision of giving regard to the choice which is made by the work force itself. We have not given untrammelled regard to that.

As the amendments make clear, in assessing the desire of a group of employees to form a new registered association, the Commission is thrown back on a consideration of whether that will facilitate those objectives that we have spelt out, and those objectives seem to us to be on common ground. When we talk to people who are involved in the productive process they see those things as being really fundamental to an improved industrial relations situation. We are simply trying to provide for the sort of flexibility which will permit people to move in their own economic interest, be they employer or employee, but with this one area of public policy concern given proper consideration by the Commission.

As we are having a fairly long debate on this Bill I suppose it sounds strange for me to say that I do not want an unnecessarily prolonged debate because we are in the unfortunate situation where we know the Australian Democrats are not going to support these amendments. We are putting them down essentially to provide the clearest possible indication to the Government as to the line we think it should adopt, and to the people of Australia as to the line we would adopt in government. In that sense it is a demonstration of the alternative that we think is available and which is better. I just want to stress to the Minister, as he would in fact know, that there are plenty of people-I have quoted the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia-who have significant reservations about the move towards bigness per se, which is really what we think is going to be achieved by the Government under this proposal.

I would also like to quote from a paper published by the Department of Industrial Relations of the University of Sydney. It is one of its Working Paper Series and comments were made on the Bill in some detail by Mr Andrew Stewart. I quote from part of that paper where he said this:

The obvious criticism to be made of the Bill in this context is that it is ill designed for the purpose of reshaping the union structure to achieve what is said by the Government to be the desired result of industry based organisation. In the first place, the existence of small unions is not necessarily incompatible with an industry based structure: it depends whether those unions are in fact industry or craft based. While it may be conceded that the majority fall into the latter category and that there are valid concerns on a more general level as to the efficacy of such unions in representing their members' interests, the adoption of a principle that all small unions must go seems a very blunt instrument. Much will turn on the Commission's view of what constitutes `special circumstances'. Conversely, the Bill makes no attempt to put pressure on larger organisations which are craft based. On the contrary, the incentive is there in the amalgamation provisions (particularly given a community of interest) to amalgamate to form even larger craft based unions. While this might reduce the number of unions with which some employers must bargain, the overall effect will be to entrench rather than detract from the craft based structure.

I repeat those words because they are quite fundamental. In the view of the University of Sydney paper we have a change which will entrench rather than detract from the craft based structure. He continued:

The same can be said of the tendency for unions with overlapping but by no means co-extensive interests to amalgamate to form ``super unions'' of the type found in the United Kingdom. The recently announced AWU/FIA merger provides an illustration. The more that attention is concentrated on eradicating small unions, while amalgamations are used to create multi-industry and multi-craft unions, the harder it will be in the long run to reorganise unions on industry lines alone. If that is the Government's aim, the Bill does little to promote it. The suspicion must be that both the Government and the ACTU's real interest lies in the reduction of the number of unions and that any restructuring along industry lines that happens to eventuate from that process will be regarded merely as a laudable coincidence.

I think that quotation very squarely puts the concerns which the Opposition has about the way the Government is proceeding. It is certainly meeting the agenda of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to have larger unions. It is not meeting the agenda of the Government, which we understood to be encouraging industry based unions.

We put those amendments forward because we believe they provide a workable, flexible scheme which pays far higher regard to the right of freedom of association, to the basic human rights of employees. We believe it provides a much greater and better instrument for encouraging the sort of workplace relationships which the Minister has so often said are at the heart of our economic future. We believe we are putting forward a union structure approach which is much more related to the change to a more productive culture that the Minister has talked about. It is a matter of very great regret to me that he is not prepared to consider these amendments.

As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, I remind this committee that we sought during the last sitting, when we had ahead of us the period of the recess-dead time as far as this Bill was concerned-a parliamentary committee examination of this particular element of the Bill. We are so convinced that any rational public examination of the Bill would produce a clear demand for a changed approach that we think it is a great shame that the Australian Democrats were not prepared to support that approach, and indeed that the Government was not prepared to support it. I think the Government has adopted a quite pig-headed-I think `mulish' was the expression I used last time we were in committee-approach to the industrial relations structure which is laid down by this Bill. I think that will be quite expensive for Australia because it will be at least into 1990 before we will have an opportunity, as a government, to introduce contrary legislation. I believe many of the Minister's own objectives with respect to Australian industry, if they are not subverted, will be substantially hindered by the trade union structure that will be encouraged by the present proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom of association obviously implies some choice over which organisation an employee wishes to belong to. The amendments to the Industrial Relations Bill which Senator Chaney has just moved in series liberalise the rules governing the registration of new organisations and give employees a far greater say over which organisation has the right to represent them. As Senator Chaney has emphasised in moving this series of amendments, a major defect in the Government's legislation is its total neglect of any attempt to protect the rights of workers to establish or to join an organisation of their own choice.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting the amendments moved by Senator Chaney, I particularly refer to clauses 189 and 193. In that regard this Bill, quite apart from the arguments which Senator Chaney put with regard to those clauses and in support of the amendments which the Opposition has moved, is also a direct contravention of Convention No. 87 of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), to which Australia is a signatory, on the freedom of association and protection of the right to organise. This convention provides that workers, without any distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and join organisations of their choosing.

Australian workers do not have the right to establish and join trade unions of their own choosing. At least, they certainly do not have the right to freely establish and join organisations that can be registered to operate within the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This is already prevented under the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Employees under that Act are prevented from forming or joining enterprise or multi-skill unions. Instead, they are forced into big trade unions which are already established and registered in respect of their particular trade. Likewise, under the Bill we are currently debating, the freedom to establish and join a registered union is restricted even further. We have moved these amendments firstly to make the provision of freedom of association one of the objects of the Act and, more especially, to delete those parts of clauses 189, and the whole of clause 193, which reinforce that inability of employees to operate under freedom of association.

Clause 189 of the Bill prohibits the registration of a new union except in exceptional circumstances, those circumstances being, firstly, that the union must have more than 3,000 members; secondly, that the union is industry based; and, thirdly, that there is no existing union to which the members might conveniently belong. Therefore, the `conveniently belong' clause of the old Act which protected the vested interests of existing unions and which was the subject of a great deal of industrial litigation over its lifetime, is even more strongly entrenched in this legislation.

Clause 193 effectively requires the amalgamation of small unions by ensuring that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will deregister unions with fewer than 3,000 members after three years unless there are special circumstances which make continuation of registration in the public interest. Article 4 of the ILO convention provides that workers and employers organisations shall not be liable to be dissolved or suspended by administrative authority. So clause 193 of the Bill is in direct contravention of Article 4 of the ILO convention. It is for this reason that the Opposition has moved amendments to clauses 189 and 193. Obviously, registration of a union is essential if that union is to be able to represent its members before the Commission. So deregistration is, in effect, equivalent to the dissolution or suspension of that union.

The creation of larger unions is a move towards increased centralised control rather than the preferred movement towards a more flexible system which would be more responsive to local enterprise and individual industry needs. As Senator Chaney said earlier in this debate, statistics show that the majority of demarcation disputes involve unions with more than 3,000 members; in other words, the sorts of unions that are required to be established under the two clauses to which I refer. Unions such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia and the building and transport workers unions are the large unions which are the subject of the majority of demarcation disputes. In fact, in a recent survey of 32 demarcation disputes it was found that only one of those disputes involved a union with fewer than 3,000 members. This indicates that these two clauses, which will serve to create bigger unions, will only increase the likelihood of these costly and destructive demarcation disputes. With a larger membership spread over a wider range of industries it is inevitable that demarcation disputes will spread out through the workplace in a ripple effect, eventually crippling many industries, many of which will not have been directly involved in the original dispute.

We should in fact be aiming for a single union in each workplace through the creation of either enterprise or industry based unions rather than legislating to create huge, unwieldy craft based unions that stretch across a multitude of enterprises. Of course, that is the policy of the Opposition. It is a policy which has been very carefully developed over the last couple of years. It has been given considerable public airing and subjected to considerable public debate and, I might say, it has won considerable public support over the past two years. It is to give effect to that well accepted policy of the Opposition that we have moved a series of amendments to this Government legislation.

In particular, we seek to amend clause 189 to leave out paragraphs (1) (b), (c), (d) and (j). Paragraph (c) requires that, to be registered, an association of employees must have at least 3,000 members. Paragraph (d) provides that for an association of employees to be registered it must be industry based. Paragraph (j) provides that an association may be registered only if there is no existing organisation to which the members of the association might conveniently belong. These are the three particular subclauses which would prevent employees from either establishing or joining the industrial organisation of their choice. They would prevent employees from exercising freedom of association, that right which is provided under the International Labour Organisation convention.

The other amendment to which I have referred proposes to remove clause 193 completely. This clause requires that after three years, unless there are special circumstances, organisations with fewer than 3,000 members will, in effect, be abolished. It provides that they will no longer be registered which, of course, means that they can no longer operate in our industrial relations system. These clauses, the Opposition amendments to which the Government has indicated it will not accept, go very much to the heart of this legislation. They also reflect the way in which this legislation gives effect to the proposed industrial structure argued for in Australia Reconstructed-that document of the Australia Council of Trade Unions which seeks to push industrial relations in this country in the wrong direction and reinforce all the shortcomings and faults which have been evident in the Australian system of industrial relations for so long.

The proposals in Australia Reconstructed are very much in accord with the clauses we are dealing with and which we are seeking to amend, in effect, to reverse that direction, to ensure that employees have the opportunity to form organisations of their own choice and of whatever size-that they have that freedom of association. That will ensure that industrial relations is more effectively conducted at the enterprise level. That is what this country desperately needs. This country desperately needs difficulties in industrial relations and disagreements between employers and employees to be sorted out at the workplace or enterprise level. One of the most effective ways of ensuring that is to base the structures in which industrial relations are conducted at enterprise level. The policies of the coalition will ensure that that objective is achieved. The legislation before the Committee, and in particular the clauses to which I have referred, will not allow that desirable development to occur. For that reason the Opposition has moved these amendments, which I strongly support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong the debate, for in some senses we have had it before, but I want to refer to one or two points relating to the comments which have been made. First of all, there are extreme practical and technical difficulties with the Opposition amendments. I sort of accuse the Opposition-not in any hostile spirit-of using this Bill as a convenient vehicle to advance an alternative strategy or philosophy in relation to the industrial relations system. I follow that. Nonetheless, the Government has the responsibility of dealing with the Bill as a piece of legislation. There are a lot of very confusing matters contained in the Opposition amendments which in my view conflict with other provisions of the legislation. That is certainly one reason why the amendments are not acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could make the point, as I did before, I think there are real problems about the Industrial Registrar's function in determining eligibility for organisations and the proposal for freedom of choice at the enterprise level of the organisation which is going to represent the worker in particular circumstances. Secondly, I believe that under the Opposition amendments we could end up with an even bigger disparity between the coverage under Federal unions and the coverage under State unions. As I coincidentally happened to make that comment at this time, might I refer to a debate on a previous clause of the Bill where it was being alleged by the Opposition that the Government was hell-bent on getting all unions into the Federal system and so on and some provisions of the Bill were seen as damaging or detrimental to the continuation of State industrial systems, and I was asked by Senator Chaney at that stage--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a view put by State unions.

—Yes, I understand that. I just make the point that in April 1954 the numbers under Federal awards represented 42.5 per cent of the total and in May 1985 represented 32.6 per cent of the total. In respect of State awards over the same period, it varied from time to time between 47 per cent of the total in April 1954 and 49.8 per cent of the total in May 1985. I come back to the point about the disparity between the coverage under Federal unions and State unions. The Opposition amendments, in addition to the other inconsistencies in legislation terms which I mentioned earlier, ignore the fact that we have a dual Federal-State industrial relations system which includes registration at State and Federal levels. Enormous problems can be caused, as the case of Moore v Doyle, with which Senator Harradine would be familiar, amply illustrates. In other words, the Opposition amendments are impractical and assume that the State systems do not exist. The Bill, on the other hand, provides machinery to overcome these problems. For example, clause 202 allows members of State unions to be treated as members of Federal unions for certain purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, what I want to say is that we disagree in a philosophical sense with the various assumptions underlying these amendments. Secondly, in a very practical sense, because of other provisions in the Bill, we say that in legislative terms the Opposition amendments cannot be accepted. Finally, there are consequences which would flow from the passing of the Opposition amendments in terms of the relationship between the State and Federal systems which would be very confusing and damaging. So we commend the Bill to the chamber as it stands.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 84, subparagraph 189 (1) (c) (i), line 13, leave out ``3,000'', insert ``1,000''.
(4) Page 86, subparagraph 193, definition of ``small oganisation'', line 40, leave out ``3,000'', insert ``1,000''.

These two amendments are the first two of seven amendments to be moved by the Democrats. It is apparent not only from my speech in the second reading debate but also from the pattern of debate in this committee stage that the Democrats are, in essence, supporting the Government on this Industrial Relations Bill 1988. We have chosen two aspects of the Bill which we find exceptional and which therefore have become the foci of our amendments. They are in essence questions of structure and specifically the question of amalgamations.

Earlier in the debate our attention was drawn to the fact that one of the most significant aspects of the Bill is that it seeks to alter significantly the structure of unions in Australia. This is one of the main thrusts of the draft legislation. However, in posing an alternative structure of unions it sees the process of amalgamation and the move towards essentially 20 large unions as being essential. In essence, we offer no objection to the process of amalgamation. However, we think it is important that we proceed slowly and responsibly and in a way which accommodates the needs of presently small unions. Indeed, we have been lobbied quite extensively by a number of small unions, which tell us that the formula for amalgamation poses considerable difficulties for them.

These two amendments seek a significant variation on the amalgamation formula. Clauses 189 and 193 of the Bill propose that it become a requirement in three years' time that employee organisations, in order to be registered-in other words, to have standing before the Industrial Relations Commission-have memberships of no fewer than 3,000 unless they are able to prove special circumstances, and that employer associations have memberships of no fewer than 1,000 in order to have such standing. It was argued by Professor Hancock in the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems-a committee that was commissioned by the Government and whose recommendations have been substantially accepted by it-that a minimum membership of 1,000 should be required. We are therefore merely endorsing the recommendations of the Hancock Committee. This figure would provide the opportunity to meet the needs of smaller unions, who could amalgamate rather than rely upon special circumstances, exemptions in the legislation. Therefore, this would avoid the overloading of the special circumstances provisions and would not detract from the credibility of those provisions where they were truly needed. The figure of 1,000 was the figure in the Government's 1987 Industrial Relations Bill. It was clearly acceptable to the Government 15 months ago and, at that time, it was also acceptable to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). We are puzzled as to why there has been a 200 per cent increase in that figure in the intervening 15 months. We argue that, since the amalgamation figure of 1,000 was acceptable to the Government and to the ACTU 15 months ago, it should still be acceptable to them now.

The former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, argued that the credibility of the amalgamations process required a strong commitment to it in the formula delineated in the Bill. He argued that without this strong commitment there would be a lack of identification and commitment by the union movement to what the Government regards as an essential process of amalgamation. The Democrats do not believe that there is any lack of commitment to amalgamations by the union movement. The two papers, Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement and Australia Reconstructed, both have the endorsement of the ACTU and the trade union movement at large and both demonstrate a strong commitment to the amalgamation of unions. We therefore reject Mr Willis's argument that there is insufficient commitment to the process of amalgamation to ensure that the Government is able to achieve the vital objectives which are inherent in the general thrust of the broad Government strategy.

Small unions have experimented with amalgamation unsuccessfully, some of them finding that very large unions cannot represent the interests of a small specialised group as well as they would like. Indeed, some of the 40-odd unions that have lobbied us in relation to these amendments have walked that course over recent years and found it to be unsuccessful. They have withdrawn from it, only to be told, through this Bill, that they are to go back whence they came. They find that quite unacceptable. We therefore feel that the figure of 3,000 is likely to lead to an ideological family of unionists whereas a requirement for a minimum of 1,000 members is more likely to be specifically based and therefore to produce the type of union structure that is able to operate more functionally in the workplace.

This amendment simply says: let us accept the recommendations of the Hancock Committee.
