Let us go back to a formula which was acceptable to the Government 15 months ago and which was acceptable to the ACTU at the same time. Let us adopt a formula which accommodates the needs of the small unions. Let us adopt a formula which will not unnecessarily exhaust or extend the clauses of special provision. The Democrats believe that such an amendment is responsible. We understand that the Opposition will find it acceptable. Whilst we realise that in recent days it has attracted a good deal of attention, from my recent discussions with the Minister--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate I detailed various examples of the disastrous situation in Victoria under the Cain Labor Government's WorkCare scheme. Also yesterday my colleague Senator Alston and I gave details of the equally horrendous situation facing the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC) due to its investment in a number of companies and ventures which have proved to be disastrous failures. I mentioned both of those in the context that, at the end of the day, the cost of these failures and the cost of the WorkCare scheme, which has grown beyond anyone's belief, finish up with the taxpayers of Victoria, and indeed of Australia. Today I received information and some of it was reported in today's Melbourne Herald--
—I hope it is better than most of your information.

—If that is best the honourable senator can do he should go back to sleep. Today I received information about the Commonwealth Banking Corporation having taken action to recover more than $300,000 owed to it. This should be of interest to Senator Button in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It is very a serious matter, in that the Commonwealth Bank has been forced to take action to recover more than $300,000 which is owed to it by a high technology computer company, which had received $6m from the Victorian Investment Corporation (VIC) Ltd. Of course, the Victorian Investment Corporation is owned jointly by the Labor Government in Victoria and the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Commonwealth Bank has taken action to recover more than $300,000 from the company, which has had significant financial problems. It is understood as well that the company owes $400,000 to the State Bank of Victoria, and as well, there is the $6m-the $3m in equity and $3m in loans-from the Victorian Investment Corporation. The Commonwealth Bank action was taken a couple of weeks ago. Indeed, on 8 September the bank wrote to Dr Peter Sheehan, who is the Deputy Chairman of the Victorian Investment Corporation, advising him that the bank had served a notice pursuant to section 364 of the Companies (Victoria) Code on O'Dowd Research Pty Ltd. Section 364 of the code details the circumstances in which a company may be wound up by the court and one of the primary components of that, of course, is that the company shall be deemed to be unable to pay its debts. I seek leave to table the letter from the bank to the Deputy Chairman of the Victorian Investment Corporation Ltd.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of this action by the Commonwealth Bank, and given that the grave financial difficulties facing O'Dowd Research are not unique in relation to the companies that the VEDC and the Victorian Investment Corporation have provided assistance to, I have today written to the Chairman of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation drawing to his attention the fact the his bank has taken formal action to recover these funds from O'Dowd Research and pointing out that in late 1986 the firm received $6m from the Victorian Government, in effect, through the VIC and the VEDC. I also drew to the Chairman's attention a reported statement by an officer of the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission that O'Dowd Research has failed to lodge returns for the 1986 and 1987 financial years.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the difficulties that so many of the companies that have received assistance from the VIC and the VEDC appear to be in, I have asked the Chairman of the bank to request that the bank review its lending policies as they apply to companies associated with both these Victorian Government financial institutions, to ensure that the interests of taxpayers in general, and Victorian taxpayers in particular, are fully safeguarded. This is a matter of very considerable importance, because it affects the public purse and, therefore, every taxpayer, every Australian and, in relation to Victorian financial institutions in particular, every Victorian taxpayer because that is where the buck stops when ventures of this nature run foul of normal commercial considerations.

Victorian taxpayers have been continually assaulted by the Cain Labor Government during the past 6 1/2 years. My letter to the Chairman of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Besley, is designed to ensure that at least in this area of Commonwealth Bank lending to institutions which have received assistance from the VEDC and the Victorian Investment Corporation much greater attention is given to safeguarding the interests of taxpayers. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my letter to the Chairman of the bank.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
29 September 1988
Mr M A Besley, AM
Chairman
Commonwealth Banking Corporation
Cnr Pitt Street & Martin Place
Sydney NSW 2000
Dear Mr Besley,
It has come to my attention that the Commonwealth Bank is taking formal action to recover more than $300,000 from the Melbourne based computer technology firm of O'Dowd Research Pty Ltd.

As you will be aware, this firm in late 1986 received $6 million, divided equally between equity and loans from the Victorian Investment Corporation, which is owned jointly by the Government of Victoria and the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.
You may also be aware of a reported statement by an officer of the Victorian Corporate Affairs Commission that O'Dowd Research has failed to lodge returns for the 1986 and 1987 financial years.

O'Dowd Research is only one of many companies which have received funding from the Victorian Investment Corporation and/or the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and which are in financial difficulties.
Any losses incurred by the V.I.C. or the V.E.D.C. of course are borne ultimately by the taxpayer. In essence the same applies to losses incurred by the Commonwealth Banking Corporation.
I do not know the extent of Commonwealth Bank loans to ventures with which the V.E.D.C. or the V.I.C. are involved.

In the light of reports about the parlous financial position of the V.E.D.C., and the V.I.C., however, I am writing to request that your Management and Board review the Bank's lending policies as they apply to companies associated with both these Victorian Government financial institutions to ensure that the interests of taxpayers in general, and Victorian taxpayers in particular, are fully safeguarded.
I am sending a copy of this letter to the Acting Treasurer for his information.
I look forward to hearing from you on this request at your earliest convenience.
Your sincerely,
JIM SHORT
cc. The Hon John Dawkins, Acting Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude by reminding the Senate of the importance of the election that will be held in Victoria on Saturday, 1 October. The result of that election will in many ways determine whether Victoria continues to slide into financial bankruptcy, as it has done inexorably over recent years under the gross and criminal economic mismanagement of the Hawke Government, or whether Victorians, by returning a Kennett Liberal government on Saturday, will give Victoria a chance to live and grow again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I did not get a chance to speak earlier on the General Business notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Crichton-Browne, I will use the opportunity to do so now-not only because I think I was personally attacked quite unjustifiably by the honourable senator but also because I think this is a very important issue which I want to address.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I will have to rely on your knowledge of the numbers of the Standing Orders, but I understand that there is a restriction in Standing Orders on the capacity of senators to address such matters on the adjournment. The matter to which the honourable senator refers was on the Notice Paper and was part of the general debate, and I think it is out of order for the debate to be continued during the adjournment debate in this way. I seek clarification on that point and your ruling on this matter.
—Does Senator Vallentine wish to speak to the point of order?

—Yes. The fact is that a number of people were on the speakers list. There was a restricted amount of time and not everybody could speak. I will withdraw my introductory remarks and make this an adjournment speech which happens to be on the same topic. I was planning to make a speech this evening anyway on the subject of nuclear warship visits. The fact that I did not get a chance to speak earlier is perhaps beside the point.

—Order! The point of order raised by Senator Chaney is correct. The matter is still on the Notice Paper and the honourable senator is not entitled to continue the debate. Her speech on the adjournment cannot be directly on the subject that is on the Notice Paper.
—That is okay. Can I continue my remarks in the adjournment--
—Senator Vallentine will have to be careful because a matter relating to the visit of American and Allied ships to Sydney is on the Notice Paper.

—May I clarify something, Mr Deputy President? Are you suggesting that I cannot make a speech on this topic while this subject remains on the Notice Paper? I am not allowed to make a speech if this matter remains on the Notice Paper for weeks or months? If that is the case, that is an outrageous situation.
—There is a 15-day limit.
—I have a right to speak on the subject.

—Order! There is a 15-day limit. Senator Vallentine can make her speech after this matter has been on the Notice Paper for 15 days. The honourable senator may speak on the adjournment, but she cannot speak on that subject.

—All right, I will speak on the topic of militarisation in general, which is not specific to the subject of the nuclear warship visits. I am opposed to the glorification of war under any guise whatsoever. I think it is most important that we do not glorify in the community any form of militarisation. I do not think we have to look very far to see the horrors of modern warfare.

SPEECH.PARA: I would concur with the comments that were made earlier by Senator MacGibbon on the subject of chemical and biological warfare. He is wrong to say that there has been an absolute silence from the peace movement on these subjects. We have spoken out on these topics. But, in fact, as often happens with media releases which are put out by individual members of parliament, there has not been a great deal of response. I have written letters about the nature of chemical warfare and what has been going on in Iraq, where the Kurdish people have suffered enormously in recent times. So it is quite incorrect to say that nothing has been said on that subject by people in the peace movement.

I would also like to point out that, as the peace movement in Australia is focusing on areas which Australia has direct involvement in and responsibility for, it is important that we speak out about chemical and biological warfare as well as nuclear weapons in general. But it is more relevant for the peace movement in Australia to direct its efforts to the active involvement of the Australian Government. As an elected representative, I think that is what it is my job to do. That is where I can have most influence on Australian public opinion. I can focus on Australia's involvement in the nuclear arms race in whatever guise that takes. I think it is most important that the peace movement is not criticised for not having opinions on international issues. We do have opinions on international issues but our most effective work can be done on Australia's direct involvement in the arms race. That is where we choose to pinpoint our community education programs.

I think it is also important to point out that nuclear weapons and the Western alliance have not preserved world peace for 43 years. This subject is often raised by members of the Opposition. I think this claim is an insult to the families of the 20 million people who have died since 1945-almost as many people as died in the Second World War. Many smaller wars, often proxy wars, have been fought by the super-powers, which use the smaller nations as pawns in the superpower rivalries. So I think it is most insulting to those countries to say that nuclear weapons have kept the peace or that there has not been a war since 1945. This just shows that there is a very clear misunderstanding of the nature of modern warfare.

Our security in Australia has nothing to do with belonging to ANZUS. I believe that we belong to ANZUS for one reason. As the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who has recently been relabelled the Minister for nuclear threat, has often said, we do so because we get cheap sophisticated military technology from the United States of America, which means that we have to buy into the war games that that country wants to play in order to test out those expensive systems. That is one of the reasons why we belong to that alliance. I believe that the benefits flow in the direction of the United States rather than in the direction of Australia.
I also want to correct something which is often said by people who criticise the peace movement-that is, that we are anti-American. This is arrant nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —And unilateral.

—It is absolute arrant nonsense for Senator Chaney to say that we are unilateralists. We are working for multilateral nuclear disarmament. It so happens that the bases in Australia are American. It so happens that many of the warships that visit Australia are American. In this case we are also protesting about the British ships, including the Ark Royal, which bear nuclear weapons. It is most important that this is understood. We would protest vigorously-and we do-against French militarisation in the Pacific. If French ships in the present naval review were bearing nuclear weapons, we would protest vigorously against them. We would also protest vigorously against the Chinese or the Soviets if their ships came into our ports. It happens that the ships bearing nuclear weapons in our ports at the moment are from the United States and the United Kingdom. So that is where we are directing our energies. Sometimes I think our energies are a little misguided. Actually, we should be directing our chief opposition to our own Government. After all, it is our own Government that has issued these kind invitations to the visiting warships.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is also important that we hold responsible our Government for putting us at risk. The Minister for Defence really ought to be defending Australia. He should be making sure that Australia and Australians are secure from any kind of risk or attack. But he is actually inviting risks. He is doing this on behalf of the Government and on behalf of the people of Australia. But 50 per cent of Australians quite clearly disagree with the Defence Minister putting us at risk by inviting these warships into our ports.

I think there are many better ways of fostering international understanding than by glamorising war, which is what I think we tend to do. We need to promote the learning of foreign languages, cultural exchanges, youth festivals and more events like the Indian Ocean festival of the arts which was held in Perth and the South Pacific event which was held in Townsville. These activities actually bring people of the region together and give them the opportunity to exchange a lot of very valuable cultural information. We can build better relationships by engaging in that kind of activity rather than by playing fancy war games with one of the superpowers.

Military activity makes the people of the region feel very ill at ease. There is no doubt at all that the people of the South Pacific see the French, the Americans and the Soviets as great threats to peace in the region. So we should not be involved with any of those superpowers by playing any fancy war games with them. These activities do not foster peaceful relationships but increase threats in our region.

I think it is also important to realise that governments have to make choices about where they spend their money. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the publication World Military and Social Expenditures 1987-88, which details, as the title suggests, how much individual countries are spending on militarisation around the world. There is an increasing call for governments to spend money on social programs-on health, education and welfare programs, on housing and on feeding people rather than feeding the arms race.

I just want to give a few examples of how money could be much more effectively spent on social programs than on weapons systems of any kind which I believe increase our insecurity. I do not believe that they make us any more secure in any way at all. For example, 50 MX so-called `Peacekeepers'-and I emphasise that that word is in inverted commas because they are violent weapons with multiple re-entry vehicles which can do an enormous amount of damage; the United States Government calls these weapons `Peacekeepers', which I think is a highly offensive euphemism-costing $4.5 billion could equal a year's cost of the United States health program for long term home care of about one million chronically ill children and elderly people. The citizens of the United States-and I was there recently-are railing against their own Government's outrageous expense on militarism. For example, that country's research on Star Wars for the fiscal year 1988, almost $4 trillion, would equal an elementary school education for 1 1/2 million children in Latin America. I think we should be paying attention to these non-military options rather than increasing the risk to all people on planet Earth by wastefully expending this amount of money on weapons systems.

One Trident submarine costing $1 1/2 billion would equal a five-year program for universal child immunisation against six deadly diseases, preventing one million deaths a year. The United Nations Children's Fund has an international program of trying to rid children of these six deadly diseases against which immunisation is available but the funding is not forthcoming. For the cost of one Trident submarine those sorts of problems could be solved. These are the sorts of choices that internationally and as a global community we have to start making. I think that the people who want peace through strength are those who are also concerned about India's rearmament, about Indonesia, about Libya, and about the Soviet threat. Some of these people talk of an all oceans alliance, involving countries with a well-known respect for human rights and democracy like Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea and Indonesia. Their records are highly dubious in areas of human rights.

On the Australian Broadcasting Corporation midday show today defence analysts were trying to work out why Malaysia was spending such a massive amount on rearmament. They came to the conclusion that Malaysia felt it necessary to follow the example of neighbours who were also expanding their military might. This is exactly the problem with the arms race. It has an escalating effect. A threat perception is seen by one country or a group of countries. Their ideological opponents, or even their neighbours who are not necessarily ideologically opposed, see a threat and immediately feel that they must try to keep up with the competition. I think that is a great shame. We should not be part of encouraging that kind of thinking to go ahead.

People who want peace through strength cannot have it both ways. It is a recipe for war, not for real long term security. It provides the momentum for the arms race and diverts resources from real human needs, which is where I believe we should be directing them. Real security comes through removing the causes of war. I have frequently advocated increased overseas aid. Currently we spend 0.36 per cent of gross national product on aid despite the original United Nations target of 0.7 per cent. So Australia is about halfway to what it should be providing in terms of the United Nations intended levels of expenditure. Australia is one of the most affluent countries. I think we should be going ahead with that rather than cutting down our foreign aid. With that aid goes trade. We object to unfair trading pressure from the United States-our first rate ally and second rate friend, as our relationship could be described. But our smaller trading partners also want fair terms to reduce their economic insecurity.

At the recent Parliamentary Christian Fellowship meeting we heard the Assistant Bishop of Canberra and Goulburn, the Reverend Bruce Wilson. He had just been to the Lambeth Conference of the Church of England in the United Kingdom. He said that what became very obvious at that conference was that the call, particularly from fellow bishops from developing countries and from the Pacific, was for economic security. That is what they are calling for. They are not looking for defence arrangements. They are saying, `We can be more secure if we have economic security and independence'. They are very keen to build better relationships. That is exactly what we should be doing. In some respects our Government is doing that. I think that its position is rather hypocritical when one lines it up against the fact that we are also part of a military and nuclear defence arrangement with the United States. I think that is a great hypocrisy of our Government's position at the moment.

I do not believe there is any security whatsoever in nuclear weapons. At the moment we have a number of nuclear weapons in Sydney Harbour for this fleet review. There is a wave of opposition around the world to nuclear port calls. The United States Navy is increasingly frustrated by protests, not just in Australia but in Denmark; New Zealand, which has been very strong on this issue; Palau; Spain; the Philippines; the North Atlantic network, which has just met for its fourth conference in Glasgow; the Pacific campaign to disarm the seas, which has just met in Sydney; and the Greenpeace disarm the seas campaign. All these campaigns are contributing to this growing opposition to the deployment of nuclear weapons at sea. Of course, we must not forget the domestic opposition to the deployment of nuclear weapons in various ports in the United States. Senator Dunn mentioned the New York situation when she spoke earlier. The same thing is happening in San Francisco. There is enormous domestic opposition to crowded ports being used for the entry of nuclear weapons in the United States and, of course, to nuclear weapons at sea. There are 16,000 nuclear weapons now at sea, which is a third, roughly speaking, of the total number of nuclear warheads.

The peace movement is turning towards demands for naval arms control, which is a very important subject. It is one which was not allowed to be part of the discussions at the special session on disarmament in New York which I attended. It was interesting to note that the United States refused to allow any mention of the naval arms race, yet this is where the arms race is escalating most rapidly in the world at the moment. Weapons at sea are not part of any arms control agreements. They are very difficult to locate because they are moving around. They can hide out in the depths of the ocean. There is no visible opposition to those weapons as they float around the seas. But the risks with the armaments being deployed at sea are enormous. For example, if there was a breakdown in communications from any vessel and there was an emergency or a situation of high tension or high risk then the commanders of the vessels would be very tempted to use their nuclear payloads if they lost contact with headquarters. That is not a wild proposition but something which is quite likely and which I have discussed with former admirals of the United States Navy as a distinct proposition. They are extremely worried about the autonomy of naval commanders at sea in a risk situation if they have lost contact.

We really need to focus a lot of attention on the arms race as part of this international campaign. Here in Australia we are participating in the growth of the arms race at sea by hosting the visits of nuclear armed warships. By inviting these ships to visit our ports-Senator MacGibbon is right; they are here at the invitation of our Government-we are saying to the nuclear navies of the world, `We approve of what you are doing. We think it is fine for you to hold the world's people to ransom by trundling your nuclear weapons all around the world's oceans'. I think that is a totally unacceptable proposition.

In more general terms we must overcome our preoccupation and obsession with East-West issues and peace through strength. Security in this part of the world means economic security, not greater expenditure on weapons of destruction. Public opinion is now leading the way in saying no to nuclear armed ship visits and the politicians must now follow. In the Small and Associates Pty Ltd polls over 50 per cent of Australians have said month after month for the year of 1988 that they disapprove of the Government continuing to invite these risks into our ports. So I think it is very appropriate that Mr Beazley has now been dubbed the Minister for nuclear risks. It is an unnecessary risk which he is inviting into our ports and I think that as the Minister for Defence he should be defending Australia against risks and not inviting risks into our ports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators know, it is now the tax season. Like the concern I had last evening, I have another concern about the Government locking up money in this Treasury that belongs to taxpayers with the add-on figure to provisional tax. Going back some 10 odd years, provisional tax was the same as the past year's tax. That amount was used as a figure for provisional tax. Under a Liberal government there was some sort of concoction brought up by which about 5 per cent was added to last year's tax bill for next year's provisional tax. That remained much the same until the last year of the Liberal Government when it put that up to 10 per cent. At that time inflation was running somewhere near that figure.

SPEECH.PARA: When this present Labor Government came into power in 1983 it immediately increased the figure to 11 per cent and has kept it there. The Government has claimed since those years that it has got hold of inflation and forced it down. But by the same token it has still insisted on leaving that add-on figure for provisional tax at 11 per cent. That adds up to a lot of dollars. I will give some figures. In 1983-84, when we arrived at the figure of 11 per cent, the inflation rate was 5.8 per cent. We had the figure of 11 per cent add-on. In 1985-86 the inflation rate was 8.4 per cent. We still had the 11 per cent add-on figure. In 1987-88 the inflation rate was officially 7.3 per cent, but we still had that 11 per cent add-on. The Government and the Treasury, having pushed the add-on figure up to 10 and then 11 per cent to counteract inflation, would, if they were dinkum, use the same criteria when inflation goes down and reduce the figure. It is time the Government brought that figure into line. That provisional figure represents an interest free loan to the Government. As I said last night in respect of the diesel fuel rebate, it is a matter of locking up interest free funds in the Treasury at certain times of the year.

Another small matter which I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate at this late hour concerns the fiasco with the capital gains tax. It is ridiculous that the dividends on a parcel of shares, whether it is large or small-I am more worried about the small investors such as old people who have retired and have a parcel of shares-are to be automatically reinvested. That means that every year a certain number of shares-it might be only 10 shares if a person has a parcel of 500 and the dividend is enough to buy 30 or 40 shares-attract a bought-in value. Every year that parcel of shares has a new date of acquisition. I know that the capital gains tax has not been in place for very long but, looking down the track seven or eight years in the case of, say, a deceased estate, a person with 500-odd shares, or any small parcel, will have to calculate the capital gains tax at 11 different dates. The first is the acquisition date and the others are the dates on which that person receives the 10 dividends every year.

Even though the capital gains tax has been in operation for only 3, 4 or 5 years-and I have the figures-it has reached the stage where, especially in a post-crash situation, no profit is made but the accounting fees taken away or added on amount to far more than the value of the dividends. This will multiply if the system remains in place for the next 20 or 30 years. We have pointed out that if there is a change of government that sort of thing will disappear within five years. As a result of the ill-thought out capital gains tax, in many cases accounting fees will increase and many people will not be able to afford them. I urge the Government, if it will not remove this iniquitous tax, to consider how it will administer that sort of thing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.04 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 2 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Have any offset obligations incurred under the civil offsets program, which have not been satisfactorily discharged, been written off since 30 June 1985; if so, what specific obligations were written off and what were the reasons for the individual write-offs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) No civil offsets obligations have been written off. Records of unfulfilled obligations are maintained indefinitely and negotiations will be recommenced should the supplier again bid for Government business.
(ii) Three civil offsets obligations have been identified which are unlikely to be fulfilled. All arose from purchases made several years ago.
They include:
- Two obligations which were incurred by corporations which ceased trading soon thereafter.
- The third was inadequately secured by an agreement which included a ``best efforts'' clause and was ambiguous to the extent that no action could be taken by the offsets authority.
These unfulfilled agreements total about $30m in value and make up less than 2 per cent of the Civil Offsets Program's achievements.

Abolition and creation of ASO positions was carried out in conjunction with introduction of new Divisional and Branch structures, with the endorsement of relevant Staff Associations and with the interests of affected staff in mind, particularly as substantial reductions in the overall number of positions occurred.
The majority of ASO positions created would have functions generally similar to positions in the former Departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2391), Senator Coulter asked Senator Walsh, as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, a question without notice concerning the occurrence of cadmium in Australian food. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia does not have the sort of cadmium pollution that occurs in the industrial countries of the northern hemisphere and therefore the use of the word pollution to describe the Australian situation is somewhat exaggerated. Some incremental cadmium may accrue from the application of fertilizers derived from phosphatic deposits and this may be of significance in areas where other factors, such as soil acidity, favour uptake by plants.

Directly or indirectly, soil is the source of cadmium for grazing cattle and sheep, but the distribution of high cadmium levels in the kidneys of sheep and cattle is not always correlated with the use of phosphatic fertilizers. The factors governing uptake and accumulation of cadmium in plant and animal tissues are complex and not well understood.
Kidney levels tend to increase with age, and higher levels are found in females than in males. Kidneys have higher levels than liver and negligible levels are found in muscle.

The 1986 National Residue Survey found 7 per cent of wheat samples analysed for cadmium to contain more than 0.05 mg/kg of cadmium. In the 1987 survey period only 2.86 per cent of samples were above 0.05 mg/kg. Since that period no further violations on wheat have been reported.

There is no record of a shipment of Australian wheat being rejected by Sweden because of cadmium contamination. Indeed, the last shipment of Australian wheat direct to Sweden appears to have been made in 1953. Sweden is a net exporter of wheat and is only a small and irregular importer.

The 1986 National Residue Survey found that 21.3 per cent of sheep kidneys and 12 per cent of beef kidneys sampled exceeded the Australian standard of 2.5 mg/kg for bovine and ovine kidney. The Western Australian data showed 47.1 per cent of sheep kidneys exceeded that level not 75 per cent as mentioned by the honourable Senator.

The samples analysed since 1986 show a somewhat lower incidence of levels exceeding the Australian standard. Only 8.6 per cent of sheep kidneys and 4.7 per cent of cattle kidneys had levels above 2.5 mg/kg, while the figures for Western Australia were 26.8 per cent for sheep and 14.7 per cent for cattle.

The complex issues governing the uptake of cadmium by plants and animals are being investigated by the Bureau of Rural Resources in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in close consultation with State agencies, the CSIRO and the NH&MRC.
